Pacific Gas and Electric Company PG&E Awards $200,000 to Drive Job Creation in
California Communities

LENGTH: 541 words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Terrebonne: Electric Energy Quebec has issued the following release news:



  Local community vitality and economic development programs just received a
boost through PG&E's Better Together Giving Programs. PG&E is awarding a total
of $200,000 in Economic Vitality Grants to 10 worthy local community
organizations. Each organization will receive $20,000 to help grow a specific
program or project focused on local business development, job creation or
workforce training.





 "PG&E supports organizations that are committed to creating local jobs and
training workers because they're making life better for their families, our
communities and California as a whole," said PG&E's Helen Burt, senior vice
president of external affairs and public policy.



 From left, PG&E's Rob Morse presents a $20,000 grant to Digital NEST. Also
pictured, second from left, are Watsonville Mayor Felipe Hernandez, Digital NEST
board chair Michelle Bassi and Jacob Martinez, founder and executive director of
the organization.



 The funding determinations for this grant program were competitive, with more
than 200 applications received. All applications were evaluated by a third party
that based its recommendations on a combination of factors, including the
strength of the plans presented, demonstrable links to job creation and
community need.



 The Northern Rural Communities Development, Inc. (NRCD) was selected as one of
this year's grant winners for the organization's high school and career
"train-the-trainer" classes on manufacturing technology, and identifying
potential manufacturing sites in Oroville.



 "This grant will help the Grow Manufacturing Initiative support and expand our
North State manufacturing sector, and support the next generation manufacturing
workforce," said Michael Cross, executive director of NRCD.



 Eligible grantees for this PG&E Corporation shareholder-funded program included
local government organizations, educational institutions and 501(c) 3 nonprofit
organizations within the company's 70,000-square-mile service area.



 Better Together Economic Vitality Grant Winners



     Fresno Community Development Financial Institution, Fresno. Training and
technical assistance for low-income entrepreneurs.



     San Joaquin County Office of Education, Stockton. Career Development
Training.



     Amador Community College Foundation, Sutter Creek. Career-building
opportunities for students.



     Mendocino Private Industry Council, Inc., Ukiah. Vocational training for
at-risk youth.

     Northern Rural Communities Development, Inc., Chico. Initiative to expand
the manufacturing industry.



     West Sacramento Foundation, West Sacramento. Job training for you in
engineering design and technology.



     Digital NEST, Watsonville. Ag-tech App development boot camp.



     Mission Community Services, San Luis Obispo. Support for entrepreneurs and
women-owned businesses.



     Center for Media Change, Inc. (d.b.a., Hack the Hood), Oakland. Tech
training for low-income youth.



     San Jose Conservation Corps & Charter School, San Jose. Turf conversion
training program for at-risk youth.

                                 Final Edition

News in brief DOVER-FOXCROFT: PARKMAN WOMAN HIRED AS COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT
SPECIALIST

SECTION: Pg. C3

LENGTH: 193 words


The Piscataquis County Economic Development Council has hired Sheila Grant of
Parkman as the council's community development specialist. The part-time
position was created through a USDA Rural Community Development Initiative grant
and matching PCEDC funds. "This is a big step for the PCEDC, and we're delighted
to have Sheila come on board," Mark Scarano, PCEDC executive director, said
Friday. Grant will assist communities with economic development initiatives,
improved tourism infrastructure and affordable housing issues. She also will
assist nonprofits in the region with capacity building and economic development
strategies. The Parkman resident has served as executive director of the
Dover-Foxcroft Affiliate of Literacy Volunteers, was a Piscataquis Observer
reporter, and most recently served as executive director of the Piscataquis
County Soil and Water Conservation District. Grant, a 2004 graduate of the
Penquis Leadership Institute, co-wrote the Piscataquis Region Cultural Heritage
Directory published by the Cultural Heritage Eco-tourism Committee and helped
produce the 2004 Southern Piscataquis County Chamber of Commerce Visitors Guide.

Washington: Klobuchar, Franken, Peterson, Nolan Announce USDA Grant Awarded to
Boost Rural Economic Development in Minnesota

LENGTH: 409  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: Office of the MP Collin Peterson has issued the following news
release:



 U.S. Senators Amy Klobuchar and Al Franken, along with Representatives Collin
Peterson and Rick Nolan, today announced that the U.S. Department of Agriculture
(USDA) has awarded a grant to Minnesota's The Initiative Foundation. The USDA
awarded grants to 23 organizations to support rural and economic development
projects. The Initiative Foundation in Minnesota was selected for a $173,372
grant to provide training, technical assistance and financial support to 20
non-profit intermediaries that are locally-based and skilled in business
development and job creation.





 "Minnesota's own The Initiative Foundation was chosen to receive this grant
because of its dedication to improving rural economies," said Klobuchar. "Our
nation's strength is anchored in our rural com unities. This grant will ensure
that The Initiative Foundation can continue to support the important job
creation and business development efforts of Minnesota's non-profits."



 "Investing in our rural com unities is good for Minnesota's overall economic
health and it's good for the entire country," said Franken. "And one of my top
priorities it to expand our workforce and get people the training they need for
middle-class, good-paying jobs. This new support will help create jobs and
economic opportunity in rural Minnesota."



 "Making investments in rural com unities and connecting important resources to
rural citizens is essential to keeping rural areas thriving," Peterson said.
"This grant will support job creation and benefit the rural economy."



 "Here in Minnesota's Eighth District, our rural economy depends on small
business development and job creation," Nolan said. "This grant for The
Initiative Foundation will help bolster our rural com unities by providing the
training, technical assistance and financial support needed to support these
important rural and economic development projects."



 The award is being provided through the Rural Community Development Initiative
(RCDI) program. RCDI helps com unity-based development organizations and other
groups promote economic development in low-incom , rural com unities. Awards are
provided to public or non-profit intermediaries that are locally-based and
skilled in business development and job creation.

                                August 27, 2014

USDA offers grants for rural nonprofits

BYLINE: The Camp Verde Journal staff

LENGTH: 275  words


Alan Stephens, Arizona state director for U.S. Department of Agriculture Rural
Development, is encouraging Arizona community development entities to submit
applications for USDA's Rural Community Development Initiative grants.

Nearly $6 million is available nationally for the grant program. The deadline
for submitting RCDI applications is Wednesday, Nov. 12.

The grants, which range from $50,000 to $250,000, are intended for qualified
intermediary organizations.

Those intermediaries will then use the funds to provide financial and technical
assistance to ultimate recipients so they can develop their capacity to
undertake projects in the areas of housing, community facilities or community
and economic development.

"Many rural nonprofits often need capital and technical assistance to carry out
their missions," Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack said. "These grants will
provide both of these components through local and regional organizations that
are experts at delivering such services."

Recipients must be nonprofit organizations, low-income rural communities or
federally recognized tribes. Intermediary organizations are required to provide
matching funds at least equal to the RCDI grants. The grants do not go directly
to business recipients but rather through qualified intermediaries.

"This is a great opportunity for Arizona's rural areas to access grant funding
for community development," Stephens said.

For information on applying for the RCDI grant, contact USDA Rural Development
at (602) 280-8745.

"There was a real feeling of hope and prosperity. The government was shaping
up."

Deborah Strange

Former University Instructor in Kurdistan

                   Commonwealth Journal (Somerset, Kentucky)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            November 8, 2011 Tuesday

Beshear at Center to announce $1 million in ARC grants for eastern Kentucky

BYLINE: Chris Harris, Commonwealth Journal, Somerset, Ky.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 993 words


Nov. 08--SOMERSET -- The Center for Rural Development will be at the forefront
of a new initiative designed to transform the way wealth is transferred in
eastern Kentucky.

Gov. Steve Beshear made a stop in Somerset only a day before Kentucky voters
decide whether or not to keep him in office. The purpose? To announce -- along
with Chris Girdler representing Congressman Hal Rogers, who was unable to attend
in person due to business in Washington -- over $1 million in grant money to
support the support the Appalachian Rural Development Philanthropy Initiative
(ARDPI).

"This investment is not in a  building or a road or a sewer line or some other
physical infrastructure," said the governor. "We're investing in something more
complex and far-reaching. Something more sustainable, (the impact of which) can
be exponentially much greater."

The initiative makes possible "the development of permanent, accessible
community foundations in Eastern Kentucky that will work to secure local assets
to provide long-term resources for their communities," according to the
governor's office.

What exactly does that mean? Les Fugate, COO for The Center, explained that it's
a way to help money that's donated philanthropically to be best distributed to
those areas and agencies that need it most.

"The Appalachian Regional Commission (ARC) is investing in the development of
community foundations, (which are) essentially community savings accounts,"
Fugate told the Commonwealth Journal.

"A local community can capture some of the assets that are (already in it) and
reinvest that back in," he continued. "For instance, let's say there's someone
who really cares about their local community that has a passion for education.
They can create an endowment, leave some money in that endowment for education,
and the community itself would grant that money back out to whatever educational
initiative in the local community they want to invest in."

Keeping that money based at home is crucial, something which Beshear stressed.

"We all know about the talent and skill we lose from time to time with the
out-migration of young people from our state, and particularly from eastern
Kentucky," said Beshear. "Lesser attention is given to a simultaneous and
equally troubling loss: the migration of wealth, as the assets that have been
built up by families and businesses over the years migrate out. When that wealth
is inherited by a generation that has already left the community, it's unlikely
that it's going to be brought back into the community, either as a business
investment or philanthropic giving."

Beshear noted that studies have indicated there's indeed "quite a bit of such
private assets" in some of Kentucky's poorest counties -- and thus, an
opportunity for the individuals worth that money to make sure that some of it is
available through ARDPI.

The Center's role in all of this is to "provide overall strategic, planning,
education, and promotion of this initiative," said Beshear. The Center will be
providing ongoing technical support and training needs for all the partners
involved.

"The Center ... feels extremely fortunate to be a partner in ARDPI ... because
it fits right in with our mission, what we do each and every day, and that's
trying to improve the quality of life for the residents we serve," said Lonnie
Lawson, president and CEO of The Center.

"This initiative will help grow the economy of our region by allowing wealth
that is already here to remain here," he added. "It blends perfectly with ...
all the affiliate organizations that are located here, all the non-profits that
serve this entire region. The most exciting part of this effort is that it truly
empowers communities."

The ARC grants have a two-year cycle, and are worth $1,004,000 in total.

As many as 11 distressed Appalachian counties will benefit initially from ARDPI:
Bell, Clay, Elliott, Knott, Knox, Lawrence, Letcher, Lewis, Magoffin, Martin and
Whitley.

Pulaski County is not among them, at least not right now, as it isn't considered
economically "distressed." However, noted Fugate, "What we hope to do at The
Center is be able to take the knowledge base that we learn and eventually be
able to turn that back around and work in counties that aren't distressed.

"In year two (of the grant), The Center's going to pick up some additional
counties, and we know that some of the counties surrounding Pulaski are also
looking at this," said Fugate. "Don't worry, The Center won't let Pulaski County
be forgotten."

ARDPI's program work will include regional planning, training for communities,
development of an on-the-ground consultant program, and the use of mini-grants
to assist communities in planning for securing and leveraging local resources.

The Center for Rural Development specifically will get a $582,150 slice of the
million-dollar pie to implement its role in the initiative, along with several
other agencies: the Brushy Fork Institute in Berea, the Foundation for the
Tri-State Community in Ashland, and the Community Foundation of Hazard and Perry
County.

Beshear called ARDPI a "powerful community development tool." It seems that
communities were on Beshears' mind, as he spoke highly of Somerset and Pulaski
County, and praised Congressman Rogers, along with the county's state
legislators such as Tommy Turner and Terry Mills, for their work in bringing the
county to the point that it can be a leader rather than be in need.

"Let me say how excited I am to be in this community," said Beshear. "This whole
area has been developing vibrant economies even in the toughest of economic
times. I'm excited about the partnership I've been able to have with our local
officials here, both elected, business, community and economic development
folks. We've had a great partnership, and it's paid results."

___ (c)2011 the Commonwealth Journal (Somerset, Ky.) Visit the Commonwealth
Journal (Somerset, Ky.) at somerset-kentucky.com Distributed by MCT Information
Services

Utah: Rural Community Development Initiative (RCDI)

LENGTH: 232  words

DATELINE: Salt Lake City


Office of Rural Assistance Center, The State of Utah has issued the following
news release:

Sponsor  USDA Rural Development
Deadlines  Nov 12, 2014
Contact

A list of state contacts is available on the program website.
Purpose

The Rural Community Development Initiative (RCDI) awards grants to develop the
capacity and ability of nonprofit organizations, low-income rural communities,
or federally recognized tribes to undertake projects related to housing,
community facilities, or community and economic development in rural areas.

Funds can be used for, but are not limited to, the following purposes:

Provide technical assistance and training on how to develop successful childcare
facilities
    Provide training on effective fundraising techniques
    Build organizational capacity through board training
    Develop training tools to be used by sub-grantees
    Train sub-grantees to conduct a program on homeownership education
    Train sub-grantees to conduct a program for minority business owners

Eligibility

Applicants must be qualified private, nonprofit, including faith-based and
community organizations, in accordance with 7 CFR part 16, and public (including
tribal) intermediary organizations.
Geographic
coverage  Nationwide
Amount of
funding

Total Funding Available: $5,967,000
Award Ceiling: $250,000
Award Floor: $50,000

For further information please visit: http://www.raconline.org/

                        The Atlanta Journal-Constitution

                     January 27, 2002 Sunday, Home Edition
                              Correction Appended

Politics splitting regional initiative

BYLINE: JANITA POE

SOURCE: AJC

SECTION: News; Pg. 1B

LENGTH: 774 words


Over the past eight months, two factors have lurked unspoken behind the numerous
discussions of the Black Belt Initiative's plans to eradicate poverty in the
rural South.

Power and money.

The pair has been the driving force behind intense e-mail debates over how a
federal commission on the Southern Black Belt should operate, and what it should
do.

They have produced grandstanding at meetings in Atlanta and Tuskegee, Ala.

They have created alliances between like-minded people and groups: poor states,
large universities, rural agencies and big-city community development centers.

Many are worried that certain programs may never get funding if the commission
comes to pass.

"There is a huge amount at stake here," said Black Belt Initiative participant
James Ledbetter, a University of Georgia official who also works for U.S. Sen.
Zell Miller (D-Ga.), the most visible elected official supporting the group.

"The problems of the Black Belt have gotten worse over time. Now this group is
proposing to come together and do something about it." Political gamesmanship,
he said, will be intense.

The goal of helping the poor is central to all Black Belt Initiative
participants, many of them chiefs of funding-hungry development groups such as
the Georgia Community Development Association in Atlanta.

Running such agencies requires persistent networking, lobbying and grant
writing, tasks the high-profile, 11-state Black Belt commission would make
significantly easier.

By being involved in setting up such a commission, individuals and groups stand
to increase their visibility and reap hundreds of thousands of dollars a year
for their programs and organizations.

At a meeting of the Black Belt Initiative in Atlanta last week, there was a
split between UGA officials and participants who had worked on a project
detailing community development services available in the Black Belt region.

With $500,000 in funding from the federal government and from Macon businessman
Benjamin W. Griffith, UGA has begun a study of the area. But members of the
research group said UGA did not communicate with them about the study.

"The idea was that our research would raise the visibility of community-based
organizations in the Black Belt," said Ava Hopkins, a Birmingham community
organizer who co-chaired the research group.

"I'm concerned about the unilateral decision-making here. You don't come back
with a redefined scope of work and ignore what we've done." "While UGA says it
is operating in good faith, their actions have suggested they are making side
decisions," Hopkins said.

In his talks with fellow initiative members, UGA's Ledbetter said he has made it
clear he is not aligning with any specific interest.

His work on what participants call "the Miller study" is available as a
reference for the Black Belt Initiative and any others interested in investing
money in economic and community development in the Southeast, he said.

Ledbetter said he is concerned that divisions and developing alliances might
mean that no group gets the funding it needs to improve the quality of life in
the South's most impoverished counties.  "When there are competing interests
with competing constituencies," Ledbetter said, "that is a recipe, generally,
for getting nothing done." Despite the divisions and philosophical differences,
the Black Belt Initiative has managed to navigate through some thorny debates.
After disputes at meetings in both Tuskegee and Atlanta, for instance, the group
has managed to pull itself together and agree on some goals.

"Many of the people around this table have been engaged in this work for years,
some since the early '60s," said Alabaman Stephen Wilson, who was elected last
week to lead a steering committee for the group. "We've hashed things out, but
left stronger and determined that this is the solution."

A review of the Black Belt Initiative's latest roster --- there are
representatives from 11 states --- shows there are quite a few people at the
table, making it even more difficult to come to some consensus on issues. That
the various states and organizations have been able to work together so far
speaks to the common desire to develop

"People who are not able to contribute to society are a strong burden on the
state and nation," said Art Dunning, the associate UGA provost who, with
Tuskegee University, helped coordinate the eight months of Black Belt Initiative
research and meetings.

"The benefits of developing a successful public-private partnership are huge.
We're talking about turning around decades of persistent poverty."

LOAD-DATE: January 30, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

CORRECTION-DATE: January 29, 2002

CORRECTION: A story in Sunday's News section about the Black Belt Initiative's
plans to eradicate poverty in the rural South dropped the last lines in the
third to last paragraph. The complete paragraph should have read: A review of
the Black Belt Initiative's latest roster --- there are representatives from 11
states --- shows there are quite a few people at the table, making it even more
difficult to come to some consensus on issues. That the various states and
organizations have been able to work together so far speaks to the common desire
to develop a powerful Black Belt alliance, participants said.

Sen. Zell Miller (D-Ga.) has led efforts to gain help for the Southern Black
Belt Initiative.

                                US Official News

Washington: Costa Statement on President Trump's FY2018 Budget Blueprint

LENGTH: 1583  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: Office of the MP Jim Costa has issued the following news release:



 Today, Rep. Jim Costa (CA-16) released the following statement on President
Donald Trump's FY2018 Budget Blueprint.



 "For someone who was elected with strong support from rural America, the
President's budget blueprint shows very little consideration for the people who
live in America's farming communities. Federal grants, like the Community
Development Block Grant and TIGER Grant, are critical funding streams for our
San Joaquin Valley, and President Trump wants to completely eliminate them.
Furthermore, the budget blueprint cuts the U.S. Department of Agriculture's
(USDA) budget by 21 percent. The USDA oversees an array of programs, from
supporting Valley farmers, investing in rural development, increasing drought
resilience to managing forest cleanup and wildfire prevention.





 "By adding $54 billion in military spending and cutting core programs, like
those that ensure safe drinking water, provide protection from floods, fund
cancer research and invest in our children's education, the budget blueprint
shifts the fundamental way in which the federal government supports the American
people.  This proposal would prove to have negative consequences for the
majority of Americans, and in failing to address the main drivers of the federal
debt, it is not a serious outline to putting our country on a path forward for
fiscal sustainability."

 Summary of cuts in Budget Blueprint:

 Department of Agriculture



 The President's 2018 Budget requests $17.9 billion for USDA, a $4.7 billion or
21 percent decrease.



 Eliminates the following programs:



     Water and Waste Disposal Loan and Grant Program: Provides funding for clean
drinking water, sanitary sewage disposal and storm-water drainage programs in
rural areas.

     Rural Business and Cooperative Service's discretionary programs: Provides
financial assistance for economic development programs in rural communities,
including renewable energy and biofuel initiatives.

     McGovern-Dole International Food for Education Program: Supports education,
child development and food security initiatives in low-income, food-deficit
countries around the world.



 Department of Commerce



 The President's 2018 Budget requests $7.8 billion for the Department of
Commerce, a $1.5 billion or 16 percent decrease.



 Eliminates the following programs:



     Economic Development Administration: Provides grants and assistance to
create new jobs, retain businesses and stimulate growth in economically
distressed communities.

     Minority Business Development Agency: Promotes the growth of minority-owned
businesses through advocacy, policy, research and access to capital and
contracts.

     Manufacturing Extension Partnership: Regional centers that assist smaller,
U.S. manufacturing companies with adopting new technologies.



 Department of Education



 The President's 2018 Budget provides $59 billion in discretionary funding for
the Department of Education, a $9 billion or 13 percent reduction.



 Eliminates the following programs:



     Supporting Effective Instruction State Grants: Provides grants to
non-profit organizations that recruit and provide professional enhancement for
teachers and principals.

     21st Century Community Learning Centers: Supports community learning
centers that provide before-and after-school programs for children, particularly
those in high-poverty areas.

     Federal Supplemental Educational Opportunity Grant: Provides need-based
grants of up to $4,000 to low-income undergraduates for postsecondary education.


     Striving Readers: Helps states fund literacy programs for children, birth
through grade 12, including those with disabilities and limited English.

     Teacher Quality Partnership: Funds initiatives aimed at improving the
quality of new teachers through better development and recruiting methods.

     Impact Aid Support Payments for Federal Property: Provides funding to
school districts that have a diminished tax base due to federal property
ownership in the district.



 Department of Energy



 The President's 2018 Budget requests $28.0 billion for DOE, a $1.7 billion or
5.6 percent decrease.



 Eliminates the following programs:



     Advanced Research Projects Agency-Energy: Provides funding and support to
short-term energy research projects aimed at improving the U.S. economy,
environment and national security.

     Title 17 Innovative Technology Loan Guarantee Program: Provides loans to
support the use of new energy technology.

     Advanced Technology Vehicle Manufacturing Program: Provides loans to
automotive and component manufacturers for facilities and engineering that
support advanced technology vehicles.

     Weatherization Assistance Program: Provides grants to local governments to
improve weatherization and energy efficiency of homes of low-income residents.

     State Energy Program: Supports local State Energy Offices in advancing
energy efficiency and infrastructure.



 Department of Health and Human Services



 The President's 2018 Budget requests $69.0 billion for HHS, a $15.1 billion or
17.9 percent decrease.



 Eliminates the following programs:



     Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program: Provides assistance to low
income families to help pay for their home's energy bills and some
energy-related maintenance.

     Community Services Block Grant: Funds projects aimed at reducing poverty in
communities, including projects focused on education, nutrition, employment and
housing.



 Department of Housing and Urban Development



 The President's 2018 Budget requests $40.7 billion in gross discretionary
funding for HUD, a $6.2 billion or 13.2 percent decrease.



 Eliminates funding for the following programs:



     Community Development Block Grant Program: Funds programs that assist
low-income people with housing issues, including the elimination of urban blight
and other community programs.

     HOME Investment Partnerships Program: Provides block grants to state and
local governments to create affordable housing solutions for low-income
households.

     Choice Neighborhoods: Funds programs to replace distressed public housing
and promotes investment for neighborhood improvement.

     Self-Help Homeownership Opportunity Program: Funds nonprofit organizations
that build new housing for low-income families through sweat equity and
volunteer labor, like Habitat for Humanity.

     Section 4 Capacity Building for Community Development and Affordable
Housing: Works with nonprofit groups to fund community development and
affordable housing initiatives aimed at low-income families.



 Department of Labor



 The President's 2018 Budget requests $9.6 billion for the Department of Labor,
a $2.5 billion or 21 percent decrease.



 Eliminates the following programs:



     Senior Community Service Employment Program: A community service and
work-based job training program for older Americans, including training for
low-income, unemployed seniors.

     Bureau of International Labor Affairs grant program: Provides funding for
research initiatives and projects in over 94 countries to combat child labor and
forced labor.

     Occupational Safety and Health Administration training grants: Provides
grants for training and education programs for employers and workers on the
prevention of safety and health hazards in the workplace.



 Department of Transportation



 The President's 2018 Budget requests $16.2 billion for DOT's discretionary
budget, a $2.4 billion or 13 percent decrease.



 Eliminates the following programs:



     Federal support for Amtrak's long distance train services: Subsidizes the
cost of traveling on Amtrak's long-distance routes.

     Essential Air Service: Subsidizes airlines for regular flights to and from
small and midsize regional airports like those in the San Joaquin Valley.

     TIGER discretionary grant program: Provides transportation infrastructure
grants to state, local and tribal governments.



 Environmental Protection Agency



 The President's 2018 Budget requests $5.7 billion for the Environmental
Protection Agency, a savings of $2.6 billion, or 31 percent decrease.



 Eliminates the following programs:



     Clean Power Plan: Creates national standards for carbon pollution from
power plants and helps states develop and deploy clean energy alternatives.

     International climate change programs: Promotes clean and efficient energy
technologies and the sharing of scientific climate research through multilateral
initiatives and treaties.

     Climate change research and partnership programs: Research and report on
climate change's impact on the U.S.

     Energy Star: Certifies and recognizes buildings and consumer products that
meet specific energy-efficiency criteria.

     Targeted Air Shed grants: Assists local and state air pollution control
agencies in developing plans and implementing projects to reduce air pollution
in highly polluted areas, like the San Joaquin Valley.



 Small Business Administration



 The President's 2018 Budget requests $826.5 million for SBA, a $43.2 million or
5.0 percent decrease.



 Eliminates the following programs:



     PRIME technical assistance grants: Provides training and technical
assistance to organizations that help disadvantaged entrepreneurs.

     Regional Innovation Clusters: Supports public-private partnerships
concentrated in regional groups to strengthen small businesses.

     Growth Accelerators: Funds startups that support underserved communities
and areas with less access to venture capital.

Kuster Announces $250,000 Rural Community Development Initiative Grant to
Northern Forest Center

LENGTH: 305  words

DATELINE: Washington


Office of the House of Representative Ann Mclane Kuster, U.S Government has
issued the following news release:

Representative Annie Kuster (NH-02) today announced that the Northern Forest
Center has received a $250,000 Rural Community Development Initiative Grant from
the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA).  The Center will use the funding to
provide technical assistance to the Northern Community Investment Corporation
(NCIC) in support of NCIC's economic development services across the North
Country.  The grant will assist the Northern Forest Center and NCIC in improving
the food system network in the North Country.

"The Northern Forest Center and the Northern Community Investment Corporation
are doing phenomenal work helping to support economic growth and job creation in
an area of the state that really needs it," said Congresswoman Kuster.  "This
grant will help these two organizations improve the food system network in the
region, which will boost local economies and increase access to natural,
delicious foods grown right here in New Hampshire.   I congratulate the North
Forest Center on this grant award and thank them for all of their work on behalf
of economic development and sustainability in the North Country and around our
state."

"Our agricultural, tourism, and forest product businesses are so important to
the economy in northern New Hampshire and northeastern Vermont," said Rob Riley,
President of the Northern Forest Center. "This grant from USDA will enable the
Northern Forest Center and NCIC to continue providing support and innovation
services to these working lands businesses.  We value USDA Rural Development as
a key partner in this work, and are grateful their support."

                                US Official News

                            October 4, 2016 Tuesday

Washington: Healthy Food Financing Initiative brings jobs and nutritious food to
low-income families

LENGTH: 484  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: U.S. Department of Health and Human Services has issued the
following news release:



 A new set of investments will allow organizations to create or expand
businesses that increase access to healthy food in low-income communities.





 The Community Economic Development-Healthy Food Financing Initiative
(CED-HFFI), funded by the Office of Community Services at HHS' Administration
for Children and Families, will award $7.4 million to 11 community-based
organizations to address the lack of healthy, nutritious food options in
low-income neighborhoods.



 CED-HFFI grants enable local, nonprofit and community development corporations
to apply for grant funding for up to $800,000 to improve access to healthy food
and reduce food deserts. Awardees use the funding to develop businesses, such as
grocery stores, farmers markets and food-distribution businesses that increase
access to healthy food options, especially in places where access to healthy
options is otherwise scarce.



 The Healthy Food Financing Initiative (HFFI) at HHS is just one component of an
interagency initiative that also involves the U.S. Treasury Department and the
U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA). The goal of this interagency initiative
is to increase healthy food access by promoting a wide range of community
initiatives that expand the supply of and demand for nutritious foods, including
increasing the distribution of agricultural products, developing and equipping
grocery stores, and strengthening producer-to-consumer relationships. Both HHS
and Treasury have specific funds Congressionally-authorized and appropriated for
HFFI use. USDA's activities have focused on developing community-based solutions
using existing programs.



 The Treasury Department's Community Development Financial Institutions Fund
(CDFI Fund) offers Healthy Food Financing Initiative Financial Assistance
(HFFI-FA) to financial institutions and community development organizations that
use these funds to spur efforts to improve access to healthy foods with local
grocers and retailers in urban and rural areas.



 Concurrently, one way USDA has been able to encourage nutritious purchasing
patterns is by providing $100 million for incentives at the point-of-sale for
Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) participants to purchase more
fruits and vegetables in various venues, including farmers markets and retail
stores. Partner organizations and state governments joined in the effort by
providing matching funds meaning that $1 in SNAP benefits can purchase up to $2
in fruits and vegetables. The program, called the Food Insecurity Nutrition
Incentive program, awarded its first round of grants in the spring of 2015 and
awarded a second round of funding earlier this yearVisit disclaimer page.

                         Deming Headlight (New Mexico)

                           January 25, 2017 Wednesday
                                   1 Edition

Grow NM initiative takes aim at developing communities

BYLINE: By, For the Headlight

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A5

LENGTH: 349 words


ALBUQUERQUE - A new initiative, Grow New Mexico, launched in collaboration with
The Grants Collective. Grow New Mexico's mission is to help New Mexico
communities develop projects that improve the quality of life of their citizens.
This effort complements The Grants Collective's existing Talent Academy work to
train community grant writers and its Cooperative Network to better help
organizations collaborate and share resources.

Grow New Mexico's staff have extensive community development experience and
decades of government service. Terry Brunner, former State Director of USDA
Rural Development in New Mexico, will serve as the Chief Program Officer of the
Grow New Mexico project. Former senior White House official Phil Schiliro will
serve as the project's Senior Adviser.

"The Grow New Mexico project expands The Grants Collective's interest in New
Mexico community development assistance. Having Terry and Phil on board gives
New Mexico communities access to needed professional knowledge and experience
they might not otherwise get," said Tara Gohr, Co-Director of The Grants
Collective along with Erin Hielkema.

Grow New Mexico was developed to help enhance the current efforts of New Mexico
communities and community organizations to put together successful projects that
improve community quality of life. Grow New Mexico will provide one-on-one
technical assistance and project development to grow the capacity around
transformational projects. Projects may include community centers, educational
facilities, libraries, community redevelopment, health facilities, broadband and
other areas of interest. These services will be provided for free or at low cost
in areas of the state with the greatest need.

"We've seen up close the challenges New Mexico communities have in accessing the
funds and expertise they need to make projects happen and to fulfill their
community vision. Grow New Mexico is ready to assemble the missing pieces for
communities and help them reach their project goals. We believe, over time, this
will have a major impact on New Mexico communities," Brunner said.

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                      May 27, 1999, Thursday, Home Edition

Atlanta picked as pilot ;
 Rebuilding: A $ 400,000 grant will go toward recruiting workers for inner- city
revitalization.

BYLINE: S.A. Reid, Staff

SOURCE: AJC

SECTION: CityLife Atlanta (Extra); Pg. 1JD

LENGTH: 483 words

The Atlanta Neighborhood Development Partnership will add $ 400,000 to its
coffers under a national initiative to recruit 1,000 new staff and volunteers to
help rebuild low-income communities.

The grant is part of a plan by the Washington-based National Congress for
Community Economic Development to dole out $ 8 million during the next five
years.

Atlanta is the site of one of 10 pilot programs in 13 communities nationwide
being funded by NCCED through its new Human Capital Development Initiative, a
campaign to attract attention and recruits to the growing field of community
economic development.

"More and more people --- from community activists, to academics, to business
people and bankers --- are coming to recognize community economic development as
an important industry," Hattie Dorsey, ANDP's executive director, said in a
statement. "Demographic shifts, environmental issues, traffic and the backlash
against urban sprawl are giving new impetus to redeveloping and revitalizing
inner-city neighborhoods in cities all over the country."

Strengthening Atlanta-area community development corporations is part of ANDP's
holistic approach to revitalization.

Community development corporations, nonprofit organizations that work to
redevelop urban and rural communities, have built more than 555,000 units of
affordable housing, created more than 240,000 jobs and lent $ 1.9 billion to
small businesses, according to NCCED.

The community development industry has seen explosive growth nationwide,
particularly in the number of CDCs. Figures from NCCED, a trade association for
the community development field, show a 64 percent increase since 1994.

"This is a pretty sizable grant in a field like this," said Roy Priest, NCCED
president.

"It just shows the increased need for the kinds of services this organization
provides these communities."

ANDP will use the money to continue its paid community development fellowship
and internship program. The program, which will graduate its first class in
June, targets local residents, college students or career changers.

"A steady supply of people interested and qualified to work in this growing
field is crucial to building on the successes neighborhood-based groups have
been able to wring from previously abandoned neighborhoods," Dorsey said.

Marie Cowser, an Old Fourth Ward resident, welcomes the opportunity to get paid
for the community work she has come to love. Cowser is completing an ANDP
fellowship with the Historic District Development Corp.

"(The initiative is) a wonderful thing, and I think it's great that it's
happening," she said.

"There are a lot of people out there who have the eye and the passion to do
community development."

Other initiative locations are Boston, California, Chicago, Cleveland, St. Paul,
Minn., North Carolina, Pacific Northwest, Philadelphia and Washington.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                          PNG Post-Courier (Australia)

                           February 24, 2011 Thursday
                                   1 Edition

Grants for community based groups

BYLINE: By NELLIE SETEPANO

SECTION: HOME NEWS; Pg. 26

LENGTH: 541 words


SUSU Mamas drop in centre is among the first lot of organisations to express its
interest in seeking grants from a project called Strongim Pipol Strongim Nesen
(SPSN) launched yesterday.

Susu Mama Inc was given an expression of interest form from the newly
established group because it (Susu Mamas Inc) is an example of one of the many
community based groups that are targeted under the grant initiative program.

The community development initiative is an AusAid funded program working in
partnership with the government of PNG.

An amount of A$100 million has been allocated by AidAID for a year to provide
grants to organizations.

The goals of SPSN is to enable civil society, together with the state and others
to better meet the needs and priorities of men, women and children in
communities across PNG.

SPSN will support activities that apply and promote democratic governance
principles of participation, equality, transparency, accountability, responsive
and legitimacy.

Using community based, demand driven-approaches, SPSN targets improvements in
maternal and child health, basic education and non-formal adult education,
HIV/AIDS, gender equity including violence against women and women's economic
empowerment. It will also target disability and social inclusion.

Minister for Community Development Dame Carol Kidu who was present said the
launch was about acknowledging partnership, participation and relationships and
progress towards coming age of those relationships. (Australia and PNG)

Dame Carol said SPSN is supporting the implementation of integrated community
development policy through direct support to the Department of Community
Development (DfCD) and increasing community level participation through DfDC's
community learning and development centre network.

"People in communities nationwide need literacy and skills to enhance their
income generating opportunities, respond to community changes, and improve their
quality of life.

Through supporting the department's network of district focal points and
community learning and development centres we are ensuring an integral approach
at the village level, with government and civil society working together to meet
community needs," the minister said.

The minister noted that SPNS is development from the lessons of its predecessor
programs, Community Development Scheme (CDS) and Democratic Governance
Transitional Program (DGTP).

Its core strategy is community empowerment through the building of capacities of
NGOs and CSO involved in community development processes so that these
organizations become effective mechanisms for service delivery.

Dame Carol also commended the SPSN support for the safe motherhood alliance,
dedicated to improving maternal health outcomes in PNG.

She said the success of SPSN will be measured by the impact it will make in
rural and marginalized communities and the improvement capacity and competences
of key agency staff at the provincial district administration.

"This program should be done using the existing systems and structures of the
national, provincial, district and local level government agencies.

This approach will enhance effectiveness and support the development priorities
of the government of PNG," she told those witnessing the launch.

                                US Official News

                           January 18, 2017 Wednesday

SUNY Cobleskill Receives $749,000 USDA Grant to Support Regional Development and
Education

LENGTH: 425  words

DATELINE: New York



 New York: State University of New York College of Agriculture and Technology at
Cobleskill has issued the following news release:



  With the USDA funding, SUNY Cobleskill will work with regional partners to
increase access to agriculture-related higher education, improve college
completion rates, expand applied learning opportunities, support agricultural
businesses, and pursue economic and community development opportunities. The
grant will help SUNY Cobleskill expand pathways for students to enter a broad
spectrum of rewarding careers in agriculture.





 "I have witnessed firsthand the important work being done at SUNY Cobleskill to
advance agricultural research, new learning opportunities, and regional economic
development," said U.S. Senator Kirsten Gillibrand, the first New York Senator
to serve on the Senate Agriculture Committee in nearly 40 years. "This federal
funding will accelerate Cobleskill's innovative initiatives and create
opportunities for future farmers, growers, and entrepreneurs throughout the
region."



 "The time is right for SUNY Cobleskill to lead this transformative effort,"
said SUNY Cobleskill President Marion A. Terenzio. "These initiatives will bring
new energy and critical support to our rural communities while providing SUNY
Cobleskill students with immersive real-world learning opportunities. This is an
exciting time for the College and our many community partners."



 Some of the work is already under way, such as SUNY Cobleskill becoming a New
York State certified Farm and Food Business Incubator and the recently launched
BOCES AgPTECH partnership in Johnstown. With the grant funding, SUNY Cobleskill
will work to expand the teaching of college-level agriculture courses in
regional high schools, improve agricultural outreach in urban areas, and assist
county and town stakeholders with economic development plans, among other
activities. A new partnership with Albany Law School will provide legal
assistance for agricultural entrepreneurs and business owners.



 These initiatives will provide partnership opportunities for local communities
and organizations to combine their resources and expertise with the College in
revitalizing the economies of rural New York. At the same time, the alignment of
academic programs with community development initiatives will create boundless
opportunities for applied learning and research for SUNY Cobleskill students and
faculty.
