              Copyright (c) 1995 University of Memphis Law Review
                      The University of Memphis Law Review

                                  Spring, 1995

                            25 U. Mem. L. Rev. 1265

LENGTH: 10178 words

ARTICLE: A Brief History and Assessment of Federal Rural Development Programs
and Policies

NAME: Donald E. Voth *

BIO:



   * Professor of Rural Sociology, University of Arkansas.

 LEXISNEXIS SUMMARY:
 ...  The so-called "agricultural crisis" of the early 1980s spawned a renewed
interest in rural policy, or rural development policy, at both state and federal
levels. ...  Several other significant developments of the 1970s were the formal
assignment of "lead responsibility" for rural development in the USDA to the
FmHA by the Carter administration, the re-emergence of "the new federalism,"
revenue sharing, the folding of many categorical grant programs into several
"block grant" programs, and finally, the very considerable reduction of funding
available for rural (and urban too, for that matter) development programs. ...
The USDA's role in the EZ/EC initiative is indicative of the Clinton
administration's rural policy and rural development policy preferences under
Secretary Espy. ...  On the one hand, it could result in another form of
"agricultural fundamentalism," which simply reasserts the conventional
definition of the USDA family's responsibility for rural areas to be exclusively
agricultural, but now as "sustainable" and "alternative" agriculture. ...  It
is, in large part, the result of this progressive co-opting of rural policy and
USDA institutions by commercial agricultural and commodity interests which
explains the evident absence of a coherent rural or rural development policy in
the United States. ...

TEXT:
 [*1265]

    I. Introduction

    The so-called "agricultural crisis" of the early 1980s
 [*1266]  spawned a renewed interest in rural policy, or rural development
policy, at both state and federal levels. One of the most recent expressions of
this interest is the recently released GAO report, which evaluates and makes
recommendations for the improvement of federal rural development initiatives.
n1

    This is merely the latest in a number of phases of intense interest in the
well-being of rural people in the United States and the potential of federal
action to ameliorate those conditions. Although it has not received extensive
treatment, the history of rural policy or rural development policy has been
discussed briefly by Nelson,  n2 Rasmussen,  n3 Freshwater,  n4 Buttel and
Gillespie,  n5 and, at somewhat greater length, by Osbourn.  n6 Rasmussen
provides perhaps the best brief account. It is especially useful because he
provides a chronological chart of the variety of federal rural development
initiatives from as early as 1880 to 1982 and, as much as possible, eschews
interpretation or selection in his coverage.

    The interpretations of federal rural and rural development policy are,
however, at least as interesting as the basic "facts" of the case. At least two
points are at issue, on both of which the conventional wisdom is, in my view,
fundamentally wrong.  First, there is the view that federal rural or rural
development
 [*1267]  policy is a relatively recent phenomenon. Osbourn says, "The idea of a
national rural policy is fairly new in American history . . . ."  n7 This
completely disregards the fact that extant relationships between the federal
government and states and localities were literally invented in the various
agencies of the USDA family, which date back to at least as early as 1862, when
both the USDA and the Land Grant System were first established. The early rural
programs which emerged from the Country Life Commission of 1908, specifically
the Tennessee Valley Authority,  n8 forged mechanisms whereby the federal
government could play a role in ameliorating the perceived disadvantaged
conditions found in rural America.  n9 Second is the view that the institutions
that were forged to respond to these perceived rural disadvantages were forged
for, and fundamentally belong to, agriculture, or, as is now stated, "the food
and fiber industry." Holding this view, which is the conventional wisdom within
the USDA family itself, Osbourn concluded that it was the narrowly conceived
concerns about agriculture and farmers, and not rural areas and/or rural people,
that dominated the original programs and policies of the USDA, the Land Grant
System, Rural Electrification, etc.  n10 So she finds it surprising that the
Country Life Commission of 1908, which paved the way for many of the USDA
family's institutions and programs, placed equal emphasis upon broad issues of
the quality of life in rural areas.  n11

    Simply put, the conventional wisdom holds that United States rural and rural
development policy originated strictly as
 [*1268]  agricultural policy, that it was allowed to focus primarily upon
supporting agriculture or the "food and fiber industry" until relatively
recently, when, among other things, concerns about the well-being of rural
people were imposed upon it. Thus, as Osbourn correctly points out, rural
development only became a separate program area within the USDA in 1955.  n12 My
own interpretation is quite different. It is that repeated concerns about
perceived disadvantage and lagging development in rural areas led to what were,
in the early phases, quite radical initiatives of federal involvement in local
affairs. These included the very establishment of the USDA and the Land Grant
system, both of which happened during the Civil War when states' rights
opposition to federal involvement from the South was neutralized, federal
agencies with offices in every county, "block grants" before the term had been
invented, and, perhaps most importantly, the pattern of federal assistance and
intervention touted by David Lilienthal as "Democratic Administration."  n13 In
the 1860s, the early 1900s, and the 1930s, when the basic structure of these
institutions was forged, it just happened that most rural people were farmers.
Hence, the major focus in ameliorating rural conditions was agriculture and
farming.

    These institutions and programs were subsequently progressively co-opted by
commercial agricultural interests, by the agri-business interests associated
with commercial agriculture, and, more recently, by agriculturally related
"industries." These "industries" are intent upon benefitting from public
investments in the development of increasingly more sophisticated agricultural
production technology to the detriment of the USDA family's commitment to the
well-being of rural people.

    Three things are fundamental about this interpretation of rural development
policy in the United States. First, in sharp contrast to the conventional view
articulated by Osbourn, concern about rural well-being was central, not
peripheral, to the
 [*1269]  history of federal policy vis-a-vis local affairs in the United
States. What David Lilienthal celebrated as his invention of "democratic
administration"  n14 --the use of federal institutions and resources to
"develop" rural areas of the United States with active involvement of the
affected publics, a pattern used by virtually all USDA programs and agencies,
including, of course, the state-administered Land Grant system--was invented for
rural development. Second, it was the progressive loss of commitment to an
effective rural policy and, incidentally, the cumulating evidence that
agricultural policies and programs not only did not benefit rural areas, but
were to a significant extent responsible for the very problems found in rural
areas which, finally in 1955, led to the need to re-articulate a rural policy
and USDA responsibility for rural development by the specific definition of
rural development during the Eisenhower administration.

    What is displayed, then, is a perverse hegemony in the relationship between
the USDA, the committee structure in Congress, and even--to a significant
extent--the Land Grant System. This perverse hegemony claims jurisdiction over
rural and rural development policy but systematically repudiates support for
rural development in favor of commercial agricultural and commodity interests
when the chips are down. Further, failing that, it insists that the best and
only appropriate rural development policy is agricultural commodity policy.

    This argument for the soul of the USDA family is inherent in recent
developments such as the appointment of Mike Espy as the Secretary of
Agriculture and in the reorganization of the Department in Espy's resignation.
Espy was a strong supporter of Rural Development. One of the more blunt
statements concerning what founders intended the soul of the Land Grant System
to be about was that made by George McDowell at a conference on the future of
the USDA and the Land Grant System in 1991:

    The Land-Grant mission and purpose was NOT primar-  [*1270]  ily
agricultural or even rural. The Land-Grant colleges were an experiment in
democracy. As the separate functions of teaching, research, and extension
evolved, they were to democratize our society, NOT JUST TO IMPROVE AGRICULTURE.
Justin Morrill reflected on the teaching function of the Land-Grant Colleges in
1887, twenty-five years after the Morrill-Wade Act establishing them, the same
year as the Hatch Act.

    "The Land-Grant colleges were founded on the idea that a higher and broader
education should be placed in every State within reach of those whose destiny
assigns them to, or who may have the courage to choose industrial vocations
where the wealth of nations is produced. It would be a mistake to suppose it was
intended that every student should become either a farmer or a mechanic when the
design comprehended not only instruction for those who may hold a plow or follow
a trade, but such instruction as any person might need . . . and without the
exclusion of those who might prefer to adhere to the classics."

    Thus the Land-Grant colleges were not originally agricultural colleges, but
people's colleges, though many of the people without access to college were
engaged in agriculture. They were to make our democracy better by providing
higher education to the sons and daughters of ordinary citizens.

    They were democratic in another way that is perhaps more significant than
who was to have access to the classrooms. For the first time in history, the
problems of ordinary people were the subject of scholarship and science.  The
scholarly agenda was democratized--the development of the Babcock milk test was
both a scientific act and a political act. The Integrated Pest Management
science is both fine science and relevant politics.

    The Smith-Lever Act and the Extension Service were established to further
democratize our society. With the inception of the Extension Service, the three
functions were complete. The USDA-Land-Grant system was to 1) teach the sons and
daughters of ordinary people in its classrooms; 2) study their problems in the
laboratories and field plots; and 3) provide functional education to even
 [*1271]  those who could not qualify, nor wanted, to be in the classroom.  n15



    II. Major Phases of Federal Rural Development Policy

    There are clear phases in attention to the well-being of rural areas in the
United States. Each has resulted in major studies documenting rural conditions
and in some kind of program and policy response. These phases include an early
phase ranging from the Civil War until the beginning of the nineteenth century,
the Great Depression and the New Deal Era, and the post-World-War-II period up
until the 1980s. The current phase starts, more or less, with the agricultural
and rural crises of the early 1980s.

    A. USDA, The Morrill Act, and The Country Life Commission

    The first period of what was apparently strong interest in rural development
extended from the Civil War until the turn of the century and is characterized
by at least three major events: the establishment of the USDA;  n16 the passage
of the Morrill Act  n17 in 1862; and Theodore Roosevelt's Country Life
Commission of 1908,  n18 which was led by Liberty Hyde Bailey of Cornell
University. The Morrill Act, significantly passed during the Civil War when
Southern opposition to federal initiatives was excluded, signified an initial
step toward federal involvement in local affairs. The Country Life Commission
Report, forty years later, is the major document characterizing rural
conditions, and it laid the groundwork for special pro-  [*1272]  grams and
policies focusing upon rural areas that followed.  During the ten years
following, a whole series of its recommendations were enacted, including a
parcel post system for rural areas, a postal saving system, the Smith-Lever Act
establishing the Cooperative Extension Service of 1914, and a land bank credit
system.  n19 As Osbourn acknowledged, many of the Commission's recommendations
were for programs to help rural residents in general, rather than merely for the
"industry" of agriculture.  n20 And, of course, the Commission concerned itself
with rural conditions broadly conceived. It should also be noted that the rise
of populism, agrarian unrest, and even agrarian violence surely played a role in
the concern that America's political elite had about rural conditions during
this early period and in their efforts to respond to those conditions.

    B. The Great Depression

    The second period of intense concern about rural development was, of course,
the Great Depression and the New Deal Era of the 1930s. A wide variety of
agencies and programs emerged during this era, including the Farm Security
Administration (FSA);  n21 its rural and agricultural programs, which later
became the Farmers' Home Administration (FmHA);  n22 the "New Community"
programs; the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA)  n23 and the creation of
federal/local partnership via "Democratic Administration"; the Rural
Electrification Administration;  n24 and the broad outlines of agricultural
commodity programs and policies which ultimately emerged from the Agri-  [*1273]
cultural Adjustment Acts of 1933  n25 and 1938.  n26 Thanks to the employment of
eminent social scientists by various government agencies during this period,
rural conditions were extensively documented in the 1940 Yearbook of
Agriculture,  n27 a large tome whose authors include a virtual "Who's Who" list
of eminent American social scientists. There is no better witness to the breadth
of concern about the well-being of rural people than informed policymaking
during this period.

    C. Post-War Rural Development Initiatives: The Rise and Fall of Rural
Development

    Another period of intense concern about rural development started in the
mid-to-late 1950s, when attention again turned to the fact that rural areas had
not recovered from the effects of the war as rapidly as urban areas. This period
lasted until the late 1970s, when a combination of the "rural renaissance,"
environmentalism, and the retirement of key players--especially utility
companies and the Land Grant System--from interest in rural development ended
it.  n28

    Several significant things characterized the early post-war rural
development initiatives. First, this marked the point, initially in 1955, when
USDA agencies acknowledged rural development as a separate program area. In the
Cooperative Extension Service (CES),  n29 for example, program areas had
included agriculture, home economics, and youth programs. Now, rural development
was added to the list. Second, the CES was given "lead responsibility" for rural
development within the USDA family. A variety of organizational forms was
devised for supporting rural development at the community or county level
 [*1274]  and for stimulating USDA agencies to collaborate in supporting the
rural development programs. Rasmussen describes these developments as follows:

    Within the USDA, rural development programs, administered by Under Secretary
True D. Morse, were largely decentralized, with emphasis upon State and county
action in 50 designated pilot counties and areas. The Cooperative Extension
Service served as the major leader in program development, with the programs
themselves carried out by a number of Federal and local agencies.
Representatives of local agencies, USDA and other Federal agencies, and
community leaders were organized into Rural Development Committees. By September
1960, under the leadership of these committees, rural development work was
planned or underway in 262 counties in 30 States and Puerto Rico.  n30



    Third, a community and/or regional development strategy emerged as the core
strategy for rural development. Initially, during the Republican administration,
this was a relatively inexpensive, self-help community development strategy. It
focused heavily upon locally-based self-help and leadership development, with
staffing and support from CES and other USDA agencies. Initially there were some
fifty of the poorest rural counties included in the program of "pilot" rural
development counties and rural development areas; subsequently, the program was
expanded to all rural counties. It resulted in the organization of county or
community development councils or committees in hundreds of counties, involving
large numbers of local leaders in extensive study, planning, and implementation
activities, and laid much of the groundwork for the more formal planning
efforts, proposal writing, etc. that was necessary when the democratic
administration launched its anti-poverty and rural development programs in the
1960s.  n31

    Under the Kennedy and Johnson administrations, this com-  [*1275]  munity
development strategy was retained, but it was rapidly transformed as federal
categorical grant programs became available, resulting in heavy federal
involvement in local affairs and detailed federal requirements and guidelines.

    During the Democratic administrations, USDA leadership for rural development
tended toward the FmHA rather than the CES and even toward non-USDA agencies
like the new Economic Development Administration and the Office of Economic
Opportunity. Key examples of federal programs were the various public facility
and housing programs of the Farmers' Home Administration. Examples of federal
funding and federal intrusion were the Community Action Agencies (CAAs) and the
Community Action Programs (CAPs) and their mandated "maximum feasible
participation of the poor" and the creation, under the new Economic Development
Administration of the Department of Commerce, of federally funded regional rural
development quasi-governments in the form of Planning and Development Districts,
now widely known as Economic Development Districts. Of course, the Appalachian
Regional Commission, as well as a set of similar regional commissions elsewhere
(e.g., the Ozarks Regional Commission), was established during this time, all to
stimulate and support rural development.

    The major documents characterizing rural well-being in this period were the
classic study of rural poverty prepared for the President's National Advisory
Commission on Rural Poverty in 1967, the Commission's full report, entitled
Rural Poverty in the United States,  n32 and its recommendations, entitled The
People Left Behind,  n33 and several assessments of rural socioeconomic
conditions prepared for Congress in the early 1970s.  n34

    The 1970s saw a brief "Rural Renaissance," the initial rise of
environmentalism and concern about the negative impacts of
 [*1276]  rural industrialization and a tendency to withdraw from rural economic
development, especially by state agencies, utility companies, and, of course,
the Land Grant System. The Rural Development Act of 1972, however, expanded FmHA
programs considerably, and, for a short period of time, stimulated joint efforts
by the CES and the state Agricultural Experiment Stations to engage in targeted
rural development programs in their respective states, an activity that was
judged to have been quite successful and cost relatively little. However, as
soon as explicit earmarking of funds for rural development by the USDA through
the CES and AES ended, most of these programs were abandoned by the Land Grant
System.

    Another relatively inexpensive and arguably effective result of the 1972
Rural Development Act  n35 was the establishment of the Regional Rural
Development Centers, including the Southern Rural Development Center at
Mississippi State University, the North Central Center for Rural Development at
Iowa State University, the North Central Rural Development Center at
Pennsylvania State University, and the Western Rural Development Center at
Oregon State University. These centers continue to operate as, in many respects,
unique advocates of rural development linking land grant universities, the USDA,
and various other agencies with an interest in rural development and do it with
combined USDA resources in the range of about $ 500,000 per year.

    Several other significant developments of the 1970s were the formal
assignment of "lead responsibility" for rural development in the USDA to the
FmHA by the Carter administration, the re-emergence of "the new federalism,"
revenue sharing, the folding of many categorical grant programs into several
"block grant" programs, and finally, the very considerable reduction of funding
available for rural (and urban too, for that matter) development programs. This
process began under the Carter administration but was accelerated under the
Reagan administration.
 [*1277]

    D. The Agricultural Crisis of the 1980s to the Present

    The current phase of interest in rural development was stimulated initially
by (1) the agricultural crisis of the early 1980s, (2) the general crisis of the
rural economy that was a concomitant of that crisis, (3) the massive withdrawal
and paralysis of the federal government, and (4) dramatic changes in the United
States economy. It is sustained into the present by continuing evidence of
significant rural disadvantage on a variety of indicators, especially among some
segments of the rural population. Generally speaking, the federal response has
been timid. It has included extensive assessment and study of rural conditions
and of rural development programs in the USDA, and the production of many papers
and documents. In terms of actual programming, however, it includes only (1) the
President's (Bush) Rural Development Initiative, (2) Congressional efforts to
pass rural development legislation, which resulted in 100 pages of rural
development provisions, virtually none of which were funded, being
unceremoniously dumped into the 1990 Farm Bill when discussion about
agricultural commodity interests took center stage in 1990, and (3) subsequent
initiatives of the Clinton administration. Finally, of course, extensive
discussion and debate has already begun, targeted upon the 1995 Farm Bill,
apparently under the assumption that, now that the federal rural development
provisions are in the Farm Bill, that is where they will be again in 1995.

    The Presidential Initiative on Rural Development emerged during the Bush
presidential campaign and apparently is the first presidential articulation of a
rural development strategy during a campaign.  n36 It involved the establishment
of a temporary Working Group on Rural Development in the Economic Policy
Council, a temporary national Rural Policy Council, and, subsequently, the
establishment, first on a pilot basis, of State Rural Development Councils. Some
forty of these State Rural
 [*1278]  Development Councils have been established, and the Clinton
administration has apparently decided to continue to support this approach. The
function of these Councils is to approach rural development at the state level
in a comprehensive fashion, involving and coordinating the activities of all
major federal, state, and local actors, including the private sector, and to
stimulate a process of strategic planning for rural development at the state
level. The USDA provides a small amount of funding for the staffing of each
state, which establishes an acceptable Council structure.

    The 1990 Farm Bill included 100 pages of rural development provisions, which
were the result of a wide variety of initiatives proposed by the Senate and the
House and which were quite inelegantly combined and included in the Farm Bill.
The major provisions were (1) the establishment of a Rural Development
Administration (RDA) and the allocation of a significant portion of the programs
of the FmHA to RDA; (2) the creation of state Rural Economic Development Review
Panels and Rural Investment Partnerships designed to turn control over
significant federal USDA resources targeted at the states and rural areas to
state-level management and administration; (3) a series of titles dealing with
water and waste treatment facilities, distance learning and medical service
delivery, rural business and emergency assistance, and rural electrification
provisions; and (4) Rural Revitalization through the Forestry program, to be
focused upon forest-dependent communities. There was also a provision for the
establishment of cooperative and technology development centers.

    Virtually none of these provisions was funded initially, with the exception
of the distance learning and medical service delivery program. The USDA moved to
establish the RDA, even without funding, against opposition from some members of
Congress. Regional RDA offices were established but have since been abolished.
n37 Some funds have been appropriated for
 [*1279]  cooperative and technology development centers. Apparently some states
have proceeded with efforts to establish State Rural Economic Development Review
Panels. However, this initiative seems to have been overshadowed by the State
Rural Development Councils, which, in contrast to the Review Panels, have no
authority over the disposition of federal rural development funds in the states
(e.g., FmHA funds).

    III. Summary and Assessment of Rural Development Programs Currently in Place


    Thus, there has been intense interest in and discussion about rural
development since the early 1980s. At the state level and among some private
sector groups, there has been some action.  n38 As pointed out above, so far
there has been little that is new at the federal level.

    What, then, can be said of the rural development programs that actually
exist? They have been intensively reviewed and evaluated, most recently in the
July GAO report.  n39 Based upon the comprehensive inventory and summary of
rural development programs performed previously by the GAO in 1989  n40
 [*1280]  and case study interviews in thirty-one counties in thirteen states,
the report evaluated current rural development programs.

    The 1989 GAO study found a total of eighty-eight programs that could be
categorized, in the broadest sense, as being related to rural development. Among
those, about $ 29 billion was available in 1987 to both rural and non-rural
counties: $ 4.2 billion classified as economic development, $ 84 million as
agriculture and natural resources; $ 11.1 billion as infrastructure, and $ 13.7
billion as human resource related. The study observed that (1) relatively few of
even these programs pursue rural development as a primary objective but that (2)
a number of the existing programs are extremely important to rural America since
they are, or at least can be, targeted to meet the major needs rural areas have.
According to this report, the USDA has the most experience of any federal agency
in working with rural areas. Hence, the GAO concluded that rural development
responsibility should continue to reside there.  n41

    The 1994 study concluded that three factors--"distance from metropolitan
areas, reliance on a single, often naturalresource industry, and sparse
population"--are the major factors that inhibit economic growth in rural areas.
n42 However, of the many factors affecting rural community well-being, it
concluded that the quality of local leadership was probably the most important.
Four problems rural areas have in using rural development programs are
identifying sources of assistance, understanding the programs' rules and
regulations, learning the intricacies of the application processes, and,
finally, reconciling inconsistencies and conflicts among rules and regulations
of the various programs.  n43 The study stated, "Many of the problems . . .
occur because numerous narrowly focused federal programs are a weak substitute
for an integrated federal ap-  [*1281]  proach to fostering economic development
in rural America."  n44 Finally, it criticized federal agencies for having done
"little to analyze the impact of their programs on a rural area's development."
n45 The measures that do exist are measures of inputs and not of impacts.  n46

    Consistent with its critique, the study recommended that Congress should
follow a two-part strategy: make short-term changes in the way federal
assistance is delivered and then develop a more comprehensive and cohesive
federal strategy.  The short-term strategy would focus primarily upon achieving
greater complementarity and coordination among the various narrowly defined
rural development initiatives.

    IV. Clinton Administration Initiatives

    Several of the items discussed here are not rural development programs or
policies per se; however, in the Clinton administration's approach to dealing
with the problems of lagging areas and communities, it seems clear that the
administration will focus upon a community development strategy generally
applicable to both rural and urban communities.

    In June 1993, President Clinton announced Community Economic Development
initiatives that included mechanisms for stimulating community development
financing and proposed revisions of the Community Reinvestment Act (CRA) of
1977.  Under the proposals, a special set of community development financing
institutions (CDFI) would be created to infuse credit into low-income
communities. A CDFI trust, for which $ 382 million in funding was originally
proposed, would be created and called the Community Development Banking and
Financial Institution Fund (CDBFIF).

    Proposed CRA revisions focused on development of new regulations and
procedures to "replace paperwork and uncertainty with greater performance,
clarity, and objectivity."  n47 The
 [*1282]  President further stated that certain goals should be met within CRA
revisions. These goals include such things as consistency and evenhandedness,
improvement in public CRA performance evaluations, more effective sanctions
against banks and thrifts with consistently poor performance, and development of
more objective, performance-based CRA assessment standards that minimize the
compliance burden on financial institutions while stimulating improved CRA
performance.

    Focus was to be placed on community reinvestment activities in both urban
and rural areas--specifically, lending to lowand moderate-income individuals and
neighborhoods, small businesses, and small farms; investments in low- and
moderateincome neighborhoods; and provision of banking services to residents of
low- and moderate-income neighborhoods.  n48

    The CDFI and CDBFIF proposals were designed, in part, to emulate efforts and
activities of the Southshore Bank of Chicago and its rural counterpart, the
Southern Development Bancorporation (SDBC) of Arkadelphia, Arkansas. These
institutions have had some success in eliminating red-lining and stimulating
community growth and improvement. The successful urban Southshore model is
undergoing considerable reexamination and revisions in the rural SDBC efforts.

    V. Community Economic Development Legislation

    Legislation introduced embodying the administration proposals on CDFI and
CDBFIF has undergone considerable transformation but has been passed and was
signed into law by President Clinton on September 23, 1994. The legislation
contains a number of banking measures and authorizes $ 382 million over four
years in specialized community development banking initiatives for rural and
urban areas, an amount that is estimated to be capable of leveraging up to $ 5
billion.  n49
 [*1283]

    A. Proposed CRA Rule Change

    Previous CRA regulations focused primarily upon the documentation of the
services institutions provided to their communities. A wide variety of services,
such as participation in and contribution to civic activities, etc., could be
considered relevant. Based upon a list of twelve assessment factors, examiners
gave a CRA rating, which was made public and which might be used when
institutions apply for the establishment of branches or for re-establishment of
their charters. In highly organized neighborhoods, which are mostly found in
urban areas, these ratings have been used effectively to pressure institutions
into participation in economic development and rehabilitation. We know of little
evidence that the CRA had much impact upon the behavior of financial
institutions in rural areas.  Financial institutions almost unanimously opposed
the regulations for the "paper work" burden they imposed, a burden which was
probably more onerous for smaller institutions.

    The four federal regulatory agencies submitted proposed revised CRA
regulations for public comment on December 21, 1993. They were designed "to
emphasize performance rather than process, to promote consistency in
assessments, to permit more effective enforcement against institutions with poor
performance, and to reduce unnecessary compliance burdens while stimulating
improved performance."  n50 Under the proposed regulations, institutions would
be evaluated based upon three measures, including their lending, service, and
investment performance within the low- and moderate-income "geographies" (census
tracts or block numbering areas) of their service areas. The institutions would
be required to make available data on the geographic distribution of their loan
applications, denials, origination, and purchases. Smaller banks and thrift
institutions could elect to be evaluated under a "streamlined method," which
would not require them to report this data but which is not clearly defined in
the proposed regulations.

    The public comment period, which was to end February
 [*1284]  21, 1994, was extended. Then, apparently because of the extent of
criticism received in the public comments, the regulations were completely
redrafted, and a new set of proposed regulations was published in the Federal
Register on October 7, 1994.  n51

    B. Empowerment Zones/Enterprise Communities

    Meanwhile, the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) and the
USDA jointly announced their Empowerment Zone/Enterprise Community (EZ/EC)
programs on January 14, 1994.  n52 Under this program, the federal government
"will designate 104 areas that meet certain poverty and distress criteria and
prepare creative strategic plans for revitalization."  n53 HUD will make six
urban EZ and sixty-five EC awards, and the USDA will make three rural EZ and
thirty EC awards. Applications, the completion of which required a very
extensive local level strategic planning process and a very sophisticated plan
document, were due June 30, 1994. The carrot in this case is large, especially
for the several EZs that will be designated, including two HHS Title XX grants
totalling $ 40 million for each empowerment zone and one Title XX grant of up to
$ 3 million for each EC. It is reported that more than 500 applications were
completed--there were fifteen from Arkansas alone. In spite of the compressed
time frame, it has been widely reported that the community based strategic
planning process has been beneficial to the communities which participated. In
some cases, quite significant commitments have already been made to local
community development investment and lending
 [*1285]  activities by local banks or by branches of major financial
institutions.  n54 The EZ/EC awards were announced just before Christmas in
1994.

    Several things stand out in these initiatives. The CRA revision and the
EZ/EC programs both appear to assume that poverty is geographically concentrated
in rural areas as it is in urban areas. Indeed, an underlying feature of all of
these proposals is that they are urban--the Southshore Bank is preeminently an
urban institution. Its success--based, as it is, upon "turning around" urban
real estate--is preeminently an urban phenomenon, and, of course, focusing upon
census-defined geographic areas rather than upon administrative units or
communities makes sense in focusing upon urban neighborhoods. Its utility in
rural areas is less obvious. Already it is becoming clear that groups preparing
EZ/EC applications in rural areas had to patch together very strange pieces of
territory, sometimes disregarding the boundaries of administrative, political,
or socioeconomic communities. Hastily doing effective strategic planning within
such artificial units, and having competitive plans prepared by June 30, 1994,
were real challenges indeed.  However, it seems that the strategic planning
process communities carried out to prepare their applications may have been very
positive and may result in important community development even for the
communities that are not selected.  n55

    C. Emerging USDA Initiatives

    The USDA's role in the EZ/EC initiative is indicative of the Clinton
administration's rural policy and rural development policy preferences under
Secretary Espy. It was quite clear that Espy strongly supported rural
development, especially efforts that were targeted upon the poorest rural areas.

 [*1286]

    1. 1995 Farm Bill

    Broad-based efforts have been underway since June 1994 to lay the groundwork
for the 1995 Farm Bill, including its Rural Development provisions. As was
pointed out by Ruth McWilliams of the United States Forest Service, who was put
in charge of the policy development process for rural development, Under
Secretary Bob Nash established eight broad issue groups, focusing upon
Developmental Finance, Rural Marketing, Water 2000, Information Super Highway,
Sustainable Rural Development, Regional Initiatives, Rationalizing Federal Rural
Policy, and Procedural Reform.  n56

    The Sustainable Rural Development issue group was charged with drafting
issue papers that will include the following: (a) review of the issue as it
relates to the 1995 Farm Bill, (b) recommendations for the USDA position on the
issue, (c) alternatives considered and rejected (and explanations if rejected),
(d) critique of effectiveness of current policies, (e) expected results of
recommended actions, and (f) anticipated cost and source of financing new
proposals. These papers were to be prepared by July 12, 1994.

    Secretary Espy drafted a New Vision of USDA's Rural Development Programs,
n57 which guides the overall RDP effort.  The draft report states: "The new
vision of the Federal role in rural development should be to assist communities,
based on inclusive development initiatives, to become more competitive in a
world marketplace, through creating sustainable economic opportunities for all
residents."  n58

    Three specific priorities for federal rural development efforts were
articulated: (a) reduction of long-term poverty in the approximately 500 poorest
rural counties in the United States, (b) increased viability of rural
communities in the declining, sparsely settled regions, such as the Great
Plains, and (c) assis-  [*1287]  tance for those parts of rural America
experiencing short-term difficulty from rapid structural change due to shifts in
public policy, the international marketplace, and natural disasters.  n59

    2. Sustainable Agriculture as Rural Development

    A new issue, "sustainable agriculture," has emerged on the horizon and
gained considerable political support and federal funding.  n60 Under the rubric
of the Quality of Life concerns of sustainable agriculture, it has begun to move
aggressively into rural development issues. It is too early to know exactly what
this will mean. On the one hand, it could result in another form of
"agricultural fundamentalism," which simply reasserts the conventional
definition of the USDA family's responsibility for rural areas to be exclusively
agricultural, but now as "sustainable" and "alternative" agriculture. On the
other hand, it could result in significant restoration of the USDA family's
commitment to the well-being of people in rural communities.

    These efforts of the Clinton administration indicate an intent to support
rural policy and rural development efforts as, perhaps, having an expanded role
within the USDA. However, given the resignation of Secretary Espy and the
apparent repudiation of the Clinton administration in the recent election, it is
hard to predict what they mean now, if anything.

    Key documents about the well-being of rural people for the 1980s include
several comprehensive assessments of rural socioeconomic conditions prepared by
the Economic Research Service of the USDA in the early 1980s  n61 and, of
course, the series of "Gloom and Doom" reports of rural conditions that
 [*1288]  characterized the agricultural and rural crisis of the early 1980s.
n62

    VI. Conclusion

    Some broad generalizations emerge from this history of interest in rural
areas and rural development program and policy initiatives, most of which are
still important today.

    (A) Concern about the status of rural areas and people in rural areas is
what led the nation into federal involvement with local level programs,
policies, and the building of local program or service delivery institutions.
The USDA was the federal agency in which the current pattern of
federal/state/local partnership was created.

    (B) This original federal commitment to rural America has, however, been
progressively co-opted into a narrower focus upon commercial and production
agriculture. It is, in large part, the result of this progressive co-opting of
rural policy and USDA institutions by commercial agricultural and commodity
interests which explains the evident absence of a coherent rural or rural
development policy in the United States.  n63 A "perverse hegemony" has
developed in the relationship between the USDA, the committee structure in
Congress, and even--to a significant extent--the Land Grant System. These
institutions claim jurisdiction over rural development policy but systematically
repudiate support for rural development in favor of commodity interests when the
chips are down. A fundamental part
 [*1289]  of this narrowing of responsibility by the USDA family has been an
ongoing process of goal displacement, with the goals of the institutions now
almost universally being represented as serving the "food and fiber industry,"
something that has very little to do with the Land Grant System's original
objectives discussed above.

    (C) It was the progressive loss of commitment to an effective rural policy
and, incidentally, the cumulating evidence that agricultural policies and
programs not only did not benefit rural areas, but were to a significant extent
responsible for the very problems found in rural areas, which, finally, in 1955
during the Eisenhower administration, led to the need to rearticulate rural
policy and USDA responsibility for rural development by the specific definition
of rural development.

    (D) There are, of course, other reasons for the failure of the United States
to develop a coherent rural or rural development policy. Even though rural
non-farm people make up a significant proportion of the population (about 20% of
the total, as high as nearly half in many rural states), they are essentially
unorganized, unmobilized, and, except for a few interest groups representing
local governments, unrepresented. Their numbers are not growing as rapidly as
the total population, resulting in continuing declines in their representation
in Congress, as well as in the state houses around the country.  n64

    Perhaps more fundamentally, though, even the most ardent advocates of rural
policy and of rural development have failed to develop a coherent argument for
why there should be a rural policy or why rural development should be an issue.
Most definitions of what is rural and what is urban resort to classifying the
population into the two--or perhaps several more along a rural-urban
continuum--statistical categories, and then focusing upon the "rural
differential." One then seeks systematic variation on a wide range of other
aggregate characteristics and develops policies geared to statistical aggregates
of individuals and families. This approach does not provide a compelling
 [*1290]  argument for rural or rural development policy, since even the very
idea of rural is devoid of content.  n65 It would seem more appropriate simply
to recognize that "rural," like "urban," means place and concerns the nature of
the places in which people live. These are, of course, their communities. Hence,
one way to give rural policy a coherent framework is to view it as rural and
small community policy.  n66

    (E) In addition to its struggle with commitment to the well-being of rural
people versus the agricultural "industry," rural development policy has
struggled with two additional dimensions: (1) the funding versus self-help
approaches, and (2) federal versus local control. When emphasizing local
control, there is the additional dimension of "establishment" control versus
grassroots, community control. Different agencies of the USDA family are allied
differently along these dimensions.  Republicans have typically eschewed federal
funding for selfhelp approaches, but self-help approaches controlled by the
local "establishment" include, of course, existing local governments. As such,
Republicans have tended to support the Land Grant System and especially the
Cooperative Extension Service's community development, educational, and
self-help approaches. Democrats, on the other hand, have emphasized federal,
categorical grant programs characterized by the Farmers' Home Administration,
programs that, in principle at least, are targeted upon the most needy,
low-income segments
 [*1291]  of the rural or farm population.

    (F) The USDA and Land Grant, federal/state partnership forged from the Great
Depression era through the 1960s has been very successful in supporting
production agriculture and providing extraordinary benefits to United States
consumers.  However, these benefits are themselves subject to constant debate.
Many argue that they have gone primarily to the larger farms, certainly
primarily to commercial farmers rather than to small, low-income, and minority
farmers. Also, of course, the peculiar supply/demand relationships in
agriculture in the United States result in the benefits of increased
productivity in agriculture accruing primarily to consumers rather than to
agricultural producers.

    (G) In addition to the question of commitment, institutional responsibility
for rural programs and policies is extraordinarily dispersed in the federal
government. Although the USDA is the "lead agency" and claims hegemony, many
other agencies are involved. Even in the USDA itself, Rural Development programs
operate in a largely uncoordinated fashion in the decentralized Cooperative
Extension Service, where support for rural development depends upon the varying
views of state directors and county staff chairs, in the Farmers' Home
Administration, in the Soil Conservation Service, and, increasingly since 1990,
in the United States Forest Service. In Congress, the same situation exists as
far as committee structure is concerned.

    (H) In spite of the extraordinary amount of experimentation with rural
programs and policies that have ensued throughout this long history, from the
bold "new communities" of the 1930s and early 1940s to the funding of public
facilities through the FmHA in the 1960s and to the joint research/extension
"self-help" Community Resource Development programs and the Rural Development
programs of the 1960s, two problems remain. First, there is extraordinarily
little evaluative research which has tried to assess the impacts of these
experiments, virtually none that can be generalized beyond specific programs
and/or specific circumstances. Second, there seems to be little consensus about
what rural development is or how it can be achieved, and, in particular, there
is not
 [*1292]  much evidence that the program and policy initiatives that have been
carried out have had a positive effect upon rural America.

    (I) Finally, it seems quite clear by now that the real action--if there is
to be any--in rural development will be at the local level or, at most, at the
state level. Some states have been very creative and seem to be having an
impact; and, of course, it is by now widely recognized that local leadership is
the most important factor. Federal and state policies and programs cannot
overcome the disadvantages of weak leadership, and strong leadership can bring
about significant rural community development even without them.

                              June 6, 2005 Monday

Housing: Administration to Continue With Plan to Eliminate CDBG

BYLINE: Matthew Vadum

SECTION: WASHINGTON; Pg. 5 Vol. 352 No. 32147

LENGTH: 564  words


Despite an apparent lack of congressional support for the proposed

Strengthening America's Communities Initiative that would replace the popular

Community Development Block Grant program, a Bush administration official said

Friday that the administration expects to present legislation aimed at

implementing its proposal to Congress this summer.

"We're still actively working on it ... the administration still very

much wants it to take effect this year," said Bryan Borlik, a spokesman for

the Economic Development Administration, an agency within the Commerce

Department.

"The thinking is that the [enabling] legislation will be proposed after

the advisory committee [studying the SACI proposal] presents its report,"

Borlik said in an interview Friday.

Borlik's comments came the day after the SACI advisory panel held its

third and final meeting in Clearwater, Fla., to discuss implementing the

plan. The committee is expected to file its report with Commerce Secretary

Carlos Gutierrez in coming weeks.

In the fiscal 2006 budget blueprint, Bush proposed replacing the

Department of Housing and Urban Development's $4.7 billion Community

Development Block Grant program and 17 other federal community and economic

development programs with the $3.7 billion SACI program that would be

administered by a yet-to-be-created agency within Commerce.

Congress funded the 18 programs that are currently located in several

federal agencies at close to $5.7 billion in the current fiscal year that

began Oct. 1. CDBG grants are often leveraged in municipal bond transactions.

The SACI proposal has thus far received a tepid reception on Capitol

Hill, and its opponents expect Congress to reject the plan, at least this

year.

"Every step of the way [our effort to preserve CDBG is] getting positive

feedback from the Hill," said Marilyn Mohrman-Gillis, director of policy and

federal relations for the National League of Cities.

"I don't think that there's much of a chance that [the SACI proposal] is

going to go through the authorizing process this year," said Mohrman-Gillis.

"The indications we've received from congressional offices is that the

SACI proposal is not being received warmly in Congress," she said.

Some housing and state and local government advocates declared victory in

the fight to preserve CDBG and keep it at HUD in March when the Senate and

House adopted fiscal 2006 spending plans that would protect funding for the

program and keep it at HUD.

Under the Bush plan, HUD would lose control over CDBG, which is divided

into formula grants and so-called set-asides, the National Community

Development Initiative, the Brownfields Economic Development Initiative, the

Rural Housing and Economic Development program, Urban Empowerment Zones Round

II grants, and HUD Community Development Loan Guarantees, also known as the

Section 108 program, which would all be moved to Commerce under the proposal.

CDBG is popular with local leaders in part because it is a flexible

program that gives them wide discretion on how to spend grants.

In recent months, support for the SACI plan has appeared soft within the

administration itself. HUD Secretary Alphonso Jackson acknowledged to a

congressional panel that CDBG "worked well" at HUD. The secretary also said

that he pressed the administration to keep the program at his department.

A HUD spokesman refused to comment Friday.

                            The Philadelphia Inquirer

                       JANUARY 29, 1999 Friday SF EDITION

CLINTON TARGETS ABANDONED BUILDINGS / HE WILL SEEK $50 MILLION TO HELP REDEVELOP
BLIGHTED AREAS. HUD'S BUDGET INCLUDES OTHER INITIATIVES.

BYLINE: Robert A. Rankin and Jodi Enda, INQUIRER WASHINGTON BUREAU

SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. A04

LENGTH: 601 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


President Clinton today will propose spending $50 million next year to knock
down abandoned buildings in blighted urban neighborhoods, the Inquirer
Washington Bureau has learned.

The initiative is part of a $2.5 billion spending increase that Clinton will
propose for programs at the Department of Housing and Urban Development in his
fiscal 2000 budget, to be announced Monday.

The abandoned-buildings initiative aims to turn "brown yards into backyards,"
according to administration budget documents. Up to 1,700 abandoned apartment
houses, single-family homes, warehouses and office buildings would be demolished
as part of comprehensive plans to redevelop property for commercial or
residential use.

Specifics on where the money might be spent were not available yesterday.

"It's expensive to take these buildings down," said a senior HUD official who
asked not to be identified. The average cost of demolishing a building is
estimated at $30,000.

The program's priority will be to replace dilapidated buildings with affordable
housing, and, failing that, to attract commercial development. HUD would provide
the money via competitive grants to local governments.

In a related initiative, the President will propose mobilizing a corps of
citizens to help rebuild abandoned or crumbling housing. A $5 million fund under
the community development block grant program would support this initiative,
which would be administered in conjunction with mayors, community organizations
and "faith-based groups." HUD plans to train local teams to reconstruct houses
in up to 80 cities.

Clinton will announce his proposals at a White House breakfast for the U.S.
Conference of Mayors. Total HUD funding would exceed $28 billion, with spending
increases for "virtually every major HUD program," the documents say.

"This is money that . . . goes into cities and rural areas for redevelopment,
for homeless assistance, to try to bring our cities and rural areas back by
making them economically strong and competitive," said a second HUD official who
also asked not to be identified.

The HUD disclosure is the latest in a long line of new budget initiatives the
administration has leaked selectively over the last month in an effort to
publicize Clinton's spending priorities and stoke political favor with
Democratic constituencies. Congress must approve any spending initiatives before
they become law.

Other previously undisclosed HUD initiatives that Clinton will propose include:

* A $25 million increase, to $4.8 billion, for community development block
grants. Philadelphia would get $77 million under this program.

* A $43 million increase, to $75 million, for the disadvantaged-youth program
Youthbuild.

* Refocusing $100 million out of $310 million in drug-elimination grants to
target youth crime and youth dependency on drugs.

* A $10 million increase, to $1.6 billion, for the HOME program of
rehabilitating homes to provide affordable housing. Philadelphia would get $15
million.

* An 18 percent boost, to $47 million, for HUD efforts to fight housing
discrimination.

* Providing 100,000 new housing vouchers to subsidize rent for the poor,
comprising 42,000 for various "worst-case housing needs," 25,000 to expand
vouchers for welfare-to-work clients, 18,000 for homeless people, and 15,000 for
elderly ones.

Under the budget proposal, Philadelphia would receive $18.5 million, a $1
million increase, for aid to the homeless, and would receive $2.4 million for
emergency-shelter aid.

Utah: USDA Community Facilities Loan and Grant Program

LENGTH: 363 words

DATELINE: Salt Lake City


Office of Rural Assistance Center, The State of Utah has issued the following
news release:

Sponsor  USDA Rural Development
Deadlines  Applications accepted on an ongoing basis
Contact  For a list of USDA Rural Development State Offices, see
http://www.rurdev.usda.gov/recd_map.html
Purpose

Community Programs, a division of the Housing and Community Facilities Programs,
is part of the United States Department of Agriculture's Rural Development
mission area. Community Programs administers programs designed to develop
essential community facilities for public use in rural areas.

These facilities include schools, libraries, childcare, hospitals, medical
clinics, assisted living facilities, fire and rescue stations, police stations,
community centers, public buildings and transportation. Community Programs
utilizes three flexible financial tools to achieve this goal: the Community
Facilities Direct and Guaranteed Loan Program, the Community Facilities Grant
Program, and the Rural Community Development Initiative.
Eligibility

Community Programs provides grants to assist in the development of essential
community facilities in rural areas and towns of up to 20,000 in population.
Grants are available to public entities such as municipalities, counties, and
special-purpose districts, as well as non-profit corporations and tribal
governments.

Loans and guarantees are available to public entities such as municipalities,
counties, and special-purpose districts, as well as to non-profit corporations
and tribal governments.
Geographic
coverage  Nationwide
Amount of
funding  Amount varies. Grants are authorized on a graduated scale. Applicants
located in small communities with low populations and low incomes will receive a
higher percentage of grants.
Application
process  Applications are handled by USDA Rural Development field offices. For a
listing of field offices, see http://www.rurdev.usda.gov/recd_map.html
Tagged as  Capital Funding, Child Care, Clinics, Community Development, Critical
Access Hospitals, Emergency Medical Services, Health Information Technology,
Hospitals, Schools, Telehealth, Trauma

For further information please visit: http://www.raconline.org/.

                           Bangor Daily News (Maine)

                          September 11, 2008 Thursday
                                  All Editions

Three Maine agencies to share grant money

SECTION: Pg. B8

LENGTH: 221 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


The U.S. Department of Agriculture's Office of Rural Development has awarded
Rural Community Development Initiative Grants totaling $457,104 to three Maine
community agencies, Rep. Mike Michaud announced in a press release.

The funds were:

.  Penquis, $57,860.  Funds will be used to provide technical assistance
focusing on 691 mobile homes, 115 of which are over 30 years old, for energy and
replacement strategies with affordable housing.  Penquis is based in Bangor and
serves Penobscot, Piscataquis, and Knox counties.

.  Piscataquis County Economic Development Council, $137,769. Funds will be used
to provide technical assistance to 22 communities for energy savings, community
development, and housing. PCEDC is based in Dover-Foxcroft and serves
Piscataquis County.

.  Western Maine Community Action Inc., $261,475.  Funds will be used to provide
financial and technical assistance and training materials that can be used
elsewhere in the areas of homeowner energy use, safety, and fire prevention.
WMCA serves Franklin, Androscoggin and Oxford counties.

"This funding will help these agencies serve communities, which have been
affected by high unemployment, plan and manage escalating energy costs," Michaud
said in the release.  "It is important that we give our communities the tools
they need to help those in most need."

                                US Official News

                            October 6, 2016 Thursday

Washington: In Eastern Kentucky, USDA Launches Relending Program to Reduce Rural
Poverty Nationwide

LENGTH: 867  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: United States Department of Agriculture has issued the following
news release:



 Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack today unveiled an innovative partnership with
community development organizations from across the country, providing $401
million of Community Facilities program funds to recipients with a track record
of successful programs to help reduce poverty in some of the nation's poorest
and most isolated rural communities. Twenty-six community development
organizations have been approved to draw upon the funding to provide long-term,
low-interest financing to be "re-lent" to local entities to build, acquire,
maintain or renovate essential community facilities. The funds also can be used
for capacity building and to finance essential community services, such as
education, health care and infrastructure.





 Many of the projects will be in some of the nation's poorest rural areas, such
as communities in Appalachia, the colonias along the U.S./Mexico border, and in
the Mississippi Delta region. Long-term poverty disproportionately affects rural
areas. Nearly nine out of 10 counties where 20 percent or more of the population
has lived in poverty for 30 years or more are rural.



 "This effort builds on our commitment to lifting up the economic prospects of
communities that have not benefited from the revitalization of rural America,"
Vilsack said. "By engaging with local and national partners, private-sector
financial institutions and philanthropic organizations, USDA will inject a
game-changing level of investment capital to reduce poverty in targeted rural
areas where the capacity for growth has not been realized. As we have seen with
the Obama Administration's Promise Zone initiative and USDA's StrikeForce
effort, targeted, place-based investments can have a real impact on reducing
poverty. This funding adds another important tool in that fight."



 The financing has two unique features. First, private financial institutions,
including Bank of America and others, will be providing guarantees for a portion
of the loans. Second, the recipient community development organizations, or
"re-lenders," may also have an opportunity to secure grants provided by seven of
the nation's premier philanthropic organizations through a $22 million fund to
assist in managing and capacity building. The Mary Reynolds Babcock Foundation
will manage this grant fund.



 Vilsack made the announcement at Berea College, which has received USDA funding
to help businesses become more energy efficient. Earlier this year, the town of
Berea received a $10 million Community Facilities loan to renovate and expand
the city hall and public safety facilities.



 The town of Berea has played an integral role in USDA's place-based initiatives
. Last year, it was chosen as one of 10 pilot sites for the Rural Integration
Models for Parents and Children to Thrive (Rural IMPACT) demonstration project.
Rural IMPACT helps communities adopt a two-generation approach to addressing the
needs of vulnerable children and their parents. Its goal is to increase parents'
employment and education and improve the health and well-being of families.



 The project is led by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services in
collaboration with USDA, the Department of Labor, the Corporation for National
and Community Service, the Appalachian Regional Commission, the Delta Regional
Authority, the Annie E. Casey Foundation, the W.K. Kellogg Foundation and other
philanthropic partners. The members of this public/private partnership have
selected 10 local and tribal communities and placed AmeriCorps VISTA members
there to provide technical assistance and capacity-building resources to reduce
child poverty. At a White House Rural Forum convened in State College, Pa.,
earlier this week, the partners announced that the AmeriCorps VISTA members will
remain in the 10 communities for a second year.



 USDA expects the financing announced today will serve as a catalyst for
additional investment. Many of the community developers already have established
relationships with other private and philanthropic funders. The ability to
relend money could foster greater leveraging of private and philanthropic
investments in rural communities.



 USDA Rural Development has a $215 billion loan portfolio and offices in every
state in the nation. The agency annually invests $30 billion, on average, in
rural communities.



 Since 2009, USDA Rural Development (@USDARDThis is an external link or
third-party site outside of the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA)
website.) has funded nearly 9,200 community facilities such as schools, public
safety and health care facilities; invested nearly $13 billion to start or
expand nearly 112,000 rural businesses; helped 1.1 million rural residents buy
homes; and helped bring high-speed Internet access to nearly 6 million rural
residents and businesses. USDA also has invested $31.3 billion in 963 electric
projects that have financed more than 185,000 miles of transmission and
distribution lines serving 4.6 million rural residents.

contact:

                     The Idaho Business Review (Boise, ID)

                               November 10, 2008

Idaho city brings in poultry breeder Hy-Line North America

BYLINE: Brad Carlson

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 554  words


The state has stepped in with a half-million-dollar nest egg, per se, to help
the City of Burley bring poultry breeder Hy-Line North America to the region.

Burley officials on Oct. 30 received a $500,000 Rural Community Development
Block Grant to assist Hy-Line with its constuction plans that include water,
sewer, sidewalk and road infrastructure improvements.

Hy-Line is investing $17 million to build a new facility in Burley, expected to
create 45 new jobs, the Idaho Department of Commerce said in a release.
Construction is under way, and expected to conclude in early 2009.

Gov. C.L. "Butch" Otter said in the release that the success of the Project 60
initiative - to raise gross state product from $51 billion to $60 billion -
depends in large measure on this kind of business expansion providing great
opportunities for local and state economies to grow.   This grant will further
improve Burley's infrastructure, creating a foundation for additional growth and
creation of even more good jobs for Idahoans, he said.

"We are really thrilled to get this particular company. They are a great
company," Burley Economic Development Director Doug Manning told the Idaho
Business Review. Des Moines, Iowa-based Hy-Line will be a good addition to a
local economy that Burley is working to diversify, the former Burley mayor and
city council member said.

"We are getting into some high-tech ag here," he said, adding: "We always will
be dependent on ag. We want to make it more value-added in many cases. "

Hy-Line says on its Web site it has been dedicated "to genetic excellence for
nearly three quarters of a century has produced revolutionary breakthroughs in
the science of poultry breeding that have not only benefited the worldwide egg
production industry, but in so doing have helped to feed the earth's burgeoning
human population. " Company officials could not be reached immediately.

Manning said Hy-Line fits well in an industrial area that continues to develop
on Burley's southwest side, at 27th Street and Washington Avenue.

Businesses setting up in the industrial area in the last 18 months include
Sacramento-based Pacific Ethanol, Mount Sterling, Ill.-based Dot Foods and
Fayetteville, Ark.-based Packaging Specialties. They joined existing occupants
Boise Cascade - which operates a corrugated container plant - and Handy Truck
Line.

A railroad spur that goes through the southwest Burley industrial area and quick
access to the city's truck route attracted some businesses and are expected to
attract additional businesses, Manning said. Distribution companies have
expressed interest in locating in the area, he said.

As for the grant to Hy-Line, Manning said: "Often, these improvements open the
way for other businesses. "

For example, the Pacific Ethanol project included sewer and water line
extensions, and road improvements, that ultimately benefit other businesses, he
said. Burley's urban renewal district has used tax-increment financing to fund
some infrastructure improvements designed to encourage business development, he
said.

This is yet another Rural Community Development Block Grants that has been
directed to the region. Administered by the Idaho Department of Commerce, the
grants are financed with state general tax revenue, under the Idaho Rural
Initiative, to expand economic opportunities.

                      The Western Star (Coldwater, Kansas)

                               December 19, 2013

Community re-opens Grocery Store

BYLINE: The Western Star staff

LENGTH: 667  words


So what's in store? No, I don't mean what is coming up soon. I mean, what is
inside the store?

This week we'll learn about a community which lost its only local grocery store,
only to get it back through its community foundation. Thanks to Logan Falleti of
the K-State Center for Engagement and Community Development's Rural Grocery
Initiative for this story.

Faye Minium, a long-time local banker, is president of the Morland Community
Foundation. The foundation was founded in 1994 and has funded various
development projects through the years, but in 2006 it faced a new challenge:
The town only grocery store was closing.

The store in Morland was founded in 1915. Through the years it had been known as
Bean's Country Store, Steven's Grocery, and Brook's Store. But in 2006 the owner
closed the store because of declining health and age.

In responise, the Morland Community Foundation launched an Access to Healthy
Food initiative. The goal was to provide healthy food to the elderly and other
members of the community. One component of the initiative was to re-open the
store and operate it as a nonprofit enterprise. They bought the former store
building and named the new store Morland Mercantile.

With help from a community development block grant, the building was winterized,
refurbished, and had a new furnace installed. Then another issue surfaced: The
store and all of Morland was classified in a flood plain which made it difficult
to get permits and insurance. The city did a study and found that the land could
be reclassified. So, the city spent $28,000 over a year to re-map and revise the
flood plain boundaries. As an additional benefit to the community, all but two
residences in Morland were cleared of their floodplain status.

The newly renovated building was then filled with equipment, most of which was
donated or bought used. The foundation was able to buy used equipment from a
town 100 miles away which had recently closed its grocery store.

The first order of canned goods arrived Oct 22, 2013, followed by deliveries of
fresh produce and meat. Volunteers unloaded and stocked all the shelves.

The store's permanent operations will add three new jobs to the town. One of
those is a full-time manager. A resident of nearby Hill City, Ron Radcliffe,
will manage the store. With his eight years of management experience, he knew
how to set up the shelving in the correct way.

The store is supplied by Affiliated Foods, but in order to meet the minimum
shipping order requirement, Morland orders through another rural Affiliated
store: Joslyn's Food Center, operated by Mark Joslyn of Hoxie, Kan. Hoxie is a
rural community of 1,207 people.

Now, tfrar's rural.

When the Morland volunteers were having trouble with the exact dimensions of its
meat counter, Mark Joslyn drove through a blizzard to Morland to answer their
construction questions himself.

On November 2, 2013, the store opened for business. On Nov. 16, the Governor of
Kansas cut the ribbon to celebrate the store's grand opening.

"It was a neat thing," said Fay Minium. "Everyone had fun and was enthusiastic
about being there. It's been a lot of work and a long time getting here, but I'm
optimistic it will be a good project for the whole area. I hope we're able to
provide the service and inventory people in the community want and need, and can
provide some unique projects."

Another part of the Access to Healthy Food initiative is a community kitchen
where residents can make their own products.

So what's in store? Not just in store for the future, but in the store itself.

The answer is necessities, healthy foods and local products for the people of
Morland. We commend Faye Minium and the

Morland Community Foundation for making a difference with this new service. If
this community can maintain the model of local initiative, there should be a lot
more good things in store."

And there's more. Three doors down from the store is an agribusiness with
cutting edge technology. We'll learn about that in another Kansas Profile.

                       The Southland Times (New Zealand)

                            August 15, 2013 Thursday

Search equipment to be upgraded

BYLINE: Neil Ratley

SECTION: NEWS; NATIONAL; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 452 words


A new emergency beacon tracking system will help to save more lives, a rescuer
says.

Fiordland Land Search and Rescue (LandSar) has received a grant of $40,590 from
Meridian Energy and will put the funds towards upgrading equipment.

LandSar committee member Lloyd Matheson said the tracking system used on search
and rescue aircraft had become outdated.

Only one of two Southern Lakes Helicopters aircraft used for search and rescue
work was fitted with the most advanced tracking system, which picked up the 406
frequency beacon now used by many trampers and boaties, Mr Matheson said.

A second aircraft with hi-tech equipment would mean greater ability to pinpoint
where a beacon was activated and improve response time, Mr Matheson said.

"It will give us full 24/7 capabilities and coverage and make a big difference
by taking any guesswork out of operations," he said.

Hi-tech search and rescue gear came at a cost and the support from Meridian was
greatly appreciated, Mr Matheson said.

Fiordland LandSar was not limited to operations in Fiordland but also responded
out of district on the west and east coasts of the country and the Southern
Ocean.

Several other organisations also received grants from Meridian's Manapouri Te
Anau Community Fund:

The Royal New Zealand Plunket Society was given $1840 to buy additional infant
and child seats for the Te Anau and Fiordland Plunket Society's Southland area
car- seat service.

The Te Anau Clay Target Club was given $12,650 to help build a down-the-line and
skeet field.

The Blackmount volunteer rural fire force received $5400 to buy a new pager
repeater system.

The Deep Cove Outdoor Education Trust received $2500 for new educational
material and signage to help pupils study the Manapouri Hydro Station habitat
restoration project in Fiordland's Deep Cove.

The Mararoa School received $7096 to buy a mega slide and commando net as part
of a playground upgrade.

Meridian's Manapouri Te Anau Community Fund chairman Mat Bayliss said the
community projects sustained the heart of rural communities.

The fund had been supporting community development initiatives since 2007, with
more than $1 million granted to a wide range of sustainable community
development initiatives in Te Anau, Manapouri, Clifden and Tuatapere, he said.

Helping hand: Manapouri Meridian Energy site manager John Twidle, left, gets an
explanation about how the Becca 406 tracking system works from Fiordland LandSar
committee member Lloyd Matheson. The energy company has provided Fiordland
LandSar with a

grant that will help pay for the advanced tracking system to be installed on a
second search and rescue helicopter.

Focus Falls On Rural Issues

Rural transport grants and policing will be among topics discussed at a new
round of Staffordshire Moorlands Neighbourhood Forums.  Moorlands Council for

meetings give local residents an opportunity to discuss health related or other
issues that affect themselves, their group organisation, or their community."

Cheddleton Craft Centre, Hollow Lane, Monday, December 2, at 7.30pm. Details on

School, Warslow, Tuesday, December 3, at noon. Information about rural library
service improvements, policing issues, and Borderlands Voices, an initiative to
benefit country communities.

St Edward' s Church meeting room, Leek, Thursday, December 5, at noon. The
topics will be supported volunteering, Market Towns Initiative, and advice on
welfare benefits and allowances.
