                        Lincoln Journal Star (Nebraska)

                          September 22, 2005 Thursday
                                  City Edition

Briefs

SECTION: B; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 684 words


State museum to open research collections

The University of Nebraska State Museum will host an open house and
behind-the-sciences tour of its research collections at Nebraska Hall from 11
a.m to 3 p.m. Saturday.

Visitors will be able to view millions of specimens from the collections of the
state museum of natural history. The collections cover the scientific fields of
anthropology, botany, entomology, parasitology, vertebrate paleontology and
zoology. They also will be able to meet the museum's scientists, visit the
research labs and ask questions.

The research collections are on City Campus in Nebraska Hall (west), fourth and
fifth floors. Enter at 16th and W streets.

Free parking will be available from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. in any UNL lot 10,
including the W Street lot between 14th and 16th streets.

Admission is $8 per family, $4 per adult and $2 per child; those younger than 5
get in free. Those with UNL identification cards or Friends of the Museum
memberships also get in free. Admission includes a pass to visit Morrill Hall on
the same day.

The Dunnes to perform at Concordia

The Dunnes, a storytelling and musical team, will present a program called
"Didgeridoo and Dulcimer, Too" for the public Saturday at Concordia University
in Seward.

During the adult conference of the Plum Creek Children's Literacy Festival, Bob
and Phyllis Dunne will tell the history of the Appalachian Mountain dulcimer and
the Australian Aboriginal didgeridoo. They will explain how they are played and
how to make them inexpensively for classroom use.

Shows will be at 9 a.m. and 11:30 a.m. in the university's science building.

This presentation is made possible by the Nebraska Humanities Council and the
Plum Creek Children's Literacy Festival as part of the council's speakers
bureau.

Telecast set on funding reforms

A satellite telecast and follow-up discussion of President Bush's proposed
reforms to community and rural development funding will be offered Monday.

The discussion will be from 2 to 4 p.m. at six sites across Nebraska. They will
be sponsored by the University of Nebraska Rural Initiative and the  Nebraska
Rural Development Commission. The local sites will be at the Gage County
Extension Office in Beatrice and the Nebraska East Union at the University of
Nebraska-Lincoln. Other viewing sites will be in Grand Island, Norfolk, North
Platte and Scottsbluff.

The reforms proposed in Bush's budget are known as the Strengthening America's
Communities Initiative. The proposal includes consolidating 18 federal
development programs into the new initiative. Among the programs slated for
elimination or consolidation are the Community Development Block Grant program,
Rural Business Enterprise Grants, Rural Business Opportunity Grants, Rural
Empowerment Zones, Economic Development Administration and Rural Housing and
Economic Development. Bush's proposal also would reduce funding from $5.3
billion this fiscal year to $3.7 billion for the initiative in fiscal 2006.

The first hour of Monday's program will be a satellite telecast from the U.S.
Department of Commerce featuring the report of the Strengthening America's
Communities Advisory Committee to the secretary of commerce. The report is
available at www.doc.gov/SACI.

The second hour will be comments and discussion of the report and its
implications for Nebraska. Commentators on the panel include:

* Scot Blehm, Nebraska state director, USDA Rural Development.

* Linda Fettig, executive director, Nebraska Rural Development Commission.

* Gary Hamer, deputy director, Nebraska Department of Economic Development.

* Robert Blair, associate professor, University of Nebraska at Omaha College of
Public Affairs and Community Service.

To view the program and attend the follow-up panel discussion at any site,
register with Marcia White by e-mail at mwhite2@unl.edu or call her at 472-1744.
Registrants should include name, organization and the location where they plan
to attend.

Program information is available on the Rural Initiative Internet site at
ruralinitiative.nebraska.edu under "Upcoming Events."

                          The Lamar Ledger (Colorado)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           November 18, 2008 Tuesday

New program to pair advocates with kids caught in legal system

BYLINE: Aaron Burnett, The Lamar Ledger, Colo.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 795 words


Nov. 18--LAMARLAMAR--For any child caught in the legal system, the situation can
feel overwhelming. In Prowers County, prospects may be improving with the recent
formation of a regional court appointed special advocate (CASA) program.

Southeastern Colorado CASA was recently formed to serve the nine counties of
southeastern Colorado that make up the 3rd, 15th and 16th Judicial Districts.
Early plans call for the organization to begin serving in the 15th Judicial
District, which includes Prowers County, before expanding to the other two
districts.

The national CASA organization was created in 1977 and has 900 member agencies
nationwide serving over 206,000 children annually in dependency and neglect
cases. In Colorado, the first CASA program was implemented in 1985 and has grown
to 14 programs statewide.

Beginning in July 2006, Colorado CASA began a rural initiative to develop and
provide sustainability to CASA organizations in outlying and rural sections of
Colorado. The initiative has been funded through a series of grants from the
state VALE program.

In southeastern Colorado, a steering committee was formed last year to determine
the feasibility of the implementation of a program in the region said Shelly
Tombleson, program coordinator for southeast Colorado. In the 15th Judicial
District, a $39,000 grant has funded the program for 2008 with a $40,000 grant
approved for 2009.

The goal of the organization is to assure the child's best interests are always
represented in court said Tombleson.

Tombleson said the program is looking for volunteers for both the community
development committee as well as to serve as advocates.

For advocate volunteers, the program calls for extensive training, amounting to
over 30 hours, as well as potentially extended periods of involvement. Tombleson
said an advocate's involvement in a case can last from 12 to 18 months.

"CASA is valuable in that they are people who are not in the legal system and
take more of a community view towards these cases and maybe sometimes more of a
common sense view," said local attorney Mark Davis, who has extensive experience
in dependency and neglect cases. Davis has served as a guardian ad litem, an
attorney who serves to represent the legal interests of the child.

"Where they help me is that a lot of times the attorneys that represent the
children cannot see them on a regular basis because of distance or another
reason and because the volunteers can be a real valuable set of eyes and ears
for the court," Davis said. "They also can be pretty helpful in helping families
who are in the system, getting them resources rounded up."

The attorney said distance and time constraints often restrict a guardian ad
litem from meeting with children as often as necessary and that a CASA volunteer
can assist by sharing some of the burden.

"Sometimes these CASAs can get in and really get involved with families and
really help them out and the guardian ad litem just can't do that," Davis said.

According to statistics provided by the National CASA Association, children with
a CASA volunteer are half as likely to spend time in long-term foster care and
are more likely to graduate from high school.

"Sometimes court and legal proceedings can get kind of convoluted. Sometimes you
need a neutral person that is not an attorney or who is not in the legal system
to kind of call a timeout and say 'wait a second, lets step back a second from
this and look at this on a more common sense level,'" Davis said.

Volunteers on the community development committee, will be asked to assist in
the recruitment of other volunteers, marketing the organization to the
community, fundraising and strategic planning said Tombleson. The committee will
meet on the second Tuesday of every month during the lunch hour.

The organization is currently seeking donations to outfit its permanent office
said Tombleson. PJ Wilson has donated a sizable space that is currently being
renovated in the Village Shopping Center for a permanent office.

"We're very lucky," Tombleson said concerning Wilson's donation.

Individuals interested in volunteering in either capacity are encouraged to
attend a meet and greet session on Dec. 9, in the dance room at the Lamar
Community Building from 11:30-1:30 p.m. Tombleson can be contacted by phone at
(719) 688-3245 or by email at southeastcasa@coloradocasa.org

To see more of the Lamar Ledger, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.lamarledger.com/. Copyright (c) 2008, The Lamar Ledger, Colo.
Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints, email
tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

FR-5981-D-01 Consolidated Delegations of Authority for the Office of Community
Planning and Development

LENGTH: 2843  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington, DC:  This Notice document was issued by the Department of Housing
and Urban Development (HUD)



  Action



 Notice of delegations of authority.

 Summary



 This notice updates, clarifies, and consolidates delegations of authority from
the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development to the Assistant Secretary for
Community Planning and Development, the Principal Deputy Assistant Secretary for
Community Planning and Development and the General Deputy Assistant Secretary
for Community Planning and Development.



 Dates



 Effective Date: January 10, 2017.

 For Further Information Contact



 Cliff Taffet, General Deputy Assistant Secretary, Office of Community Planning
and Development, Department of Housing and Urban Development, 451 7th Street
SW., Room 7100, Washington, DC 20410-7000; telephone number 202-708-2690. This
is not a toll-free number. For those needing assistance, this number may be
accessed via TTY by calling the Federal Relay Service at 800-877-8339.

 Supplementary Information



 This notice updates, clarifies, and consolidates into one notice the authority
delegated by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development to the Assistant
Secretary for Community Planning and Development, the Principal Deputy Assistant
Secretary for Community Planning and Development and the General Deputy
Assistant Secretary for Community Planning and Development. This notice
supersedes all previous delegations to the Assistant Secretary for Community
Planning and Development, the Principal Deputy Assistant Secretary for Community
Planning and Development and the General Deputy Assistant Secretary for
Community Planning and Development, including the delegation published on April
20, 2015, at 80 FR 21747.

 Section A. Authority Delegated



 Only the Assistant Secretary for Community Planning and Development is
delegated the authority to issue a final regulation or a Notice of Funding
Availability (NOFA). The authority delegated herein to the Assistant Secretary
for Community Planning and Development, the Principal Deputy Assistant Secretary
for Community Planning and Development, and the General Deputy Assistant
Secretary includes the authority to waive regulations and statutes, but for the
Principal Deputy Assistant Secretary and the General Deputy Assistant Secretary
the authority to waive statutes is limited in Section B below. Except as
provided in Section B, the Secretary of HUD delegates to the Assistant Secretary
for Community Planning and Development, the Principal Deputy Assistant Secretary
for Community Planning and Development and the General Deputy Assistant
Secretary for Community Planning and Development the authority of the Secretary
with respect to the programs and matters listed below:



 1. The AIDS Housing Opportunity Act, Title VIII, Subtitle D of the
Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act, Public Law 101-625, 104 Stat.
4079 (1990) (codified as amended at 42 U.S.C. 12901-12912); 24 CFR part 574.



 2. The Base Closure Community Redevelopment and Homeless Assistance Act of
1994, Public Law 103-421, 108 Stat. 4346 (codified as amended at 10 U.S.C. 2687
note); 24 CFR part 586.



 3. Capacity Building for Community Development and Affordability Housing
grants, Section 4 of the HUD Demonstration Act of 1993, Public Law 103-120, 107
Stat. 1148 (codified as amended at 42 U.S.C. 9816 note).



 4. Comprehensive Housing Affordability Strategies (CHAS), Title I of the
Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act, Public Law 101-625, 104 Stat.
4079 (1990) (codified as amended at 42 U.S.C. 12701 et seq.); 24 CFR part 91.



 5. Economic Development Initiative grants, as provided for in annual HUD
appropriations acts (e.g., the Consolidated Appropriations Resolution, Fiscal
Year 2003, Public Law 108-7, 117 Stat. (2003)).



 6. Urban Empowerment Zones (EZ), as authorized under Title 26, subtitle A,
chapter 1, subchapter U of the Internal Revenue Code (codified as amended at 26
U.S.C. 1391 et seq.); 24 CFR parts 597 and 598.



 7. The HOME Investment Partnerships Act, Title II of the Cranston-Gonzalez,
National Affordable Housing Act, Public Law 101-625, 104 Stat. 4079 (1990)

 8. The Loan Guarantee Recovery Fund under Section 4 of the Church Arson

 9. Neighborhood Initiatives grants specifically designed in annual HUD
appropriations acts (e.g., the Consolidated Appropriations Act 2010, Pub. L.

 10. The Homelessness Prevention and Rapid Re-Housing Program (HPRP), as
authorized under the Homelessness Prevention Fund heading of Division A, Title
XII of the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009, Public Law 111-5, 123
Stat. 115.



 11. The Housing Trust Fund (HTF), Section 1338 of the Federal Housing
Enterprises Financial Safety and Soundness Act of 1992, added by Section 1131 of

 12. Rural Innovation Fund grants as provided for in annual HUD appropriations

 13. The Tax Credit Assistance Program (TCAP), as authorized under the HOME

 14. The Self-Help Homeownership Opportunity Program (SHOP) under section 11 of

 15. Technical Assistance and Capacity Building awards authorized under any

as provided for in annual and supplemental HUD appropriations acts (e.g., the

 16. Title I of the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974, Public Law

part 570, including the following:

Law 113-291, 128 Stat. 3292, 3521-3524 (2014).

 Section B. Authority Excepted



 There is excepted from the authority delegated under Section A:



 1. The power to sue and be sued;



 2. Under Title I of the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974, Public
Law 93-383, 88 Stat. 633 (codified as amended at 42 U.S.C. 5301 et seq.):



 a. The power to administer the Indian Community Development Block Grant
program, for which the authority has been delegated to the Assistant Secretary
for Public and Indian Housing;



 b. The power to administer section 107 programs delegated to the Assistant
Secretary for Policy Development and Research;



 c. The power to issue obligations for purchase by the Secretary of the Treasury
under section 108(g) of the Housing and Community Development Act (42 U.S.C.
5308); and



 d. The power and authority of the Secretary with respect to nondiscrimination
under section 109 may be exercised only with the advice of the Assistant
Secretary for Fair Housing Equal Opportunity.



 3. For programs noted in Section A.22 of this delegation that are no longer
authorized for funding;



 a. The power to establish interest rates; and



 b. The power to issue notes or obligations for purchase by the Secretary of the
Treasury.



 4. The authority delegated under Section A to the Principal Deputy Assistant
Secretary and General Deputy Assistant Secretary does not include the authority
to waive the following statutes:



 a. The authority under annual and supplemental HUD appropriations acts
providing Community Development Block Grant funding for disaster recovery (e.g.,
Pub. L. 113-2) to waive, or specify alternative requirements for, statutory
requirements;



 b. The authority under section 215(a)(6) of the Cranston-Gonzalez National
Affordable Housing Act (42 U.S.C. 12745) to waive qualifying rents; and



 c. The authority under section 858(b) of the Cranston-Gonzalez National
Affordable Housing Act (42 U.S.C. 12907) to waive requirements for short-term
supported housing and services.

 Section C. Authority To Redelegate



 The Assistant Secretary, the Principal Deputy Assistant Secretary and the
General Deputy Assistant Secretary for Community Planning and Development are
authorized to redelegate to employees of the Department any authority delegated
under Section A. Redelegated authority to CPD Directors, Deputy Assistant
Secretaries or other CPD program officials does not supersede the authority of
the Assistant Secretary as designee of the Secretary.

 Section D. Delegations Superseded



 This notice supersedes all prior delegations of authority from the Secretary to
the Assistant Secretary for Community Planning and Development, including the
delegation published on April 20, 2015, at 80 FR 21747.

 Authority



 Section 7(d) of the Department of Housing and Urban Development Act, 42 U.S.C.
3535(d).

 Dated: January 10, 2017.

 Julián Castro,

 Secretary.

                                US Official News

                             March 30, 2015 Monday

Arizona: HUD AWARDS $1.5 MILLION TO BOOST ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT IN THE LOWER
MISSISSIPPI RIVER DELTA REGION

LENGTH: 481  words

DATELINE: Phoenix


Department of Housing and Urban Development has issued the following news
release:

WASHINGTON - U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) Secretary
Julián Castro announced today that HUD is awarding $1.5 million to stimulate
local economies, produce more affordable housing and boost job growth in the
chronically underserved and undercapitalized Lower Mississippi River Delta
Region. The funding is provided through the Delta Community Capital Initiative
(DCCI).

San Antonio -based LiftFund, formerly Accion Texas, Inc. will receive a $1
million grant and Communities Unlimited and Southern Bancorp Capital Partners
(SBCP), both located in Arkansas, will each receive grants of more than
$200,000. These states  will use this funding to increase lending to small
businesses and entrepreneurs in eligible Delta regions. (See project summaries
below).

"The Lower Mississippi River Delta plays a vital role in strengthening its
regional economy and the entire United States," said Castro. "This funding will
spur business development, create jobs and produce more affordable housing
opportunities. HUD is committed to working with local leaders to help build
communities that thrive."

Delta Regional Authority's Federal Co-Chairman Chris Masingill added: "We are
excited to see much-needed resources coming to the Delta region to help our
community institutions increase their investments into our small businesses and
entrepreneurs, who in turn create the jobs that build our communities and
improve the lives of the people of the Delta region. We take our role of being a
strategic partner with HUD and our federal partners seriously; this is another
example of federal partnerships empowering our communities and businesses to
grow and compete in the global marketplace."

The Delta Community Capital Initiative ("DCCI") is a collaborative effort among
three federal agencies - the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD),
the Department of the Treasury - Community Development Financial Institutions
Fund (CDFI Fund) and the Department of Agriculture - Rural Development
(USDA-RD).  The DCCI builds on the investments that strategic partner Delta
Regional Authority (DRA)'s Small Business and Entrepreneurship Initiative has
made to develop a pipeline of educated and skilled entrepreneurs and improve the
climate for business growth.  The DCCI will increase access to capital for
business lending and economic development in the chronically underserved and
undercapitalized Lower Mississippi River Delta Region. Specifically, it will
provide direct investment and technical assistance to community development
lending and investing institutions that focus on small business development to
benefit the residents of Lower Mississippi River Delta Region.

contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

Utah: Community Economic Development (CED) Healthy Food Financing Initiative
Projects

LENGTH: 320  words

DATELINE: Salt Lake City


Office of Rural Assistance Center, The State of Utah has issued the following
news release:

Sponsor  Office of Community Services
Deadlines  Jul 21, 2014
Contact

Gerald Shanklin
Phone: 855.792.6551
Email: ocsgrants@acf.hhs.gov
Purpose

The Community Economic Development (CED) Healthy Food Financing Initiative
Projects awards funding to Community Development Corporations for projects that
implement strategies to address food deserts, increase healthy food access in
low-income communities, foster self-sufficiency for low-income families, and
create sustained employment opportunities in low-income communities.

Examples of successful use of CED-HFFI funds include:

Financing the construction of grocery stores
    Providing direct assistance to farmers
    Supporting rural farmers markets
    Expanding existing food distribution businesses
    Supporting food business entrepreneurs

Bonus points will be awarded to projects that will create jobs in a rural
community or hire low-income individuals from a rural community to fill
positions created.
Eligibility

Applicants must:

Be a private, non-profit Community Development Corporation with 501(c)(3) or
non-501(c)(3) status
    Have articles of incorporation, bylaws, or other official documents
demonstrating that the CDC has as a principal purpose the planning, developing,
or managing of low-income housing or CED activities
    Have a Board of Directors with representation from each of the following:
community residents, business leaders, and civic leaders.

Geographic
coverage  Nationwide
Amount of
funding

Total Funding Available: $9,500,000
Award Ceiling: $800,000 per project period
Award Floor: $100,000 per project period
Number of Awards: 13
Application
process

Links to the full announcement and online application process are available
through grants.gov.
Tagged as  Economic development, Food and hunger

For further information please visit: http://www.raconline.org/

                            Ayr Advocate (Australia)

                           February 4, 2009 Wednesday
                                  1 - Edition

Blueprint delivers $20,000 grant to Burdekin council

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 336 words


COMMUNITIES in the Burdekin will continue to grow stronger thanks to a $20,000
grant issued as part of the latest round of Blueprint for the Bush funding,
local government minister Warren Pitt said this week.

Mr Pitt joined Premier Anna Bligh to present a $20,000 cheque to Burdekin Shire
Council on Sunday to develop the Burdekin Economic Development Strategic Plan.

The presentation was made as part of the Bligh Government's Community Cabinet
meeting in Townsville.

``The Burdekin Economic Development Strategic Plan will outline a 10-year
economic development vision for the Burdekin district and will empower the
community to take charge of its economic future,'' Mr Pitt said.

``Specifically, the plan will identify strategies to achieve growth and new
investment in the region, particularly in the agricultural, small business,
engineering, manufacturing, and tourism sectors.''

Mr Pitt said the grant had been secured through the Queensland Government's
Blueprint for the Bush ``Our Place Our Future initiative, which provides rural
and remote communities with the resources to strengthen their capacity to shape
their future.

``The funding will be used as a contribution toward the appointment of a
consultant who will work with a steering committee of 20 community
representatives and a broader group of stakeholders to develop the plan.''

Mr Pitt said the government was strongly committed to building strong and
sustainable communities across rural and remote Queensland.

``One of the major goals of the Blueprint for the Bush is for communities to be
viable and strong so it is important that they have access to funding
initiatives such as these,'' he said.

``Our ongoing investment through the program helps to deliver practical measures
to address rural community development issues, assist effective community
engagement and help implement existing community plans."

The presentation was originally scheduled to take place in Ayr but was moved to
Townsville because of flooding associated with ex-Cyclone Ellie.

                             156 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                   The Star Phoenix (Saskatoon, Saskatchewan)

                             April 17, 2012 Tuesday
                                 Final Edition

Despite UN push, official says these are 'dark days' for Canadian co-ops

BYLINE: Will Chabun, Leader-Post

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. C6

LENGTH: 478 words

DATELINE: REGINA


What was intended as an international year to salute co-operatives has turned
into "dark days."

That's the opinion of Beryl Bauer, president of the Saskatchewan Co-operatives
Association, reacting to news that federal budget cuts will mean the end of
Ottawa's Co-operative Development Initiative and a reduction in the size of the
Agriculture and Agri-Foods Canada branch that administered it, the Rural and
Co-operatives Secretariat.

Bauer said the CDI goes back to 2003 and has helped with the creation of
numerous co-operatives.

And Tuesday will see Bauer in Regina to ask Economic Development Minister Jeremy
Harrison about rumours the $65,000 grant his ministry gives the SCA to pay for a
full-time organizer of co-operatives will be cut too.

On the federal scene, Bauer said the Canadian Co-operatives Association has been
unsuccessful so far in getting a meeting with federal agriculture minister Gerry
Ritz, though his department sent to the Leader-Post an email stating it and the
CDI "have laid the groundwork for communities to more effectively interact and
take advantage of opportunities on their own."

"In addition," the email added, "other departments are increasingly sensitive to
the issues of rural Canadians, allowing AAFC to end the Community Development
and the Co-operatives Development Initiative programs.

"Furthermore, all government departments operate with a rural lens and will
continue to play a role in supporting rural communities. AAFC will retain a
reduced policy and research function on rural issues to reflect and meet the
needs of Canadians in rural communities."

Bauer said he's heard CDI grants that have already been approved will be paid
out. Those not yet approved will languish.

He added he can remember when the provincial government itself had eight
full-time co-operative organizers, but "when they retired, they didn't get
replaced."

That's odd, according to Bauer, because the provincial co-operatives association
shares a common goal with the government: "Develop business and grow the
province."

As well, he's noticed interest from Social Services Minister June Draude in
co-operatives, particularly in meeting the province's shortage of housing.

The United Nations declared 2012 as the International Year of Co-operatives to
salute and encourage this economic sector, which worldwide has one billion
members and employs 100 million people - 20 per cent more than are employed by
the world's multinational corporations.

Nationally, there are 9,000 co-operatives with 18 million members, $330 billion
in assets and 155,000 employees.

In Saskatchewan, one of Canada's strongholds of the co-operative and credit
union movements, these enterprises have a million members - many people are
members of more than one co-operative organization - and fully one-third of the
province's top 100 businesses are co-operatives.

wchabun@leaderpost.com

Kentucky: Gov. Beshear Joins Federal Officials to Announce New Program to Assist
Communities Affected by the Downturn of Coal, Energy Production

LENGTH: 814  words

DATELINE: Frankfort


Department of Commonwealth, The State of Kentucky has issued the following news
release:

Governor Steve Beshear today joined several federal and state officials to
announce the Partnerships for Opportunity and Workforce and Economic
Revitalization (POWER) initiative, which will award up to $38 million in grants
to coal communities to support economic and workforce development. The POWER
initiative is designed to effectively utilize a range of federal economic and
workforce development resources to assist communities negatively impacted by the
downturn of coal and energy production.

"It is no secret that our Kentucky coal communities have been struggling due to
a steady decline in production, and we must continue working on ways to expand
economic opportunities there," said Gov. Beshear. "The POWER initiative
emphasizes public, private and philanthropic partnerships tailored to the
specific needs of each community. I believe the POWER initiative will be a
strong component in helping our coal communities overcome their challenges and
thrive in the future. We will aggressively pursue these grant funds with our
local partners."

POWER will award grants to using $28 million to $38 million in FY 2015 funds
from the Department of Commerce (DOC), Department of Labor (DOL), Small Business
Administration (SBA), and the Appalachian Regional Commission (ARC). Grants will
be competitively awarded to applicants including state agencies, local
governments and stakeholders anchored in coal communities to develop and
implement strategic plans that will:

diversify economies;
    create jobs in new or existing industries;
    attract new sources of job-creating investments; and
    provide a range of workforce services and skills training that offer
industry-recognized credentials for high-quality, in-demand jobs.

Grant applications are tentatively set to be announced in April and May.

Joining Gov. Beshear today were U.S. Assistant Secretary of Commerce for
Economic Development Jay Williams; White House Director of Intergovernmental
Affairs and former Lt. Governor Jerry Abramson; Senior Advisor to the President
Brian Deese; and Lillian Salerno, administrator of USDA's Rural
Business-Cooperative Service. Each spoke to the importance of the POWER
initiative and the positive impact it can have on struggling communities.

"The Obama Administration is committed to supporting our workers and communities
as they face challenges related to a changing energy landscape in this country,"
said Assistant Secretary Williams. "EDA is proud to be leading the POWER
initiative and we look forward to working with our federal partners to help
communities diversify their economies and help workers get the skills they need
to adapt to and thrive in this changing economy."

"The POWER initiative is an opportunity to bring together the best efforts of
federal, state, and local governments and the private and non-profits sectors to
help Kentuckians build a better future for themselves, their businesses, and
their families," said Abramson.

The Department for Commerce's Economic Development Administration (EDA) will be
the administrative home for POWER and coordinate the effort among the many
federal agencies involved in the initiative. Grant selection, awards and
execution will be managed by each authorized agency, with EDA playing a
coordination role. For more information about the EDA, visit www.eda.gov.

$1.8 Million USDA Rural Business Loan
In coordination with today's POWER announcement, USDA Administrator Lillian
Salerno announced approval of a $1.8 million loan for a new innovative business
in Eastern Kentucky.

Kentucky Dairy Product Innovations (KYPDI) is a health-and-wellness beverage
business headquartered in London, Ky., that will become the first U.S. producer
of low-calorie, lactose-free skim milk. Using the low-calorie, lactose-free skim
milk, the company also has created a new carbonated and flavored dairy product
called Fizza that has been approved for sale at middle and high schools across
the country.

"Investing in small, rural businesses is essential to continuing the economic
revitalization we are seeing today," said Salerno. "The funding announced today
will help support the Obama Administration's vision by providing rural
communities with resources to support small businesses and create new,
sustainable jobs."

The funding is provided through USDA's Rural Economic Development Loan and Grant
program. It will enable KYDPI to lease-purchase a 12,000-square-foot production
facility in the London-Laurel County Industrial Park. The company plans to hire
up to 20 employees as a result of USDA's investment, which is supplemented by
other funding from Kentucky Highlands Investment Corporation and a Community
Development Block Grant.

In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

LOAD-DATE: March 27, 2015

                     The Journal Record (Oklahoma City, OK)

                            August 11, 2016 Thursday

Group proposes healthy food financing initiative

BYLINE: Sarah Terry-Cobo

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 464  words


OKLAHOMA CITY - Liz Waggoner is working to create jobs by making more healthy
food available.

The Voices for Healthy Kids campaign director with the American Heart
Association is a member of a task force with Native American citizens, bankers
and small grocers, among others. The group is following a national
public-private partnership funding model to open more food stores in rural and
low-income areas.

But she needs to pass legislation to establish the healthy food financing
initiative in Oklahoma.

Fifteen Food Access Task Force members met Thursday at the state Capitol to
learn about how other state initiatives have succeeded and to plan policy goals.
State Rep. Seneca Scott proposed the task force as part of House Bill 2650, but
it wasn't heard before the full chamber. He later approached the Choctaw Nation
and the Oklahoma Department of Agriculture, Food and Forestry, and the two
groups then signed a memorandum of understanding to proceed with the task force.

Waggoner said the goal is to make more fresh fruits and vegetables available by
opening new grocery stores, helping convenience stores add produce to shelves,
or bringing mobile farmers markets to neighborhoods.

Pennsylvania was the first state to establish fresh food financing assistance in
2004. The nonprofit group The Food Trust worked within the state to establish a
public-private partnership to fund a portion of grants or loans to start new
grocery businesses, said organization project manager Deirdre Church.

The state agreed to provide $30 million over three years. Combined with private
funding, the state's initiative resulted in $190 million invested and 88 new
grocery stores were opened in five years. The stores ranged between 900 square
feet and 69,000 square feet, and created 5,000 jobs.

Church said there is a federal healthy food financing initiative that provides
money to community development financial institutions. Citizen Potawatomi Nation
Community Development Corp. CEO Shane Jett said his organization has that status
and is willing to help bring federal money to Oklahoma for a fresh food funding
program.

But finding the political will to set aside state money for more small
businesses selling fresh food could be challenging, Waggoner said. That's in
part why it is important to emphasize the health benefits as well as the
potential to increase tax revenue from new businesses, she said.

"It is an economic issue, whether you live in a rural area, an urban area, a
suburban area, for the agricultural industry and for the tribes," Waggoner said.

Waggoner said the group will meet twice more before finalizing policy
recommendations in October.

resource.

                             India Investment News

                      December 9, 2013 Monday 6:30 AM EST

TD Charitable Foundation Awards $2.5 Million in Grants to Non-Profits Focused on
Affordable Housing Initiatives

LENGTH: 518  words


New Delhi, Dec. 9 -- The TD Charitable Foundation, the charitable giving arm of
TD Bank, America's Most Convenient Bank, today announced the winners of $2.5
million in grants to support affordable housing initiatives through its eighth
annual "Housing for Everyone" grant competition.



The "Housing for Everyone" competition, the TD Charitable Foundation's signature
program to bolster affordable housing efforts, invited non-profits from Maine to
Florida to submit proposals outlining their plans and initiatives.

"We are proud to award 'Housing for Everyone' grants to these outstanding
organizations as they continue their efforts to stabilize communities and
revitalize neighborhoods, and provide housing services to their many diverse
populations," said Elizabeth K. Warn, President of the TD Charitable Foundation.
"Our goal is to build successful partnerships that benefit people in our
communities, and the 'Housing for Everyone' grants will support the tremendous
work of these non-profits as they strive to help the underserved."

This year's "Housing for Everyone" grants winners are:

* Connecticut: Mutual Housing of Greater Hartford, Inc.

* Florida: Neighborhood Housing and Development Corporation in Gainesville;
Mid-Florida Housing Partnership, Inc. in Daytona Beach; Habitat for Humanity of
Greater Miami.

* Maine: Community Housing of Maine, Inc. in Portland.

* Massachusetts: Valley Community Development Corporation in Northampton; Twin
Cities Community Development Corporation in Fitchburg; Lawrence Community Works,
Inc. in Lawrence.

* New Hampshire: NeigborWorks Greater Manchester.

* New Jersey: Housing and Neighborhood Development Services, Inc. in Orange;
Garden State Episcopal Community Development in Jersey City.

* New York: Women in Need, Inc, in New York; Long Island Housing Partnership,
Inc. in Hauppauge; Community League of the Heights, Inc. in New York; Rural
Ulster Preservation Company, Inc. in Kingston; Women's Housing and Economic
Development Corporation in the Bronx.

* Pennsylvania: New Kensington Community Development Corporation in
Philadelphia; Asociacion Puertorriquenos En Marha, Inc. in Philadelphia; Impact
Services Corp. in Philadelphia; Intercommunity Action, Inc. in Philadelphia.

* North Carolina: Mountain Housing Opportunities, Inc. in Asheville.

* Rhode Island: Pawtucket Citizens Development Corporation in Pawtucket.

* South Carolina: Homes of Hope, Inc. in Greensville.

* Vermont: Champlain Housing Trust in Burlington.

* Washington, DC: TRF Development Partners, Inc. in Baltimore.

Organizations were required to have tax-exempt 501(c)(3) status and to develop
or maintain affordable housing, or provide housing-related programs and services
to  very low-, low- and moderate-income individuals or families.

A staunch commitment to active involvement in the local community is a vital
element of the TD Bank philosophy. TD Bank, America's Most Convenient Bank and
the TD Charitable Foundation provide support to affordable housing, financial
literacy and education, and environmental initiatives, many of which focus on
improving the welfare of children and families.

                             160 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                           Aberdeen Press and Journal

                                August 31, 2004

Rural petrol stations to benefit from subsidy plan

BYLINE: Moira Kerr

SECTION: News; Consumer; Motors; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 565 words


Motorists throughout rural Scotland last night received a boost with the news
that more petrol stations could be built in the Highlands and Islands and
Argyll.  Rural stations will benefit from Government subsidies after a ban on
fuel suppliers developing within an eight-mile radius of each other was lifted.

But the fresh step to encourage businesses to apply for grants for up to 50% of
capital funding was last night criticised by opponents.

They claimed the new steps failed to take the cost of providing jobs into
account.

Grants were previously only available to stations which were at least eight
miles from other filling stations.

Announcing the sweeping changes, Transport Minister Nicol Stephen stressed they
followed a review which found the subsidy scheme provided substantial travel,
economic and environmental benefits to many rural communities in Scotland far in
excess of its cost.

He said: "Keeping rural petrol stations open reduces unnecessary travelling
which is good for local people, the local economy and the environment.

"By making the scheme available to all rural petrol stations, more communities
can benefit from this support. For many people and businesses in rural Scotland,
a nearby petrol station is vital to improving convenient travel." But Fergus
Ewing, SNP MSP for Inverness East, Nairn and Lochaber, claimed the Government
had not done enough to help rural petrol stations and motorists.

He said: "I think this is a worthy scheme - as far as it goes - but it is
important to appreciate that this does not provide any support for staff and
running costs.

"The real problem is that Gordon Brown has, as the Tories did before him,
regarded the motorist as an easy way of raising taxes in a guise of action for
the environment." Mr Ewing argued that, in many parts of Argyll and the
Highlands, the environmental argument was not applicable.

He added: "Few of us are choked in the congested roads on Colonsay, or suffer
from smog clouds in Strontian, or are victims of pollution as we sit bumper to
bumper on the freeway from Fort William to Mallaig. Ozone is not Oban's biggest
problem." He argued Scotland should follow France's lead and establish a
community support scheme for essential services, such as the local shop, post
office and petrol station.

But Argyll MSP George Lyon welcomed the revised grant scheme, claiming it would
help many small petrol stations to improve their infrastructure.

John Hunt, who runs Kintyre Filling Station, at Tarbert, Mid Argyll, welcomed
the move.

Mr Hunt, whose business is half-a-mile from the nearest petrol station, found he
was not eligible for the grant scheme when he needed to improve his petrol pumps
a couple of years ago. He said he had to take out a loan - which he is still
paying off - to meet the costs and added he will now search for help to upgrade
the building.

The grant scheme is administered by Highlands and Islands Enterprise (HIE) and
Scottish Enterprise.

HIE has assisted 47 stations with grants, including £126,610 to Colonsay
Community Development for upgrading tanks and pumps and £66,646 to upgrade
petrol stations on Lewis.

More than 60 rural petrol stations have received grants totalling £2.7million
since the subsidy initiative was introduced in 1998. The new-look subsidy scheme
is due to come into effect on October 1.

                                US Official News

                             March 27, 2015 Friday

Kentucky: Gov. Beshear Joins Federal Officials to Announce New Program to Assist
Communities Affected by the Downturn of Coal, Energy Production

LENGTH: 814  words

DATELINE: Frankfort


Department of Commonwealth, The State of Kentucky has issued the following news
release:

Governor Steve Beshear today joined several federal and state officials to
announce the Partnerships for Opportunity and Workforce and Economic
Revitalization (POWER) initiative, which will award up to $38 million in grants
to coal communities to support economic and workforce development. The POWER
initiative is designed to effectively utilize a range of federal economic and
workforce development resources to assist communities negatively impacted by the
downturn of coal and energy production.

"It is no secret that our Kentucky coal communities have been struggling due to
a steady decline in production, and we must continue working on ways to expand
economic opportunities there," said Gov. Beshear. "The POWER initiative
emphasizes public, private and philanthropic partnerships tailored to the
specific needs of each community. I believe the POWER initiative will be a
strong component in helping our coal communities overcome their challenges and
thrive in the future. We will aggressively pursue these grant funds with our
local partners."

POWER will award grants to using $28 million to $38 million in FY 2015 funds
from the Department of Commerce (DOC), Department of Labor (DOL), Small Business
Administration (SBA), and the Appalachian Regional Commission (ARC). Grants will
be competitively awarded to applicants including state agencies, local
governments and stakeholders anchored in coal communities to develop and
implement strategic plans that will:

diversify economies;
    create jobs in new or existing industries;
    attract new sources of job-creating investments; and
    provide a range of workforce services and skills training that offer
industry-recognized credentials for high-quality, in-demand jobs.

Grant applications are tentatively set to be announced in April and May.

Joining Gov. Beshear today were U.S. Assistant Secretary of Commerce for
Economic Development Jay Williams; White House Director of Intergovernmental
Affairs and former Lt. Governor Jerry Abramson; Senior Advisor to the President
Brian Deese; and Lillian Salerno, administrator of USDA's Rural
Business-Cooperative Service. Each spoke to the importance of the POWER
initiative and the positive impact it can have on struggling communities.

"The Obama Administration is committed to supporting our workers and communities
as they face challenges related to a changing energy landscape in this country,"
said Assistant Secretary Williams. "EDA is proud to be leading the POWER
initiative and we look forward to working with our federal partners to help
communities diversify their economies and help workers get the skills they need
to adapt to and thrive in this changing economy."

"The POWER initiative is an opportunity to bring together the best efforts of
federal, state, and local governments and the private and non-profits sectors to
help Kentuckians build a better future for themselves, their businesses, and
their families," said Abramson.

The Department for Commerce's Economic Development Administration (EDA) will be
the administrative home for POWER and coordinate the effort among the many
federal agencies involved in the initiative. Grant selection, awards and
execution will be managed by each authorized agency, with EDA playing a
coordination role. For more information about the EDA, visit www.eda.gov.

$1.8 Million USDA Rural Business Loan
In coordination with today's POWER announcement, USDA Administrator Lillian
Salerno announced approval of a $1.8 million loan for a new innovative business
in Eastern Kentucky.

Kentucky Dairy Product Innovations (KYPDI) is a health-and-wellness beverage
business headquartered in London, Ky., that will become the first U.S. producer
of low-calorie, lactose-free skim milk. Using the low-calorie, lactose-free skim
milk, the company also has created a new carbonated and flavored dairy product
called Fizza that has been approved for sale at middle and high schools across
the country.

"Investing in small, rural businesses is essential to continuing the economic
revitalization we are seeing today," said Salerno. "The funding announced today
will help support the Obama Administration's vision by providing rural
communities with resources to support small businesses and create new,
sustainable jobs."

The funding is provided through USDA's Rural Economic Development Loan and Grant
program. It will enable KYDPI to lease-purchase a 12,000-square-foot production
facility in the London-Laurel County Industrial Park. The company plans to hire
up to 20 employees as a result of USDA's investment, which is supplemented by
other funding from Kentucky Highlands Investment Corporation and a Community
Development Block Grant.

                           November 14, 2015 Saturday

Kansas Health Foundation supports K-State's Rural Grocery Initiative

LENGTH: 268 words

DATELINE: Lahore



    Manhattan: Kansas State Univearsity has issued the following news release:



   K-State's Center for Engagement and Community Development has received a
$328,000 grant from the Kansas Health Foundation to support the center's rural
food access work.





 The Rural Grocery Initiative is one of the center's programs to build campus
and community partnerships around significant issues facing Kansans and Kansas
communities.



 "For about eight years, we've been working to help strengthen food access in
rural communities by working to sustain independently-owned rural grocery
stores," said David Procter, the center's director. "These stores play a
critical role in sustaining the social fabric of small Kansas towns and provide
a source of healthful foods, local jobs and taxes, as well as a community asset
for citizen recruitment and retention."



 The Kansas Health Foundation grant will help the center explore the
possibilities and elements of a food-access technical-assistance collaborative
and a food-access learning laboratory. The technical assistance will focus on
three interrelated healthy food access challenges:



     The challenge of strengthening retail grocery business practices while
expanding healthy food options, especially in rural parts of the state,

     The challenges of increasing the reach of Market Match, a SNAP local foods
incentives program, and

     The challenges of expanding the number of WIC- authorized retailers,
especially in rural counties and communities.

                            October 17, 2014 Friday

Pennsylvania: Corbett Administration Awards Community Development Block Grant
for Infrastructure Improvements in Somerset County

LENGTH: 321  words

DATELINE: Harrisburg


The state of Pennsylvania has issued the following news release:

Department of Community and Economic Development Secretary C. Alan Walker today
announced the award of a $500,000 Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) to
the Somerset County Commissioners to extend public sewer piping and improve the
pump station to handle the increased capacity in the Village of Gray in Jenner
Township, Somerset County.

"Improving sewer systems are a costly but necessary upgrade to ensure public
health and safety," said Sec. Walker. "This grant will help support these
efforts without leaving the Township and individual homeowners with the
financial burden."

The Jenner Area Joint Sewer Authority will provide sewer to residents of the
Village of Gray who are currently relying upon failing or marginally performing
on-lot septic systems. The project will include the extension of 7,000 linear
feet of new sanitary sewer piping and the connection of 21 households to the new
system. In addition, improvements will be made to the pump station to handle the
increased capacity. The project will benefit both the 21 households added but
also the existing households currently on the system.

The CDBG grant will provide funding to extend public sewer to the Village of
Gray area of Jenner Township, Somerset County, to eliminate deficient on-lot
systems.

The Community Development Block Grant Entitlement Program is federally funded
and provides funding for the smaller communities and rural areas of the
commonwealth for community development including but not limited to housing
rehabilitation, public services, community facilities, infrastructure
improvement, development and planning.

For more information about the CDBG program and other community development
initiatives, visit www.newPA.com or call 1-866-466-3972.

                       Eureka Times Standard (California)

                            February 4, 2008 Monday

Supervisors consider revised Headwaters Fund process

BYLINE: Jessie Faulkner/The Times-Standard

SECTION: LOCAL; News

LENGTH: 449 words


EUREKA -- The Headwaters Fund Board is citing nearly a year of study sessions
and planning meetings in recommending changes to its process, including taking a
more proactive approach.

The latter, if approved, would allow the board to chose an area of economic
development within the county's Comprehensive Economic Development Strategy, set
up an initiative steering committee, and "launch and staff" each initiative,
according to Community Development Services Director Kirk Girard.

"The Initiative partners would help identify appropriate uses of Headwaters Fund
monies," he wrote. "The Board of Supervisors would approve each initiative
before it starts and would approve all grant awards."

Those initiatives would be financed by revolving loan fund interest and unspent
grant funds. If the process is approved, the supervisors are scheduled to review
and comment on the proposed first initiative.

The Headwaters Fund Board is suggesting an initiative to align local education
and training with the needs of local business and industry.

"Our initial objectives will be to create a 'call to action,' host formation
meetings where specific goals are set by all stakeholders (education and
business), create a framework for supporting and implementing change, and
support development of specific projects that could receive Headwaters Fund
grants," the report stated.

Tuesday's agenda also includes a letter to Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger asking
that Grizzly Creek Redwoods State Park be removed from the list of state parks
to be closed.

"The State's budget deficit should not be shouldered by a department that has
'stepped up to the plate' and through its dedicated employees and volunteers
maintained a park system with very minimal resources," the proposed letter
states. "Finally, in Humboldt County the closure of Grizzly Creek State Park
will significantly impact rural residents who rely upon the park for their
drinking water."

Meanwhile, Public Works Director Tom Mattson is seeking the board's approval of
plans and specifications to stabilize the foundation and the piers of the
Martin's Ferry Bridge, and authorize him to distribute bid packages for the
work. There is some urgency to the request as the federal Highway Administration
will cover 100 percent of the stabilization efforts if the work is completed by
June 1, according to Mattson's report. After June 1, the federal contribution
drops to 88.5 percent with the county and OES making up the balance. The
stabilization is estimated to cost $6.13 million.

If You Go:

What: Humboldt County Board of Supervisors

When: 9 a.m., Tuesday

Where: 825 Fifth St., Eureka

Jesie Faulkner can be reached at 441-0517 or jfaulkner@times-standard.com .

                                US Official News

                            April 1, 2015 Wednesday

HUD Announces Key Grants to Help Arkansas's Small Businesses, Provide Emergency
Construction Funds

LENGTH: 341  words

DATELINE: Washington


Office of the House of Representative French Hill, U.S Government has issued the
following news release:

The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) formally awarded $1.5
million to boost economic development in the Lower Mississippi River Delta
Region. This funding is provided through the Delta Community Capital Initiative.

"America's economy is fueled by small businesses, and when those businesses are
unable to access the capital needed to grow and expand, our states and local
communities feel the effects. Our CDFIs in Arkansas serve a vital role,
providing small and local businesses with loans--often microloans--tailored to
meet their specific needs while strengthening their local towns," said
Congressman French Hill.

Included in the $1.5 million award was $250,000 for Southern Bancorp Capital
Partners (SBCP). SBCP is a Little Rock-based community development financial
institution (CDFI) that aids economic development in rural areas.

"We are grateful to both the Delta Regional Authority and HUD for their
partnership in creating new economic opportunities in the rural Delta. Our
organization, a § 501(c)(3) U.S. Treasury-certified CDFI, has been supporting
Delta entrepreneurs through small business training and lending for over 25
years, which means we have seen firsthand the challenges faced by businesses
needing to raise capital. The investment by the Delta Community Capital
Initiative will be a great tool for empowering rural entrepreneurs and
stimulating growth in the Delta," said SBCP CEO Dominik Mjarten.

HUD also announced a grant of $3,333,442 to the Searcy Housing Authority for the
replacement of the sewer and plumbing lines at Searcy Apartments.

"The Searcy Apartments have experienced severe infrastructure problems over the
past several years, and this grant will help ensure necessary repairs are made
to protect the health and safety of those who reside in the community." said
Hill.

                         Middlesbrough Evening Gazette

                            December 15, 2008 Monday
                                  SP3 Edition

New proposals will boost the business base;
Commercial Feature in association with Tees Valley Unlimited

SECTION: FEATURES; Pg. 30

LENGTH: 550 words


PROPOSALS have been drawn up for a new pounds 11m initiative, backed by the
European Regional Development Fund, to boost and restructure the Tees Valley
business base.

The Tees Valley Integrated Business Support Activity Operation, is a set of 11
projects that will provide new job opportunities through business establishment
and growth, and safeguard existing jobs through improved efficiencies.
Concentrated in the most disadvantaged areas of the sub-region, it will help
reduce the disparities in economic performance in the Tees Valley and the
North-east region.

All of the selected projects will help to remove the barriers to growth for the
self-employed and micro businesses operating below the VAT threshold and to
support them with the aim of increasing the number of VAT registrations.

The majority of the projects will work in partnership with Business Link North
East to ensure there is no duplication of activity and to maximise the benefit
to the individuals and small to medium sized businesses.

Some of the key benefits will be:

Linking companies to mentoring, training and networking opportunities, these
projects will assist in developing the entrepreneurship skills of new companies.

Linking new companies to training, support and a ready supply of information
which will allow them to access procurement opportunities across the EU.

Some new businesses supported through these projects will be linked to one of
the region's major innovation connectors, the Digital City initiative, which
lies at the heart of the Tees Valley.

By supporting the growth and survival of new companies in deprived communities,
this project will allow for an increase in high quality employment opportunities
in these deprived wards.

Meanwhile an application for European funding to support the rural communities
of the North York Moors, Howardian Hills and East Cleveland area has been
successful in securing pounds 3m. It will be used to support projects that
improve the quality of life and economic prosperity of local communities between
now and 2013.

The money is being provided via the LEADER grant programme funded by the
European Union and the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs that
supports sustainable economic and community development in rural areas.

The funding will be managed by the North York Moors, Coast and Hills LEADER
Partnership whose members include the North York Moors National Park Authority,
the Tees Valley Joint Strategy Unit, Redcar and Cleveland Borough Council North
Yorkshire County Council, local authorities in North Yorkshire, Rural Community
Councils and local voluntary organisations. The partnership will shortly be
looking to create a Local Action Group of local businesses, farmers, landowners,
voluntary groups and individuals which will play a key role in allocating the
funding.

Following consultation with local communities and stakeholders, three main
priority themes have been identified:

Sustainable rural communities

Conservation and enhancement of the rural heritage, recreation opportunities and
environment

Village renewal and development Early in the new year, people and organisations
within the project area will be able to apply for grants for initiatives that
fit with the themes and priorities of the programme.

                                 The Bond Buyer

Deficit Estimates Revised Upward For 1983, 1984

                           April 13, 1983, Wednesday

By Craig T. Ferris and Frank Gresock

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 12


Despite new projections of increased economic growth, the Reagan administration
today estimated that the fiscal 1983 and 1984 budget deficits will be $4 billion
larger than it projected in January.

The Office of Management and Budget said that the 1983 deficit will be $210.5
billion when the fiscal year ends Sept. 30, $2.5 billion larger than it
projected in January. Similarly, the fiscal 1984 deficit is now expected to be
$190.2 billion, $1.5 billion higher than previously estimated.

Although the administration now projects economic growth of 4.7% this year, up
from the 3.1% rate forecast three months ago, OMB said the deficit will rise
because of declines in revenue due to falling oil prices and lower inflation and
higher spending due to passage of the jobs bill.

OMB said inflation is now expected to rise 4.5% this year, instead of the 5.6%
rate projected in January.

At the same time, OMB projected a lower budget deficit for fiscal years 1985
through 1988 than in January. The revised projection for fiscal 1985 is for a
$184.6 billion gap, down $9.6 billion from January. And the nation's combined
budget deficits through 1988 will be $28.5 billion lower than originally
projected, although the deficit in fiscal 1988 will still be $102.4 billion.

The revised forecast left unchanged both the administration's earlier forecast
of a 4% real growth rate, on a fourth-quarter-to-fourth-quarter basis, for
fiscal 1984 through 1988, and 90-day Treasury bill rates of 8.0% this year, 7.8%
in 1984, 7.1% in 1985, 6.6% in 1986, 6.4% in 1987 and 5.9% in 1988.

The updated forecast also projected that unemployment will decline faster than
originally thought. The estimate is for a drop in joblessness to 9.7% this year,
on a fourth-quarter-to-fourth-quarter basis, down from the 10.4% rate projected
in January. The jobless rate is expected to decline to 8.8% next year and 8.2%
in 1985, down from 9.5% and 8.5% projected in January.

OMB projected that the deficit will rise by $2.5 billion this year, as receipts
increase by $800 million to $598.3 billion while spending rises by $3.3 billion
to $808.5 billion - primarily due to the recently enacted jobs bill.

The fiscal 1984 deficit will rise by $1.5 billion, OMB said, as receipts fall by
$6 billion to $653.7 billion while spending is expected to decline by $4.6
billion from earlier estimates to $843.9 billion.

Because of the projected rise in the deficits this year and next, OMB said it
now expects federal government borrowing to rise this year by $2 billion over
the January estimate to $217 billion and by $1 billion in 1984 over the January
estimate to $204 billion.

Because of the higher deficits and increased agency borrowings, OMB said it
expects the total debt subject to limit will be $1.388 trillion on Sept. 30,
about $8.3 billion above the Janurary estimate, and $1.619 trillion on Sept. 30,
1984, some $16.2 billion over the estimate three months ago.

OMB said the higher real GNP, lower unemployment and inflation would cut $98
billion from the combined deficit through 1988 - but lower oil prices, the jobs
bill, and other spending will raise the combined deficit by $69.5 billion,
resulting in a net reduction of only $28.5 billion from the combined deficit
projected in January.

Although the projected rise in real growth could mean an $18.4 billion reduction
in the total deficit this year and next, OMB said that gain will be more than
wiped out by lower oil prices, the jobs bill, and technical reestimates. As a
result, it said, the nation will be $4 billion further in debt and the end of
this year and next than forecast in January.

Meanwhile, in the Republican-controlled Senate Budget Committee, President
Reagan suffered a number of setbacks to his 1984 budget. The committee
tentatively rejected some of his proposed cuts in urban aid and transportation.

Pete V. Domenici, R-N.M., chairman of the budget committee, said some of the
decisions made today could be revised after the committee decides on the level
of tax revenues they will propose for the 1984 budget.

The committee is scheduled to set a tax revenue level on Wednesday, which could
force them to lower spending to hold down the deficit.

The panel made no mention of the President's New Federalism initiative, which
would consolidate urban aid grants to states and localities, and provided the
full $3.5 billion for community development block grants.

President Reagan had proposed taking the $1.1 billion provided for community
development under the recent emergency jobs bill from the total $4.5 billion
cities and counties expect to receive next year.

The President's federalism plan also envisioned combining community development
money with the $4.5 billion into one block grant. No mention of this block grant
was made by the senators. In addition, the panel agreed to provide $450 million
for urban development action grants in 1984.

The administration's budget called for a savings of $200 million by carrying
over unused urban action grant money from 1983.

Earlier in the day, the committee rejected the idea of a $850 million rural
housing block grant under the federalism initiative.

Under the initiative, the $850 million would have been divided among the states
to provide housing in rural areas. But the committee's rejection of that plan
showed that Congress wanted to continue the current system of providing
interest-subsidized mortgages to residents of rural areas.

President Reagan would have provided part of the housing-block grants to the
states by eliminating low-interest loans through the federal Farmers Home
Administration. However, the committee today voted a 2% increase in the
subsidized loans. In 1983, the mortgage authority under the farmer's home
program is expected to provide mortgages for some 90,000 single-family homes.

As part of its tentative decisions, the budget committee also proposed funding
for 14,000 units of housing for the elderly and disabled, which the President
wanted held to 10.000 units.

Sen. Domenici said of the rural housing loans: ''I don't believe we're ever
going to get rid of Farmers Administration low-interest loans.''

At the same time the committee rejected the administration's plan to cut back
highway and mass transportation spending authorized when Congress enacted the
5-cents-per-gallon gas tax last year.

The committee voted 10 to 6 to rule out the administration's latest attempt to
phase out by 1985 the $700 million annual operating subsidies for public
transportation systems around the country.

When Congress passed the gasoline tax it dedicated 1 cent, or about $1 billion a
year, for mass transportation, capital projects and operating subsidies.
Although the committee cannot say how the money shall be spent, it made it clear
that it felt capital spending could be reduced next year to provide the
operating subsidies.

The committee also rejected the administration's plan to cut $200 million from
highway spending, and instead approved the full $12.1 billion authorized when
Congress passed the gas tax. Revenues from the tax finance federal highway
construction.

Earlier the committee agreed to a $12.7 billion international affairs budget
which includes $8.5 billion in additional funds for the International Monetary
Fund.

The international affairs budget, which includes the IMF and World Bank
activities, also contains foreign aid and assistance to Israel, as well as food
programs for underdeveloped nations.

Although the committee cannot dictate how this money should be used, it will
send language to the Senate calling for tighter controls on loans made by both
the World Bank and the IMF.

                                 July 16, 2015

MEETING FOR ARTS, CULTURAL & HISTORIC ORGANIZATIONS

BYLINE: N. Warren Town & County News staff

LENGTH: 496  words


In August 2014, the Iowa Heartland Resource, Conservation & Development, Inc.
(IHRC&D) based in Indianola received a USDA Rural Community Development
Initiative grant to assist in supporting and sustaining efforts to unite the
vast array of arts, cultural and historical assets in Dallas, Jasper, Madison,
Marion, Polk (rural) and Warren counties. One of the outcomes of this grant is
to establish a Regional Arts Council composed of advocates for the arts, culture
and history.

To share more information and learn about this exciting development, a
"Community Conversations" Lunch Meeting is planned for Tuesday, July 28, at
11:30 a.m. at the Winterset Public Library, 123 North Second Street. The lunch
is complimentary and parking is easily accessible. Please RSVP to Nancy at
library@winterset.lib.ia.us or by calling 515.462.1731 by Friday, July 24, if
you plan to attend.

Through this initiative, they are partnering with the Iowa League of RC&D,
University of Iowa and the Iowa Department of Cultural Affairs to bring support
and assistance to arts, cultural and historic organizations within our rural
communities.. What we know:

Current arts, history and cultural organizations in Iowa may benefit from
technical assistance, opportunities to network with one another and share
projects or goals.

Many groups doing great things are faced with small, but mighty, Boards and/or
volunteers who are aging or stretched to capacity.

Accessing funds for arts, history and culture is challenging-especially in rural
Iowa yet we have outstanding resources and assets worthy of support.

Investing in arts, history and cultural projects can have a huge economic impact
on small communities, as well as entice younger generations to stay or return to
a vibrant, small community.

Arts, history and culture programs in regional school districts are often the
first to go when budgets are tight.

At this time, one of our primary goals is to establish a Regional Cultural
Council. The purpose of the Council is to preserve, protect, interpret and
promote Iowa's art, culture and history. To that end, Regional Cultural Councils
are being developed to provide local input, guidance and leadership for regional
planning and implementation of projects.

Regional Cultural Councils serve as a catalyst for the creative economy.

Regional Cultural Councils are empowered to become engines for economic
vitality, cultural diversity and historic preservation as well as regional art,
history and cultural project planning throughout Iowa.

Because the public's guidance and input is critical to this process, we
encourage advocates for the arts, culture and history to attend this meeting.
This is a multi-year effort that will rely on the ideas, creativity and energy
to achieve successful outcomes.

The IHRC&D is a 501(c)(3) corporation serving Dallas, Jasper, Madison, Marion,
Polk and Warren counties for the purpose of improving the quality of life
through economic development and resource conservation.

Pennsylvania: Corbett Administration Awards Community Development Block Grant
for Infrastructure Improvements in Huntingdon County

LENGTH: 332  words

DATELINE: Harrisburg


The state of Pennsylvania has issued the following news release:


Department of Community and Economic Development Secretary C. Alan Walker today
announced the award of a $500,000 Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) to
the Huntingdon County Commissioners to relocate a public sewer and water lines
in Mt. Union Borough, Huntingdon County.

"The Corbett Administration is pleased to assist Mt. Union Borough with the
support to proactively respond to a significant infrastructure need that will
positively impact the community," said Sec. Walker. "Our partnership with the
borough will save 16 households from becoming uninhabitable due to potential
collapses and infrastructure cutoffs."

The CDBG grant will provide funding to relocate a portion of the public sewer
and water lines along with three brick manholes in the Pennsylvania Avenue area
in Mt. Union Borough.

The Huntingdon County Planning and Development Office will administer the
project which will include the relocation of 1,475 linear feet of sewer and
water lines that are compromised due to an unstable retaining wall. By
relocating the sewer and water lines, the retaining wall can be reconstructed
preventing 16 households from becoming uninhabitable in the event that the wall
collapses and cuts off the sewer and water lines. Upon completion, the project
will also allow for officials to reopen the closed portion of Pennsylvania
Avenue.

The Community Development Block Grant Entitlement Program is federally funded
and provides funding for the smaller communities and rural areas of the
commonwealth for community development including but not limited to housing
rehabilitation, public services, community facilities, infrastructure
improvement, development, and planning.

For more information about the CDBG program and other community development
initiatives, visit www.newPA.com or call 1-866-466-3972.

Northern Forest Canoe Trail, Madison get grants

BYLINE: The Original Irregular staff

LENGTH: 308  words


WASHINGTON -- Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack recently announced the selection
of 145 recipients for more than $15.3 million in grants to start or expand
businesses in rural communities.

In addition to the $15.3 million that USDA Rural Development is providing for
the 145 projects announced, recipients have raised $16 million from other
sources.

In Maine, three organizations will receive a total of $378,000 to promote
economic and community development.

Northern Forest Canoe Trail Inc. has been selected to receive $75,000 to provide
technical assistance to rural small businesses in promoting tourism, recreation
and heritage attractions m the Maine counties of Franklin, Somerset and
Piscataquis. This project is part of the Northern Forest Canoe Trail's Rural
Destination Tourism Initiative, which seeks to promote and foster economic
development through promoting nature-based tourism in New York, Vermont, New
Hampshire, Maine, and Quebec.

The Town of Madison has been selected to receive $50,000 to enhance its
revolving loan fund for small rural businesses, creating economic opportunities
in the area.

The Town of Greenville has been selected to receive $253,000 to construct a
building that will house its Natural Resource Education as well as serve as a
Visitor's Center for the Moosehead Lake Region Chamber of Commerce.

Acting State Director Valarie C. Flanders said. "These-investments represent
significant opportunities for Maine's rural small businesses, encourage tourism,
and support economic and community development in our state."

USDA Rural Development's mission is to increase economic opportunity and improve
the quality of life for rural residents. Further information on rural programs
is available at a local USDA Rural Development office or by visiting USDA Rural
Development's web site at http://www.rurdev.usda.gov/me.

Housing assistance funds awarded in Northern California

BYLINE: Staff report

SECTION: NEWS; Local

LENGTH: 456 words


Grant funds to assist needy families were awarded to seven agencies in Northern
California including the Community Action Agency of Butte County.

Senator Sam Aanestad (R-Grass Valley) announced that emergency grant funding has
been awarded to seven cities in his Northern California District.

The funding, administered by the California Department of Housing and Community
Development, is part of the Emergency Housing and Assistance Program (EHAP). The
grant funding will be directed to local agencies that provide shelter and other
services for homeless families and individuals.

"This grant funding is an important part of Governor Schwarzenegger's Initiative
on Homelessness, and shows his commitment to helping parents who are struggling
to provide for their children," Aanestad said.

More than $30,000 in grant funding has been awarded to Community Recovery
Resources in the Nevada County community of Grass Valley and Community Action
Agency of Butte County, Inc. has qualified for a grant of more than $25,000.

The Glenn County Human Resource Agency in Willows has qualified for two grants
worth more than $21,000, and the Alternatives to Violence agency in the Tehama
County community of Red Bluff will received an EHAP grant of more than $20,000.

EHAP grants in the amount of $16,980 have also been awarded to the Siskiyou
Domestic Violence and Crisis Center in Yreka. Rural Human Services, Inc. in
Crescent City will receive more than $10,000 in grant funding, and the Human
Response Network in Weaverville will receive a $10,000 EHAP grant.

"The agencies selected for this funding have shown previous success in not only
providing shelter, but helping the homeless find stable employment and permanent
housing," Aanestad said.

EHAP funds are distributed to eligible applicant agencies, and the application
process is competitive. Grant funding can be used to defray the costs of
facility operations and administration, residential rental assistance, and
leasing or renting rooms for temporary shelter. The grant funding can also be
put toward capital improvements.

Senator Aanestad says the goal of the Governor's Initiative on Homelessness is
to provide integrated permanent housing and services to long-term homeless
people in partnership with local governments and the private sector.  The
California Department of Housing and Community Development recently estimated
there are 80,000 to 95,000 homeless children in California, making the
percentage of homeless children greater today than at any time since the Great
Depression.

"Every Californian deserves a place to call home, Aanestad said. "The Governor's
initiative is a proven approach to help the long-term homeless start a new life
and say goodbye to the streets forever."
