David E. Procter, Director of CECD
K-State Receives USDA Research Grant to Advance Work with the Rural Grocery
Initiative.

Kansas State University has been awarded a $500,000 grant from the USDA to
address the economic and nutritional challenges faced by rural communities.  The
U.S. Department of Agriculture's (USDA) National Institute of Food and
Agriculture (NIFA) just announced more than $12 million in grants to support
research, education and Extension activities aimed at increasing prosperity and
economic security for farmers, ranchers, entrepreneurs and consumers across the
nation. The grant awarded to Kansas State University is directed by Dr. David
Procter, Center for Engagement and Community Development.  K-State co-project
directors include Dr. Hikaru Peterson, Agricultural Economics; Dr. Sandra
Procter, Human Nutrition Extension; Dr. Dan Kahl, Community Development
Extension; and Dr. Kathryn Draeger, University of Minnesota Extension.  Industry
partners include Affiliated Foods Midwest and NuVal, LLC.
National speakers highlight K-State Engagement Symposium

Four national thought leaders in engagement spoke at this year's Kansas State
University Engagement Symposium on April 7, 2014. The 2014 Engagement Symposium
focused on "The Centrality of Engagement in Higher Education: Integrating
Engagement across the University."  The panelists explored engaged work from all
mission areas of university work including research, teaching, and
outreach/Extension. In addition to bringing together national engagement voices,
K-State faculty and staff also highlighted their work.

Biosecurity Research Institute teams with Mercy Regional Health Center

When diagnosing most patients, Dr. Francis Koopman believes "when you hear
hoofbeats, look for horses." But when it comes to certain patients, like those
from Kansas State University's Biosecurity Research Institute, his team "looks
for zebras." The BRI researches many significant zoonotic pathogens that could
spread from animals to humans. Swine flu, yellow fever, tularemia, rift valley
fever, anthrax and even plague are all studied in the building. Mercy Regional
Health Center performs special health surveillance for uncommon diseases as part
of a medical partnership that keeps zoonotic research safe for the scientists
and the community.
Sociology students study rural communities and challenges they face

Matthew Sanderson, associate professor of sociology, asks his rural sociology
students on the first day of class, "What in rural Kansas is worth saving?" Some
say their families or their farms. The majority are silent. Rural communities
are facing challenges such as decline of small businesses and loss of young
people to more urban areas. Sanderson teaches the rural sociology class every
fall semester, and each year more students say they do not plan to return to the
rural towns in which they lived.
Manhattan Experimental Theater Workshop is subject of documentary

In 1989, Jim Hamilton's son and daughter asked if he would teach a directing
class. The K-State philosophy professor stepped up to the challenge and created
the five-week Manhattan Experimental Theater Workshop (MXTW), held every summer
at the Manhattan Arts Center. Twenty-five years later, the workshop is so
successful it recently became the subject of a documentary, "Dreaming in Flames:
Theater."
Military Partnership

Kansas State University and U. S. Army Fort Riley renewed their partnership for
the fourth year in 2013. This agreement strengthens the ties that military
students have to civilian life and makes K-State one of the most military
inclusive universities in the country. The partnership advocates a
"whole-of-university" approach with nine specific categories: connection and
stewardship of military alumni, military student success, outreach programs,
cultural events, athletics and arts programs, military community relations,
scholarship, military research, and support for faculty and teaching staff.
K-State and Wichita Downtown Development Corporation collaborate to revitalize
city center

Wichita Downtown Development Corporation (WDDC) approached a group of Kansas
State College of Architecture, Planning and Design students about revitalizing
key parts of their city center. These "catalyst sites" are publicly owned and
the city believed that their redevelopment could attract more people and
businesses to the area.
Earthworms Across Kansas

There are 170 species of earthworms in North America, but very little
information on where each species can be found. Invasive species have taken over
the natural environment of some native worms. Human development has forced worms
to move or adapt to living along sidewalks and in yards. The data was incomplete
and general at best.
Beach Museum of Art promotes early childhood art education

Art SmartTen years ago, the Marianna Kistler Beach Museum of Art received a
grant from the Kansas Art Commission to promote early childhood art education.
This allowed them to consolidate the few classes they had under a new
initiative: ArtSmart!, a program dedicated to teaching children about the
composition and making of art. Classes are held weekly during the summer and
during school breaks. According to Kathrine Schlageck, senior educator at the
museum, the groups maintain a stable base of returning students.

Students collaborate with state environmental agency to reduce soil nitrates

Kansas State University Department of Agronomy and Department of Geology
students are working together with the Kansas Department of Health and
Environment (KDHE) to clean up a plot of land contaminated by nitrates in Sylvan
Grove, Kan. This two-acre plot of land has been tested and monitored by two
classes of Kansas State University students since 2011.
Welcome our fall 2013 interns

This fall we welcome our five interns, Haley Acker, social media; Jennifer
Butler, Rural Grocery project coordinator; Logan Falletti, writing and research;
Jared Wasinger, media; and Katy Weidner, events.

K-State

with the Institute for Community and Economic Development, University of North

Please join Dr. Clayton in Town Hall of the Leadership Studies Building to

Eureka! Town + gown = fresh ideas for Kansas communities

Todd Gabbard, an associate professor of architecture, invited local development
groups to collaborate with his students, all Kansas State University Master of

their communities.  The idea sparked interest among several communities,

                         Telegraph Herald (Dubuque, IA)

                           August 29, 2012 Wednesday

Official: Smart Code a key to sustainable communities

BYLINE: BEN JACOBSON TH staff writer ben.jacobson@wcinet.com

SECTION: A; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 409 words


Dubuque County's first Rural Model Smart Code could provide a blueprint for
sustainable communities, according to Zoning Administrator Anna O'Shea. County
planning and zoning officials, along with representatives from "pilot
communities" Bankston, Durango and Sageville, spent the summer developing the
code. It suggests ordinance changes that promote positive, long-term growth
practices.

"It just gives you some ideas of things you can do for sustainability," O'Shea
told the Dubuque County Board of Supervisors in a work session Monday. The
project was funded by a $30,000 Community Development Block Grant. The pilot
communities met demographic eligibility requirements for the grant, making them
ideal subjects for the process, O'Shea said. A technical committee was formed
with representatives from each of the cities, along with county zoning and
planning officials. Over the past several months, committee members learned
about planning techniques, practices and terms from experts and discussed ways
smart growth principles could be implemented locally. "The code is kind of a
conglomeration of all the meetings we had and the discussions we had," O'Shea
said. The code's implementation plan defines it as a "hybrid, form-based zoning
code," meaning that if adopted, the physical form and appearance of an
environment would be highly valued, whereas traditional zoning rules are more
concerned with a separation of uses. Public input played an important role
throughout the process as well, O'Shea said. Questions and comments gathered
through two public meetings and other interactions with community members helped
shape specific aspects of the code. "We received good input," O'Shea said. "A
lot of questions, usually. "¦ We tried to answer their questions and amend some
of the ordinances to reflect some of their concerns." As it is outlined, the
Rural Model Smart Code will likely never be fully adopted due to the
complexities of having to be adjusted for every zoning situation. But O'Shea
said it could serve as a template for development or to launch future
sustainability initiatives. "If we want to use it, we can, but we have to
recalibrate it for a specific area," she said. Though grant stipulations require
that the code be approved by all three pilot communities and the county
supervisors, O'Shea indicated that work on sustainability initiatives will
continue. "We're not really sure how the final product will end up," she said.

                         Deming Headlight (New Mexico)

                            March 21, 2012 Wednesday

USDA seeks apps to spur job creation, economic growth

BYLINE: For the Headlight

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 600 words


WASHINGTON, DC - Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack announced that USDA is
seeking applications for grants to help rural businesses create jobs and spur
economic development.

"This funding is part of the Obama administration's commitment to using existing
federal resources to foster regional innovation, create sustainable jobs and
help ensure long-term prosperity," Vilsack said. "The funding will speed up job
creation and new business start-ups and expansions by building regional economic
systems in rural areas."

USDA Rural Development plans to award up to $8.6 million through the Rural
Community Development Initiative program. Applications are sought for projects
that:

Provide technical assistance to improve the capacity of local organizations to
complete successful housing, economic development and community facilities
projects;

Help recipients complete pre-development requirements - such as architectural
and engineering plans;

Help development organizations improve their board operations, management and
knowledge of financial and information technology systems;

Provide homeownership education or training for entrepreneurs.

When told of the availability of this funding, USDA Rural Development State
Director Terry Brunner said, "In these challenging times, when America is facing
tough competition from around the globe, we need to up our game. And that is why
USDA is providing this type of funding which in the long run will create jobs
and revitalize New Mexico's economy."

Part of the RCDI funds to be awarded may be used for projects associated with
the Rural Jobs and Innovation Accelerator Challenge, which was announced on
March 8, 2012. This initiative was designed by the Taskforce for the Advancement
of Regional Innovation Clusters and the White House Rural Council. Secretary
Vilsack chairs the Council. The Jobs Accelerator is being funded by USDA, the
U.S. Department of Commerce's Economic Development Administration, the Delta
Regional Authority and the Appalachian Regional Commission.

The deadline for submitting RCDI applications is May 9, 2012. Applications must
be submitted to the USDA Rural Development state office where the applicant's
headquarters are located. A list of these offices is available on the USDA Rural
Development website. For more information, see the March 21 Federal Register.

The deadline to apply for RCDI funding for Rural Jobs and Innovation Accelerator
projects is May 9, 2012. For more information on how to apply, please visit
Grants.gov. Applications for Jobs Accelerator projects must be submitted to both
USDA and the EDA.

Since taking office, President Obama's Administration has taken historic steps
to improve the lives of rural Americans, put people back to work and build
thriving economies in rural communities. From proposing the American Jobs Act to
establishing the first-ever White House Rural Council -chaired by Agriculture
Secretary Tom Vilsack - the President wants the federal government to be the
best possible partner for rural businesses and entrepreneurs and for people who
want to live, work and raise their families in rural communities.

USDA, through its Rural Development mission area, administers and manages
housing, business and community infrastructure and facility programs through a
national network of state and local offices.

Rural Development has an active portfolio of more than $165 billion in
affordable loans and loan guarantees.

These programs are designed to improve the economic stability of rural
communities, businesses, residents, farmers and ranchers and improve the quality
of life in rural America.

LOAD-DATE: March 21, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: This funding is part of the Obama administration's commitment to using
existing federal resources to foster regional innovation, create sustainable
jobs and help ensure long-term prosperity. Secretary Tom Vilsack, US Dept. of

                             239 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


            Colorado Springs Business Journal (Colorado Springs, CO)

                                November 3, 2006

LENGTH: 916  words


Time Warner Telecom acquires Xspedius Time Warner Telecom has completed a deal
to acquire Xspedius Communications, which has a sales office in Colorado Springs
with 10 employees. The acquisition is not expected to affect the number of local
sales jobs. Xspedius is a privately held company which provides
telecommunications services to businesses across the United States. Under the
terms of the agreement, Time Warner Telecom will purchase Xspedius for $531.5
million, which includes $212.5 million in cash and $319 million in shares of
Time Warner Telecom's Class A Common Stock. The company will assume no debt in
the acquisition. Xspedius provides ethernet, local and long distance voice, data
and dedicated Internet access services to 43 markets in 18 states. The
acquisition increases Time Warner Telecom's service reach to 75 markets.

Nominations sought for small business advocate The National Small Business
Association is seeking nominations for its 2007 Small Business Advocate of the
Year. Applicants must demonstrate a commitment to small business advocacy, a
proven history of voluntary efforts and endeavors to advance small business and
improve the conditions for small business owners, success and growth as a small
business owner and any other accomplishments demonstrating merit as an effective
advocate for small business interests. Applicants also must be small business
owners and are permitted to nominate themselves. An application form is
available at nsba.biz/award. The deadline to apply is Nov. 17. Send nominations
to Rob Yunich, Small Business Advocate of the Year Award, National Small
Business Association, 1156 15th St. NW, Suite 1100, Washington, D.C. 20005-1755.

Barnstorm acquires Diamond Graphic Source Barnstorm Creative has acquired
Diamond Graphic Source of Florissant and will take over service of the company's
existing client base. Barnstorm also has received three international and one
national industry awards recognizing corporate identity and branding for its
work with ERA Shields.

SBA launches new markets lending initiative The U.S. Small Business
Administration has launched a pilot program to provide financial assistance to
small business in economically distressed urban and rural areas, or "new
markets," that need the economic attention to get communities back on their
feet. The initiative provides incentives for commercial lenders and local
development organizations to make more SBA-guaranteed loans in these
communities. The New Markets Lending Initiative will help small businesses by
enabling Community Development Entities to combine the benefits of the New
Markets Tax Credit Program and SBA-guaranteed loans to provide inner-city and
rural small business owners and entrepreneurs greater access to financing and
business training. The program permits investors to receive credits on their
federal taxes of up to 39 percent of investments made in Community Development
Entities and waives a regulation that limits an SBA lenders ability to sell any
portion of an SBA guaranteed loan to anyone other and an SBA lender. The waiver
allows CDEs with New Market Tax Credit allocations to purchase up to 90 percent
of SBA Express or Community Express 7(a) loans up to $150,000 made to NMTC
"qualified" businesses in low-income communities.

Casino revenue rises in September Colorado casinos produced $69.7 million in
adjusted gross proceeds (AGP) in September, a 1.5 percent increase from $68.7
million in AGP in August and a 9.6 percent increase from $63.6 million a year
earlier. AGP is most simply defined as the amount wagered by bettors less
payouts from casinos. Black Hawk's 21 casinos generated $48.6 million, up from
48.1 million in August and $44.6 million in September 2005. Cripple Creek's 19
casinos totaled $14 million, higher than $13.4 million in August and $13.3
million the previous September. Central City's seven casinos earned $7 million,
down from $7.1 million the previous month, but up 24.7 percent from $5.6 million
in September 2005. Casinos statewide paid $8.3 million in gaming taxes in
September, up from $5.9 million in August.

Applications for drought assistance being taken The Colorado Department of
Agriculture is accepting grant applications through Nov. 17 for drought
assistance in 24 eastern Colorado counties. Cattle and sheep producers in Baca,
Bent, Cheyenne, Crowely, Custer, Elbert El Paso, Fremont, Huerfano, Kiowa, Kit
Carson, Larimer, Las Animas, Lincoln, Logan, Morgan, Otero, Philips, Prowers,
Pueblo, Sedgwick, Washington, Weld and Yuma counties are eligible. To qualify,
owners of foundation breeding herds of cattle and sheep must be able to
demonstrate drought-incurred expenses, such as costs of hauling water, acquiring
additional pasture, purchase of hay or other forage, etc. No more than $10,000
will be awarded to any eligible herd owner. Foundation herds consist of breeding
and replacement cows and bulls, ewes and rams. Foundation breeding herds do not
include cattle under the age of 2 and sheep under the age of 1. To apply,
livestock owners should visit www.ag.state.co.us and go to the Livestock
Assistance Grants page to download the application forms, which also are
available at USDA Farm Services Agency offices and Colorado State University
Cooperative Extension offices. Completed forms should be mailed to the Colorado
Department of Agriculture, Livestock Assistance Grant Program, 700 Kipling St.,
Suite 4000, Lakewood, CO 80215. For more information, call (303) 239-4187.

                         Telegraph Herald (Dubuque, IA)

                              July 8, 2014 Tuesday

ECIA receives grant for training institute

BYLINE: Telegraph Herald

SECTION: A; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 150 words


East Central Intergovernmental Association has received a $150,000 grant to
establish a government training institute.

The United States Department of Agriculture, through its Rural Community
Development Initiative program, awarded the grant, according to a news release.

This project is the result of the expressed interest of low-income rural
government leaders and economic development organizations in the ECIA region -
Clinton, Cedar, Delaware, Dubuque, Jackson and Jones counties.

The institute will be comprised of four modules - group trainings, one-on-one
training, idea-sharing meetings and a data dashboard. Each entails a different
form of technical assistance, but all focus on improving the capacity of
low-income rural government leaders and economic development organizations so
they can adequately use available resources to improve the quality of life for
residents and business leaders.

                                 Crewe Guardian

                            December 16, 2007 Sunday

Cash is on offer to help fund youth projects

BYLINE: Staff reporter

SECTION: LATEST NEWS (CREWE NEWS)

LENGTH: 234 words


A £20,000 Christmas windfall is up for grabs to organisations working with young
people in rural areas of Nantwich.

The Rural Youth Grant aims to develop projects that bring long-term benefits to
those aged between 10 and 18.

Clubs, voluntary youth groups and charities can apply for up to £5,000 under the
scheme, funded by Rural Enterprise.

Gaynor Bowen-Jones, Cheshire County Council's Rural Development Officer, who is
administering the grant for Rural Enterprise, said dozens of projects had
already benefited from grant support.

She urged groups to act quickly before the funding deadline runs out in January.

"The projects we've supported are a striking example of what can be achieved
through community development and the commitment of our young people," she said.

Schemes that have already benefited from funding support include a skate park, a
youth brass band, and a youth centre.

Nicola Lavin, Programme Director of Rural Enterprise, said grant applications
should show good value for money and preferably sustainable benefits for young
people.

"The successful bids will involve initiatives which benefit a wide range of
young people or a group of young people," she added.

For an application form, please contact Gaynor Bowen-Jones, Cheshire County
Council Rural Development Officer, Room 268 County Hall, Riverside, Chester. CH1
1SF. Telephone 01244 603373 or Email: gaynor.bowen-jones@cheshire.gov.uk

                                US Official News

                           August 14, 2013 Wednesday

Utah: USDA Seeks Applications for Grants to Create Jobs, Economic Opportunity in
Rural Areas

LENGTH: 233  words

DATELINE: Salt Lake City


Department of Agriculture, The State of Utah has issued the following news
release:

Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack announced today that the U.S. Department of
Agriculture (USDA) is seeking applications for grants that will be awarded to
organizations to help rural businesses create jobs and spur economic
development. USDA is making $5.6 million available through the Rural Community
Development Initiative (RCDI), a program that generates economic activity in
rural areas.

"This funding will help local and regional organizations as they assist small
and emerging businesses," Vilsack said. "The Obama Administration recognizes
small businesses as the engines of job creation and essential to strengthening
our national economy."

Strengthening the rural economy remains a main focus of USDA, despite budget
uncertainties. Qualified intermediary organizations receiving the grants will
provide financial and technical assistance to recipients to develop their
capacity to undertake housing, community facilities, or community and economic
development projects. Recipients will be non-profit organizations, low income
rural communities, or federally recognized tribes. Intermediary organizations
must provide matching funds at least equal to the RCDI grant. Funds are not
directly provided to business recipients by USDA under the program.

For further information please visit: http://www.usda.gov/

                                 June 20, 2001

Rural cash boost

SECTION: News:People:Issues, Pg.4

LENGTH: 191 words


ORGANISATIONS in North Lincolnshire in need of cash for community development
projects in rural areas could be in luck.

The Carnegie UK Trust has announced it has more than GBP 1-million pounds up for
grabs over the next five years.

It is looking to award grants of up to GBP 10,000 for imaginative schemes and
groundbreaking ideas which will energise and revitalise villages and rural
communities.

A spokesman said: "They could be anything from setting up a business, to
marketing local produce to establishing a cybervillage.

"The new initiative is the result of the Trust's five-yearly review of its
activities."

It has also announced a second grant scheme for creative ideas from small
organisations at their early stage.

He said: "This particularly aims to target ideas which cross traditional
boundaries between the arts, environment, science available to widen the use of
village halls serving populations below 5,000 as centres of services for the
community."

Further details are available from Carnegie United Kingdom Trust, Comely Park
House, Dunfermline, Fife KYI2 7EJ or phone (01383) 721445 or website

www.carnegieuktrust.org.uk

                  The State Journal-Register (Springfield, IL)

                              June 3, 2007 Sunday

State looks to help increase coverage

BYLINE: JEREMY PELZER State Capitol Bureau

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 846 words


Many broadband deployment advocates, such as Lt. Gov. Pat Quinn, think it's up
to the state of Illinois to ensure every Illinois resident has access to
affordable high-speed Internet.

Quinn heads the Broadband Deployment Council, which gives grants to extend
broadband networks and seeks to find ways to extend high-speed service to
unserved areas of the state.

"Our basic theme is everybody in, nobody out," Quinn said recently. "I really
feel we need to have that."

The state's most significant foray into extending rural broadband networks is
the Vince Demuzio Rural Broadband Initiative, a $1 million pilot project
designed to extend high-speed Internet to underserved areas of Macoupin and
Montgomery counties.

Carolyn Brown Hodge, director of rural affairs for Quinn, said initial surveys
have shown  broadband access is more widespread in the two counties than
anticipated. As a result, the initiative - named after the late state senator
from Carlinville - will instead be redirected to ramp up Internet speeds for
businesses.

Nora Feuquay, economic development coordinator for Macoupin County, said the
initiative will help both to keep tech jobs in the area and to lure in new
businesses.

"When (businesses) are looking at our county, we have a lot to offer as far as
cheaper labor and better taxes and things like that," she said. "However, if we
don't have the broadband ability that they need, that can sway them to stay in a
more urban area."

Hodge said Quinn's office is also considering a plan to require the Illinois
Department of Transportation to install high-speed fiber optic cables underneath
any stretch of new road IDOT builds.

Quinn is trying to expand on the Broadband Deployment Council by creating a new
non-profit organization called ConnectIL. ConnectIL would control broadband
grant money, be responsible for determining which areas of the state don't have
broadband service, and try to extend service to all Illinois residents.

One state that has invested millions in public money to construct rural
broadband networks - with promising results - is Virginia.

In recent years, rural areas of southern and southwestern Virginia have lost
jobs as coal, tobacco, furniture and textile industries have either declined or
moved overseas.

The state's response has been to make those areas meccas for high-tech jobs by
sinking millions of dollars into providing high-speed fiber optic cable to these
areas, said Todd Christenson, deputy director of community development for the
Virginia Department of Housing and Economic Opportunity.

The state has already extended high-speed Internet to several rural counties,
Christenson said. Two dozen more counties are drawing up broadband deployment
plans of their own.

The investment has immediately started to pay off, Christenson said.

About a year and a half ago, the state ran fiber optic Internet service to
Lebanon, a town of about 3,000 in what Christenson called one of the most
economically distressed areas of the state. Since then, two research and
technology companies, CGI and Northrup Grumman, decided to open offices there,
creating about 700 jobs.

"These are software programmers and software engineers - not call-center jobs,"
Christenson said.  "These are $50,000-a-year jobs."

"But without this community having this fiber (optic cable)," he said, "they
wouldn't have any chance in the world of having Northrup Grumman coming
through."

But simply using state money to blanket rural areas with fiber optic cable
networks isn't a solution by itself, said Ed Feser of the University of Illinois
at Urbana-Champaign.

"Some states have ... just dropped fiber everywhere - every time there's a road
built, every time they're running fiber," Feser said.

It's important to let rural areas find local solutions, he said. Some
communities have done so by creating municipal Internet providers, he said. Even
the threat of a municipal broadband service has been enough for telecom
companies to extend service to some communities.

Public advocates and private broadband companies don't have to be at odds.

In the southernmost 20 counties in Illinois, business and political figures have
banded together with Internet providers to create ConnectSI, a non-profit
Internet cooperative.

Only about 12 percent of southern Illinoisans have broadband service.
ConnectSI's goal is to increase that usage rate to 54 percent by 2012, Duncan
said.

To achieve this, Southern Illinois residents who want broadband access can send
requests to ConnectSI, Duncan said. ConnectSI determines whether the requesters
already have broadband access. If not, ConnectSI passes those requests on to
local broadband companies, which figure out whether they can extend service to
those areas, he said.

The result is a win-win situation, Duncan said. Many homes and businesses now
have broadband access for the first time, and Internet providers have more
paying customers.

"More people using more bandwidth drives more return on network provider
investment," he said. "And that will cause more infrastructure expansion."

                                US Official News

                            March 25, 2017 Saturday

Washington: Reps. Bustos, Yarmuth, Peterson & O'Halleran Warn Against Impact of
Trump's Budget Cuts on Working Families, Rural America

LENGTH: 588  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: Office of the MP Collin Peterson has issued the following news
release:



 Congresswoman Cheri Bustos of Illinois, Co-Chair of the Democratic Policy &
Communications Committee, Congressman John Yarmuth, Ranking Member on the Budget
Committee,  Congressman Collin Peterson, Ranking Member on the Agriculture
Committee, and Congressman Tom O'Halleran of Arizona today held a press
conference highlighting the devastating impact President Trump's FY2018 budget
blueprint would have on hard-working American families, especially those living
in rural America.





 The blueprint calls for a 21 percent cut to the U.S. Department of Agriculture
(USDA), which administers important programs and services to Americans in rural
areas. The budget also calls for eliminating the water and wastewater loan and
grant program, the TIGER grant program, Essential Air Service program, Rural
Business Cooperative Service, the Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program
(LIHEAP),  and Community Development Block Grants, which states use to pay for
Meals on Wheels, and other initiatives that provide jobs and services for
working families. Reps. Bustos, Peterson and O'Halleran all represent largely
rural districts, which were carried by Donald Trump in the 2016 election.



 "Every weekend, when I go to grocery stores across my district, more and more
moms and dads are asking me what the heck is going on with President Trump
breaking his promises," said Congresswoman Cheri Bustos. "When it comes to rural
America, there is no clearer example of President Trump breaking his promise
than the budget he released yesterday. President Trump likes to call this an
'America First' budget, but when you dig into the details, he's making a
deliberate choice to damage our rural economy by eliminating programs that have
created thousands of jobs in small towns, ending critical infrastructure
investments in rural communities and making it harder for our growers and
producers to sell their crops."



 "The Trump budget is not only irresponsible and cold-hearted, it's ignorant to
the needs and priorities of American families," said Congressman John Yarmuth.
"President Trump promised to create jobs and make Americans safer. Yet his
budget cuts education, transportation, resources that protect public health and
our environment, and diplomatic initiatives that keep our country safe. This
budget is called "America First" but it's the last thing American families can
afford."



 "Rural America provides a tremendous service to this country but I don't think
the Administration understands that," said Congressman Collin Peterson. "The
budget cuts programs that help our smaller communities be able to update their
water systems and farmers navigate farm programs. These programs support rural
areas, which support agriculture, which allows us to have cheap, safe and
dependable food. I'm not sure this is going any place but I have concerns about
what this means for the future farm and rural policy."



 "The reality is our tribal communities face anywhere from 50 to 80 percent
unemployment, wages are lower in rural America, and the types of programs that
are being cut in this proposal would have a devastating impact on our tribal
lands and rural areas," said Congressman O'Halleran. "Rural Americans are tough.
They have always given back to our country, and they deserve fairness and
respect. What we see in this budget proposal is not fairness and respect, but
rather, a complete disregard for the challenges our rural communities face."

LOAD-DATE: March 26, 2017

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                           Cape Argus (South Africa)

                           September 17, 2010 Friday
                                   E2 Edition

Community Chest facing a cash crisis;
Poor and the elderly set to suffer

BYLINE:  ESTHER LEWIS Staff Reporter

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 607 words


THE Community Chest has called an emergency meeting with its beneficiaries to
warn them of an expected R7 million cut in grants next year.

They were told they needed to start making contingency plans.

The organisation provides funding to 487 recipients, with grants ranging from
R18 000 to R1m a year, according to Community Chest chief executive Amelia
Jones.

Last year it paid R16m to beneficiaries but expects this figure to drop to R9m
in the 2011/12 financial year.

"How we are going to cut the cake will be our big challenge," a concerned Jones
disclosed after yesterday's meeting.

Some of the organisations that receive funding cater to the elderly, homeless
and physically and mentally disabled. The Community Chest also supports
rehabilitation and community development projects.

Danie Digue, financial manager of the Helderberg Society for the Aged, said that
without Community Chest funding the poor would suffer most.

The society runs two old-age homes and Digue said 50 percent of residents were
unable to pay.

It also owns nine blocks of flats, three of which are occupied by pensioners who
pay only R450 to R500 a month in rent.

The society runs community outreach programmes in Lwandle, Nomzamo, Garden
Village and Chris Nissen Park where the elderly and disabled are taught various
skills to encourage economic independence.

Digue said each of the components was running at an enormous loss.

If funding was lost, the outreach programmes would have to be closed down.

He said they had approached the private sector for financial help but without
very much success,

"Today old people are not a favourite. People just don't care about the aged any
more."

Hassan Khan, chief executive of the Haven Night Shelter Welfare Organisation,
said the Community Chest was an integral part of its operations.

Every month 13 of its shelters were granted R2 500 each. The Ceres and Swartland
shelters, in particular, would be in serious trouble if they lost the grant.

He added, however, that they would have to relook at how much they leaned on the
Community Chest for funding, and to see where they could cut back.

Khan said that there were beneficiaries - especially in the rural areas - that
were completely dependent on their Community Chest grants.

All the bigger, more mature organisations had the responsibility to ensure they
checked out all possibilities for funding so that they did not take away from
beneficiaries in the rural areas.

Jones confirmed that many of the beneficiaries operated from hand to mouth and,
in some cases, their operating grants were what enabled them to keep their doors
open.

The future of these places was now in jeopardy.

Jones explained that the Community Chest had seen a 50 percent decrease in
corporate and individual donations this year.

The Community Chest was largely funded by the private sector, and family trusts
and legacies.

These donations were dependent on investments, and returns had been low because
of the recession, Jones explained.

Another source of income was the Pay As You Earn initiative.

Those who donated in this way were mostly factory workers and people from other
low-income groups.

Few high-level earners were involved in this initiative.

Fanzu Badenhorst, who works for Shape, a service provider to the Department of
Social Development, also attended the meeting.

He said the onus was now on organisations to intensify fundraising efforts, but
admitted it would be difficult in small, poorer towns.

His company would help organisations apply to other sources for funding.

"For the current year they will be okay. But 2011/12 is probably going to be a
very |difficult financial year," Badenhorst said.

Community Chest Almost Empty

BYLINE: Esther Lewis

LENGTH: 607  words


The Community Chest has called an emergency meeting with its beneficiaries to

They were told they needed to start making contingency plans.

                         Telegraph Herald (Dubuque, IA)

                           February 10, 2015 Tuesday

Pilot program strives to boost area's vitality

BYLINE: TH Media

SECTION: A; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 156 words


Monticello will serve as a pilot community for a program aimed at connecting
philanthropic giving and community leadership to increase civic engagement and
strategic planning.

Community Foundation of Greater Dubuque recently received a two-year, $100,000
grant from Orton Family Foundation to implement its community engagement process
in the six-county rural affiliate region, beginning with Monticello.

The community foundation will match the Orton grant with a $150,000 grant from
the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Rural Community Development Initiative to
grow philanthropy in Allamakee, Jackson, Jones, Clayton and Delaware Counties in
Iowa and Jo Daviess County in Illinois.

Orton has invested $10 million over the past five years to test its Heart and
Soul method in nine towns with the goal of developing a better way to help small
communities identify new leaders and strengthen community values and social and
economic vitality.

               The Times and Democrat, Orangeburg, South Carolina

                            January 22, 2006, Sunday

Claflin University hosts economic summit targeting African-American community

BYLINE: By Dionne Gleaton

LENGTH: 1666 words



Education leads to employment and employment leads to economic empowerment.

This was the thread of commonality which was woven through several presentations
given to a host of concerned citizens and legislative, church, education and
community leaders gathered at Claflin University on Saturday.

Claflin, in collaboration with the South Carolina Conference of the NAACP and
the S.C. Legislative Black Caucus, hosted the first statewide African-American
Economic Summit, which was designed to close the gap in disparities with which
African-American grapple within the state's educational, employment and economic
arenas.

"Today we are here as partners who share a common interest in the viability and
welfare of the African-American community. I'm excited ... about the outcome of
this conference," Claflin President Dr. Henry N. Tisdale said during the opening
session, which was quickly followed by a panel of experts who discussed how to
forge enhanced economic development in the black community.

Tisdale highlighted a few of the initiatives the university has implemented to
educate its students and prepare them for a global economy which is increasingly
being marked by "digitization, virtualization and automation."

The university is home to a nationally accredited School of Education; an
innovative "Call Me Mister" program which now boasts 60 young black men in the
program designed to recruit, train, certify and secure employment for
African-American men as teachers in the state's public elementary schools; a
burgeoning Center for Entrepreneurial Development; and an S.C. Center for
Biotechnology and a partnership with the University of South Carolina in a
five-year, $ .75 million grant from the National Institutes of Health to tackle
HIV/AIDS and cancer issues in the community.

Economic Development Maceo Nance III, director of community and rural
development at the S.C. Department of Commerce, outlined that there was more
than $ 2.6 billion invested in the state in 2005. There were 12,000 new jobs
created, 43 percent of which stemmed from new investments.

While the department's mission is to improve the per capita income of all South
Carolinians for an enhanced quality of life, he said supporting the growth and
viability of small businesses is key in boosting economic development in the
black community.

To that end, the department has set up a website for aspiring business owners to
use at business one-stop centers across the state, and for the last two years
has also grown as Capital Access Program, for which funding is being sought this
year.

The department's Community Development Block Grant program has also awarded $
27.8 million in grants to distressed communities, and its Workforce Investment
Act Program has also reached a little more than 5,000 state cities with its
job-building initiatives.

"You have to have something on the shelf for companies to look for," he said,
noting that product development is another facet on which the department is
working on through, for example, its Speculative Building Program now being
implemented in 15 different counties.

"Of all companies, 70 to 80 percent of them end up first looking for available
building space in which to locate," he said. He also noted that the department's
opportunity grants have also provided for the development of Magic Johnson
Centers in Orangeburg and four other counties to give students after-school
programs for children in kindergarten through 12th grade.

He said there needs to be improvement in individuals' obtainment of a bachelor's
degree or higher, or else they're "doomed to failure" in today's globalized
economy.

"We want to improve education and workforce skills," he said.

Panelist Dr. Lucy Reuben, finance professor at North Carolina Central
University, said, "It is important to have businesses that can support jobs,
hiring and community development," Dr. Leroy Davis, executive director of the
Center of Excellence and Rural and Minority Health at Voorhees College, said
historically black colleges and universities are vital "depositories of
intellectual capital," but there are still gaps to be addressed.

With black males representing only 9.7 percent of enrolled undergraduate
students in the fall of 2004, they are increasingly becoming an "endangered
species" in the post-secondary educational arena. He also noted that
African-American faculty represented only 10 percent of the total pool of white
faculty in South Carolina (540 to 5,961).

"There are more areas where we need to work," he said, with still more blacks
not completing high school or college at all.

While statistics showed that more than 60 percent of African-American children
do not graduate from high school in South Carolina, Davis noted that fair and
equitable state funding, small endowments and deferred maintenance of facilities
among the challenges state which HBCUs currently face and need addressing.

Traci Young Cooper, assistant principal Alcorn Middle School in Columbia, was
one of three panelists discussing factors impacting the success rate among black
students in the classroom.

She said while "exterior issues" like school funding, teacher quality and early
childhood education need to be addressed, an even greater focus needs to be
placed on what's going on in the classroom.

She said the state Department of Education has worked to implement curriculum
calibration in schools statewide over the past four years, providing funding in
approximately 751 schools to institute the collection and analysis of student
work to measure the percentage of alignment of assignments to grade level state
standards.

She said African-American students are disproportionately not being taught at
grade level and, consequently, often can't make the grade on standardized tests
as the Palmetto Challenge Achievement Test.

"This leads to high rates of high school drop outs for African-American children
and an increased truancy rate when they don't feel like they're being taught, or
they farther and farther behind," said Cooper, noting that the educational
system must be revamped so that the organization, rigor and progression of the
state content standards are being properly taught.

"This is not an indictment on teachers in South Carolina. The state just needs
to make sure that teachers get the resources and support they need for children
to become effective and productive leaders. There is a direct correlation. It
does have a serious impact on the overall economic climate," she said.

James M. Daniels, research and planning administrator in the Labor Market
Information Department at the S.C. Employment Security Commission, was one of
three panelists to discuss employment. He specifically gave an overview of
unemployment by race and gender.

In December 2005, the national unemployment rate stood at 4.9 percent.

While the white unemployment rate stood at 4.3 percent, the rate for blacks
stood at 9.3 percent. Davis noted that the unemployment rate for blacks age 16
to 19 was a whopping 24. 4 percent.

For 2004, the state annual average unemployment rate was 6.9 percent.

The unemployment rates for whites was 5.6 percent, with the rate for blacks
nearly double that at 10.2 percent. The unemployment rate for black females and
males age 20 to 24 stood at 22. 5 percent.

"These are just a few statistics. They're attached to income to make people more
aware and informed as far as trying to discuss solutions," he said, noting the
per capita income for whites in the state was $ 22,095, compared to $ 11,776 for
blacks.

Orangeburg County ranked 13th among the counties with the largest disparities in
per capita income by race, with the disparity between blacks and whites standing
at around $ 10,000.

Like Nance, Daniels touted the empowerment and strengthening of African-American
businesses, particularly small businesses. He said more work needs to be done in
recruiting African-American businesses, particularly to economically depressed
areas, many of which are in Lowcountry counties such as Beaufort.

He said successful recruitment models which have already been implemented in the
Raleigh-Durham and Greensboro areas of North Carolina to bring "economic relief"
to distressed areas need to be studied and applied.

Sen. John Matthews, D-Bowman, is also a member of the S.C. Legislative Black
Caucus. He said the task forces which would come together at the end of the
summit to discuss solutions in the economic, educational and employment areas
would continue their work beyond Saturday.

"We're not talking about meeting for a day. It has to be continual, and they'll
have to meet on a quarterly basis to find new ways to engage the black community
and provide leadership in the process," Matthews said.

"We want to come up with a comprehensive proposal to engage the black community.
It's all about self-reliance and self-responsibility."

Orangeburg NAACP President William Wilson said the summit was timely and
necessary.

"We have got to get about the business of economic development in our community.
As we've heard today, African-Americans have buying power in South Carolina, but
we don't have economic wealth. It is essential that we start putting wealth back
into our communities," Wilson said.

"We have got to start businesses, get our colleges and universities
concentrating on curriculums other than the traditional ones so that we can
compete in global markets. I'm very elated about this summit and what will come
after it," he said.

                                US Official News

                             April 4, 2015 Saturday

UGA awarded USDA grant to study Georgia's community revitalization needs

LENGTH: 603  words

DATELINE: Athens


The University of Georgia has issued the following news release:

An increased understanding of the housing and neighborhood revitalization issues
facing Georgia's rural and small-town communities will help researchers at the
University of Georgia address needs in these communities.

Led by the College of Family and Consumer Sciences' Kim Skobba, an assistant
professor of financial planning, housing and consumer economics, UGA is using a
five-year, $474,998 grant from the U.S. Department of Agriculture to conduct the
research. The research team will be assessing housing and neighborhood
challenges and collecting community-level social capital data for 353 small and
nonmetropolitan municipalities in Georgia.

This Agriculture and Food Research Initiative grant was awarded through the
National Institute of Food and Agriculture, which supports projects that sustain
and enhance agriculture and related activities in rural areas and protect the
environment, enhance quality of life and alleviate poverty.

"We're looking at how these communities use social networks and social capital
to bring about change related to housing and neighborhood revitalization,"
Skobba said.

Researchers will use communities selected from the Georgia Initiative for
Community Housing as well as small, rural communities not a part of GICH to
compare needs and issues. These comparison communities will help researchers see
whether or not capacity building programs enhance social capital and support.

GICH is a technical assistance program that "helps communities improve their
quality of life and economic validity through the development of locally based
housing and revitalization strategies," said Karen Tinsley, GICH program
coordinator.

The UGA researchers will help develop "the local capacity of these smaller
communities in terms of them being able to improve their economic and community
development," among other things.

The program "helps communities get off the ground and meet their own housing
needs," said Sharon Gibson, a multicultural extension specialist at UGA.

The study will map social networks used to address these housing issues and
other community problems.

Jerry Shannon, a limited-term assistant professor in community geography, is
also working with groups in each community to locate hot spots of housing needs.

"By using spatial analysis and new online mapping tools, these communities will
be able to map out current problems and share housing development plans with a
broad audience," Shannon said.

"This research will inform the development of training materials for extension
agents and community members-the content will focus on helping communities
understand the importance and use of social capital to improve housing stock
while addressing neighborhood revitalization," Gibson said.

"What we hope to learn is how programs like GICH can build networks that might
enhance the ability to solve problems in communities, and what we really hope to
see is whether this is something that can be replicated in other parts of the
state," Skobba said.

Overall, the researchers aim to provide technical assistance, increased public
awareness and policy solutions through the integration of research, education
and extension activities.

The Office of the Vice President for Public Service and Outreach is a financial
sponsor of the Georgia Initiative for Community Housing. Georgia Power Co. is
serving as the founding sponsor of GICH, which allows the program to be provided
to communities at no cost.

                             The Gloucester Citizen

                                 April 22, 2002

Grant to help hi-tech hall

SECTION: NEWS: OTHER, Pg.2

LENGTH: 210 words


A NEW computer and resource centre will be set up at Woodchester after the
village hall received a grant of GBP 3,000.

The money from the Carnegie UK Trust will go towards equipment and installing
additional phone lines.

The grant is part of the trust's long-running programme to widen the use of
village halls as centres of services for the community.

It links with a new million -pound initiative, announced a year ago, to
encourage community development in villages and rural areas.

Since 1991 the trust has already donated almost GBP 1 million to improve
facilities at more than 500 village and community halls in the UK and Ireland.

Secretary John Naylor said: "Village halls are an integral part of rural life
and we are keen to do everything we can to extend their range and enhance the
quality of life for small communities.

"As a result of this concern, we announced a new programme in 2001 to support
imaginative schemes to energise hard-pressed rural areas. We are prepared to
give grants of up to GBP 10,000 each for anything from setting up a child care
centre or surgery to establishing a cybervillage."

The trust, one of Britain's longest -established, was set up by Andrew Carnegie,
the Scottish-American industrialist in 1913.

                            December 13, 2013 Friday

Indiana: Lt. Governor Sue Ellspermann Awards a $29,160 Planning Grant to the
Town of Elizabethtown

LENGTH: 178  words

DATELINE: Indianapolis


Office of Community & Rural Affairs, The State of Indiana has issued the
following news release:

Lt. Governor Sue Ellspermann has awarded a $29,160 planning grant to the town of
Elizabethtown for a storm drainage system study through the state's Office of
Community and Rural Affairs.

"Infrastructure improvements are a key to economic growth, and ensuring
appropriate stormwater drainage is important as the town of Elizabethtown plans
for a prosperous future and growth," said Lt. Governor Ellspermann.

The planning grant for the town of Elizabethtown will be used to evaluate the
existing drainage system and make recommendations for improvements to the
existing structure along with any additional needs.

The funding comes from the Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) program,
which has proven to be an effective tool for community-based planning and
research initiatives. Elizabethtown provided a local match of $3,240.

The CDBG program is administered by the Indiana Office of Community and Rural
Affairs.

For further information please visit: http://www.in.gov/

                               Leicester Mercury

                                 March 24, 2004

Grants aim to help rural areas prosper

BYLINE: A. NDY GILGRIST

SECTION: Business; Economy; Financial; Pg. 24

LENGTH: 361 words


Leicester Shire Economic Partnership (LSEP) will be providing funding of
£355,000 to the projects, which are running across the county.  It is working
with Leicestershire Rural Partnership, which is giving £170,000 over the next 12
months.

LSEP chief executive Kishor Tailor said the awards were the first stage of a
long-term commitment to improving social prosperity and encouraging economic
regeneration in rural areas.

He said the two agencies would be working with Leicestershire and Rutland Rural
Community Council in delivering the support.

The projects to receive funds are: Rural Community Chest: The money will help
the chest make grants to voluntary and community groups in rural areas, to
encourage social and environment improvements, social enterprise and rural
services that benefit the area.

Countryside Retail Support Grant Scheme: The scheme provides small grants to
shops, public houses and garages to help them cover the costs of making
improvements to the businesses and their premises.

Rural Centres: The grant will help finance stage two of the project, which
provides country agency healthchecks in Thurmaston, Broughton Astley, Earl
Shilton and Bottesford, through the implementation of action plans.

Building Capacity in Rural Communities: The money will go to supporting a
network of community development workers, who will assist communities in
evaluating and developing their economies and to build up capacity.

Mr Tailor said: "This is just a small part of our ongoing commitment to
developing our rural economy.

"It will support initiatives that will make a real difference to businesses and
communities." Jeremy Prescott, director of the Rural Community Council for
Leicestershire and Rutland, said: "All these projects will provide greater
capacity and sustainability in supporting rural communities and developing local
solutions to address local needs.

"The aim of the agencies involved in these projects is to allow rural
communities, while retaining the essential nature of the surrounding
countryside, to be as vibrant and inclusive as possible for all those who live
in them."

                      Mt. Vernon Register-News (Illinois)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           September 29, 2008 Monday

Main Street program receives grant

BYLINE: Mt. Vernon Register-News, Ill.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 339 words


Sep. 29--QUINCY -- The Illinois Main Street program has received a $219,800
Rural Community Development Initiative grant from the U.S. Department of
Agriculture, and part of the funds are earmarked for Mt. Vernon.

Due to the grant funding, the expanded program will serve 18 communities across
the state including Mt. Vernon, Beardstown, Benton, Canton, Carbondale, Du
Quoin, Golconda, Hardin County, Hoopeston, Marion, Marshall, Mount Sterling,
Paris, Pittsfield, Quincy, Rossville, Vandalia and Vienna.

According to Downtown Mt. Vernon Development Corporation Executive Director
Cyndy Mitchell, the DMDC has agreed to support the grant and participate in it.
Recipients will be grouped by the four regions in the state, she said.

Conditions of the grant are that the program will receive the $219,800 over the
next three years and Illinois Main Street will contribute $183,950 in matching
funds during the three year period.

Grant funds will be used to expand the Illinois Main Street curriculum to
include dedicated technical assistance and education services to rural
communities. Services will consist of affordable housing workshops and webinars,
small business retailing workshops, energy audits and assessment visits.

Since the Illinois Main Street program began there has been a reinvestment of
more than $575 million in Main Street downtowns, according to information from
Lt. Governor Pat Quinn, who administers the program.

Mt. Vernon was awarded the Illinois Main Street designation in April 2006. There
are more than 62 communities across the state who have met the criteria to be a
Main Street city.

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                    November 13, 1989, Monday, City Edition

N.C. shines with its grassroots self-help projects

BYLINE: Neal R. Peirce

SECTION: EDITORIAL; Columns; Pg. 12A

LENGTH: 737 words



Not many vintage-1920s high schools draw 2,000 to 3,000 alumni from    across
the United States for annual reunions. Nor do many high schools    house
"business incubators" to nurture new enterprises in depressed    rural towns.

     But the old Dillard High School at Goldsboro, in heavily black,    rural
and poor eastern North Carolina, does both. Back in the    pre-integration '50s
and '60s, its students, despairing of a local job,    flocked onto the
northbound Seaboard Coast Line Number 76 train the    moment they had their
diplomas.

     Today those graduates include solid middle-class citizens of such    cities
as Philadelphia, Boston and Washington, D.C. - all of which have    their own
Dillard High alumni chapters. They raise thousands of dollars    a year in
scholarships. And when their old high school was slated for    demolition in
1979, the alumni sold quilts and donuts, held "pig    picking" raffles and
raised enough cash to buy it.

     Five years later, they decided to turn their familiar old    classrooms
into an incubator for fledgling businesses. They turned to    the New York-based
Local Initiatives Support Corp. for technical    assistance. In 1985, they were
turned down for state funding. "People    didn't believe we could do it," says
Geneva Hamilton, an alumna and      prime mover in the project.

     But a year later the state grant came through. Today the incubator
supports 13 businesses ranging from a children's wear manufacturer to    an
accounting firm. "We have the leading nonprofit incubator in the    state. We
have a waiting list of tenants," Hamilton boasts. She even    hopes to see the
old auditorium renovated "just like when we were in    school."

     In George Bush political terms, the Dillard School is one of those
"1,000 points of light." Just down the road in little St. Pauls,    there's
another - students learning to be entrepreneurs by running    their own
business. It's called "The Way-Off Broadway Delicatessen,"    an "authentic" New
York Jewish deli. Catering to vacationers    traveling along nearby Interstate
95, it grosses $ 250,000 a year.

     The St. Pauls school-based business would never have been launched,
however, without REAL (Rural Education through Action Learning), an    affiliate
of the state's Small Business and Technology Development    Center.

     The fact is that precious few "points of light" flicker into life
without a major network of support groups and, more often than not,    some
serious government assistance.

     North Carolina is one state that seems to glimmer with hundreds of
self-start economic-development projects. It has a rich fabric of    co-ops,
credit unions, community-development corporations, nonprofit    housing
producers and land trusts. For rural- and small-town efforts,    it may be the
nation's star.

     The Center for Community Self-Help, headquartered in Durham, plus    the
network provided by Legal Services of North Carolina, educate and    encourage
low-income groups and neighborhoods to get into bootstrap    initiatives. They
specialize in garnering support from foundations,    corporations, banks, and
state government.

     One beneficiary is the Watermark Association of Artisans in    Elizabeth
City. It has 400 members, mostly women, many referred by    churches and
battered women's shelters. Rather than polished crafts,    Watermark trains a
woman how, in one day, she can make a product she    can sell right away. The
project has won funding under the state    government's micro-enterprise
demonstration program.

     Since 1987, the North Carolina Legislature has capitalized a    $
100-million small-business loan and investment pool to be run by a new    Center
for Rural Economic Development. It provides core funding for
community-development corporations and credit unions and has a
micro-enterprise demonstration program. The Center for Community    Self-Help in
Durham received $ 2-million for its development bank.

     With enough government, foundation, corporate backing, self-help    could
become for many states a mainstream anti-poverty strategy of the    '90s.

 Washington Post Writers Group

              North Carolina Community Development Initiative Inc

                              5800 Faringdon Place
                               Raleigh,  NC 27609
                                 United States

* * * * * * * * * * COMMUNICATIONS * * * * * * * * * *
TELEPHONE: (919) 828-5655
URL: www.ncinitiative.org

* * * * * * * * * * COMPANY INFORMATION * * * * * * * * * *

* * * * * * * * * * DESCRIPTION * * * * * * * * * *

   The North Carolina Community Development Initiative is nationally recognized
as a model public-private community economic development intermediary. We are
dedicated to increasing assets and creating wealth for communities and
individuals in low-resource communities. Since our founding in 1994, we have
channeled more than $65 million to local Community Development Corporations,
resulting in more than $358 million of completed local development projects.
Our leadership comes from a Chief Executive Officer and a 21-member Board of
Directors made up of public officials, CDC leaders and representatives from the
private sector. The Chairman of the Board of Directors is Richard M. Taylor, CEO
of the North Carolina Academy of Trial Lawyers.  The Initiative provides annual
core operational grants to 28 established, high-performing CDCs in rural areas,
small towns and major cities across the state. We also provide project lending,
strategic issue management and project development assistance to the CDC
industry statewide. Foundations, government, corporations and others have
invested in the Initiative and, through it, in the future of North Carolina. The
Initiative leverages these investments and appropriations to attract millions of
dollars of additional private sector investment.

Indiana: Lt. Governor Sue Ellspermann Awards a $15,000 Planning Grant to the
Town of Birdseye

LENGTH: 174  words

DATELINE: Indianapolis


Office of Community & Rural Affairs, The State of Indiana has issued the
following news release:

Lt. Governor Sue Ellspermann has awarded a $15,000 planning grant to the town of
Birdseye for a public library feasibility study through the state's Office of
Community and Rural Affairs.

"We are pleased to support the public library feasibility study as the town of
Birdseye continues its efforts to improve quality of life and educational
opportunities for its residents," said Lt. Governor Ellspermann.

The planning grant for the town of Birdseye will assist in determining the most
feasible option for the future of the Birdseye Branch Library of the Dubois
County Contractual Public Library.

The funding comes from the Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) program,
which has proven to be an effective tool for community-based planning and
research initiatives.  Birdseye provided a $3,500 local match.

The CDBG program is administered by the Indiana Office of Community and Rural
Affairs.

For further information please visit: http://www.in.gov/

                                 Morpeth Herald

                           September 1, 2009 Tuesday

New source of rural funding

BYLINE: ANNA SMITH

LENGTH: 288 words



HIGHLIGHT: RURAL projects are being urged to tap into a new Northumberland
funding scheme.


The Northumberland Coast and Lowlands Leader project has a guaranteed £350,000 a
year to distribute to groups to support rural development.

Projects for the wider scheme can be based around the environment, heritage,
tourism, agriculture, forestry and business opportunities, with the local fund
picking out community development, tourism and small businesses as its priority
themes.

A Local Action Group (LAG), made up of around 30 volunteers from organisations,
businesses and individuals, will decide how to allocate the grants, which are
available for both capital projects and revenue support.

Co-ordinator Ivan Hewitt said: "This is an opportunity for businesses and
communities in Northumberland to deliver rural development projects.

"We want to work with local communities, councils and individuals to do a range
of things. We want to try to bring in and encourage more people to deliver local
services in rural areas.

"Most of the projects come under the community development theme, but we also
recognise that the environment is very important to Northumberland, whether it
is helping to manage it or develop the tourism offer. It is a wonderful place to
visit, live and work."

Anyone wishing to access the funds must first submit an expression of interest,
giving a brief outline of their idea, which will be assessed by a LAG sub-group
to ensure it ties in with the themes of the scheme.

The second stage is the formal application, which will go through a technical
appraisal.

The initiative is supported by the European Union, Department for the
Environment, Food and Rural Affairs, One North East and Northumberland County
Council.

For further information contact Mr Hewitt on 01670 794913, or e-mail
ivanhewitt@enrgi.co.uk

USDA Seeks Applications To Expand Economic Development In Rural Communities

BYLINE: The Johnson Pioneer staff

LENGTH: 301  words


USDA Rural Development State Director Patty Clark announced that USDA is seeking
applications for grants to support rural community economic development.

Approximately $4 million is being made available under the Rural Community
Development Initiative (RCDI) program. Eligible applicants include public,
private, and non-profit intermediaries, and federally recognized tribes.

"USDA supports regional projects that build the capacity of rural Kansas
communities, and help spur community and economic development," said Clark.
"Through the RCDI program, USDA can provide technical assistance to rural
communities to build resilient rural regions in Kansas."

RCDI grants can be used to provide training or technical assistance. Training
may focus on home ownership education, minority business entrepreneurship,
strategic community planning or accessing alternative funding sources.
Intermediary organizations must provide matching funds at least equal to the
RCDI grant. Grants range from $50,000 to $250,000.

USDA has invested more than $33 million through the RCDI program since 2009. In
2011, The Kansas Center for Entrepreneurship received a $200,000 grant for
technical assistance and training to assist Marion, Wichita, Greenwood, Greeley,
Chase, and Norton counties The assistance included community and entrepreneur
coaching, succession planning for businesses, and the education and recruitment
of potential angel investors. The technical assistance helped to create new
leadership capacity, capital creation, and increased connectivity to local,
regional, state, and national resources.

For information on how to apply, contact USDA Rural Development Community
Programs Specialist in Kansas, Janette Womack at (785) 271-2742 or
janette.womack@ks.usda.gov Applications must be submitted by August 13, 2015.

Grants pumped into local communities

BYLINE: ANNA SMITH

LENGTH: 195 words



HIGHLIGHT: A COMMUNITY grants scheme has made its mark across Northumberland,
pumping £785,816 into the area.


The Northumberland Coast and Lowlands Leader Local Action Group has dished out
the cash total in its first full year of operation.

Money has been given to various projects across the county, including the new
Strawberry Hill Day Centre in Lynemouth.

The scheme has around £1.2million of funding to distribute over the next three
years and is open for applications from residents, farmers, landowners,
businesses and community groups.

Co-ordinator Ivan Hewitt said: "We are committed to helping support and develop
communities to have a real say in the delivery of rural development through
local community-led projects.

"If you have an idea for developing your small business, improving our natural
and cultural assets, benefiting from bio-energy, carrying forward community
development, sustaining farming and forestry, encouraging tourism and
recreation, or improving basic rural services then we would very much like to
hear from you."

Funding for the initiative is provided through the Rural Development Programme,
which is jointly supported by Defra and the European Union.

For further information contact Mr Hewitt on 01670 863007 or email
ivan@leadercoastandlowlands.org.uk

USDA to highlight rural development

BYLINE: East Bernard Express staff

LENGTH: 335  words


USDA Rural Development representatives will hold a Rural Development Office Day
for Wharton County from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. June 14 to present program information
and applications to the public.

The office day is at the Northside Center, 707 Fahrenthold in El Campo.
Information will be provided about USDA Rural Development Housing, Community and
Business and Cooperative loan and grant programs.

USDA Rural Development works to ensure rural residents can participate fully in
the global economy through technical assistance and programs that help rural
Americans build strong economies to improve their quality of life.

Rural Development loans and grants assist rural communities meet their basic
needs by building water and wastewater systems; financing decent, affordable
housing; supporting electric power and rural businesses, including cooperatives;
and supporting community development with information and technical assistance
including broadband initiatives. USDA Rural Development representatives will be
available during the office day to answer questions and assist individuals with
applications in all program areas.

USDA Rural Development Housing Programs offer loans and grants to families with
very low to moderate income levels in towns and cities meeting certain
population requirements.

Loans are primarily used to help income eligible individuals or households
purchase homes in rural areas. Funds can be used to build, repair and renovate a
home, or to purchase and prepare sites with water and sewage facilities.

For very low-income families who own homes in need of repair, the Home Repair
Loan and Grant Program offers funding for renovations. Funding has previously
been requested to repair a leaking roof, make a home wheelchair accessible,
repair damaged or faulty wiring and to install a waste disposal system.

For more information regarding USDA Rural Development programs, please contact
the Angleton Office at (979) 849-5251, ext. 4 or by visiting our website at
www.rurdev.usda.gov/tx/.

                                US Official News

                             March 17, 2017 Friday

Reps. Yarmuth, Bustos, Peterson & O'Halleran Warn Against Impact of Trump's
Budget Cuts on Working Families, Rural America

LENGTH: 593  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington, DC: U.S. House of Representatives Committee on the Budget has
issued the following press release:



 Congressman John Yarmuth, Ranking Member on the Budget Committee,
Congresswoman Cheri Bustos of Illinois, Co-Chair of the Democratic Policy &
Communications Committee, Congressman Collin Peterson, Ranking Member on the
Agriculture Committee, and Congressman Tom O'Halleran of Arizona today held a
press conference highlighting the devastating impact President Trump's FY2018
budget blueprint would have on hard-working American families, especially those
living in rural America.





 The blueprint calls for a 21 percent cut to the U.S. Department of Agriculture
(USDA), which administers important programs and services to Americans in rural
areas. The budget also calls for eliminating the water and wastewater loan and
grant program, the TIGER grant program, Essential Air Service program, Rural
Business Cooperative Service, the Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program
(LIHEAP),  and Community Development Block Grants, which states use to pay for
Meals on Wheels, and other initiatives that provide jobs and services for
working families. Reps. Bustos, Peterson and O'Halleran all represent largely
rural districts, which were carried by Donald Trump in the 2016 election.



 "The Trump budget is not only irresponsible and cold-hearted, it's ignorant to
the needs and priorities of American families," said Congressman John Yarmuth.
"President Trump promised to create jobs and make Americans safer. Yet his
budget cuts education, transportation, resources that protect public health and
our environment, and diplomatic initiatives that keep our country safe. This
budget is called "America First" but it's the last thing American families can
afford."



 "Every weekend, when I go to grocery stores across my district, more and more
moms and dads are asking me what the heck is going on with President Trump
breaking his promises," said Congresswoman Cheri Bustos. "When it comes to rural
America, there is no clearer example of President Trump breaking his promise
than the budget he released yesterday. President Trump likes to call this an
'America First' budget, but when you dig into the details, he's making a
deliberate choice to damage our rural economy by eliminating programs that have
created thousands of jobs in small towns, ending critical infrastructure
investments in rural communities and making it harder for our growers and
producers to sell their crops."



 "Rural America provides a tremendous service to this country but I don't think
the Administration understands that," said Congressman Collin Peterson. "The
budget cuts programs that help our smaller communities be able to update their
water systems and farmers navigate farm programs. These programs support rural
areas, which support agriculture, which allows us to have cheap, safe and
dependable food. I'm not sure this is going any place but I have concerns about
what this means for the future farm and rural policy."



 "The reality is our tribal communities face anywhere from 50 to 80 percent
unemployment, wages are lower in rural America, and the types of programs that
are being cut in this proposal would have a devastating impact on our tribal
lands and rural areas," said Congressman O'Halleran. "Rural Americans are tough.
They have always given back to our country, and they deserve fairness and
respect. What we see in this budget proposal is not fairness and respect, but
rather, a complete disregard for the challenges our rural communities face."
