                             Assam Tribune (India)

                            August 8, 2015 Saturday

MoU to improve quality of life in Arunachal

LENGTH: 584 words

DATELINE: ITANAGAR


ITANAGAR, Aug. 8 -- The Tata Trusts has signed a Memorandum of Understanding
(MoU) with the Government of Arunachal Pradesh (GoAP) to work towardssustainable
development and improvement of the overall quality of life in the state. Tata
Trusts' associate organisation,the North East Initiative Development Agency
(NEIDA) will implement this programme with an aim to benefit 6,000 households
located in Papum Pare and Lower Subansiri districts.

NEIDA, in co-ordination with the GoAP, collaborates to reduce poverty for low
income rural households in the state. The MoU, signed by Ramesh Negi, Chief
Secretary, GoAP and Burzis S Taraporevala of Tata Trusts, is effective for a
period of five years. While the total outlay of the programme is Rs 14 crore,
Tata Trusts will contribute grants of Rs 6 crore. The remaining funds will be
raised from various sources, including the community in the district.

Tata Trusts will focus on reducing poverty for low income rural households in
the state through enhancing pig rearing management practices; increasing
productivity of rice, maize and horticulture crop (orange) through adoption of
improved cultivation practices and scientific management of orange orchards; and
enhancing forest-based livelihoods and conservation initiatives,thereby enabling
each household to earn an income of Rs 1.5 lakh per annum. Other pilot projects
that are in the pipeline will focus on education, drinking water and sanitation
to improve the overall quality of life of the households in Arunachal Pradesh.
BSTaraporevala, secretary and chief accountant, Tata Trusts said, 'Tata Trusts
has invested Rs 1.43 crore in the state till March 2015 in the sectors of
agriculture, natural resource management, etc. There is a demand for such
development initiatives and the community is keen on contributing and taking
ownership of the project for their betterment.'

Tata Trusts will design the implementation strategy and ensure overall
governance of the initiative, including financial due diligence. The GoAP will
synchronize actions of concerned Government departments and agencies for
successful execution of project objectives. GoAP is expected to co-finance the
programme through its schemes such as NRLM, MGNREGA and key development
projects.

Speaking on the occasion, Ramesh Negi, Chief Secretary, Government of Arunachal
Pradesh said, 'A State Level Steering Committee (SLSC) would be constituted to
review the progress of the programme and provide direction for future course of
action. Tata Trusts and SLSC will jointly review the progress and shall meet on
an annual basis under the Chairmanship of the Chief Secretary, GoAP. District
Level Coordination Committees comprising representatives from the GoAP, Tata
Trusts and NEIDA will also be formed to monitor the developments. These
committees will be under the Chairmanship of the concerned Deputy Commissioner',
Negi added.

Tata Trusts are amongst India's oldest, non-sectarian philanthropic
organizations that work in several areas of community development. Tata Trusts
seek to be catalysts in development through giving grants to institutions in the
areas of Natural Resources Management, Rural Livelihoods, Urban Livelihoods and
Poverty, Education, Enhancing Civil Society and Governance, Health and Media
Arts, Crafts and Culture.

Lt. Governor Skillman Awards Greens Fork with a $30,000 Planning Grant

LENGTH: 265  words

DATELINE: STATE HOUSE


STATE HOUSE, July 28 -- The State Of Indiana has issued following Press Release:

Lieutenant Governor Becky Skillman has awarded the Town of Greens Fork with a
$30,000 planning grant the town will use to fund a wastewater utility planning
study. These federal dollars are from the Community Development Block Grant
(CDBG) program. Indiana's Office of Community and Rural Affairs (OCRA)
administers the grants.

"These planning studies are often the first step for communities that want to
pursue new economic development opportunities," said Lt. Governor Skillman, who
oversees OCRA. "These studies are costly for rural communities, but the state
will continue to support communities that have a vision for improving the
quality of life for Hoosiers."

The grant will fund a study to evaluate the town's current wastewater
infrastructure and treatment plant in order to identify mechanical and
maintenance issues. The system is experiencing freezing controls and inadequate
electrical service. The completed study will outline alternatives to resolve the
issues that are plaguing the system with the goal of providing improved utility
service to residents.

The CDBG grant program has proven to be an effective tool for community-based
planning and research initiatives. Visit www.in.gov/ocra for additional
information on this grant program.

                     Thomasville Times-Enterprise (Georgia)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             August 22, 2008 Friday

Co-Op kicks off Initiative

BYLINE: Teresa Williams, Thomasville Times-Enterprise, Ga.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 766 words


Aug. 22--THOMASVILLE -- The kick-off for a state-wide expansion of the
Communities of Opportunity -- Co-Op -- Initiative took place in Thomasville
Thursday.

Georgia Department of Community Affairs (DCA) and the Georgia Rural Development
Council (GRDC) representatives announced plans to roll out the initiative,
starting in Service Delivery Region 10 -- which includes Thomasville -- at the
municipal auditorium. The kick-off, hosted by City of Thomasville, was the first
stop in the marketing tour for the program.

"This initiative will help you as a local community be what you want to be,"
Mike Beatty, DCA commissioner, said. "It is a bottom-up, locally-driven approach
of where you see yourselves over the next 10 years. The reality is we have a lot
of work to do."

Beatty said, of Georgia's 159 counties, 91 are considered "persistent poverty
counties."

"We've got to change what we've been doing, change our strategy," he said. "This
is an interagency type of initiative: we really work with you all to bring
together a community."

DCA's Jim Finch told kick-off participants it would "behoove all of you to take
a hard look at this program and see if it will help you."

Beatty urged local government officials to participate in the initiative.

"This is about empowerment of people in your communities," he said. "I challenge
all of you to be involved. It's not about money -- that will be there as long as
you all get together -- but about local solutions to global problems."

Co-Op is a collaborative, locally-driven community development strategy that
came about after University of Georgia's Fanning Institute and GRDC discussed a
2003 rural communities study by the school's Carl Vinson Institute of
Government. Agencies worked with DCA to develop a framework for the effort.

Gov. Sonny Perdue signed an executive order in March 2007 launching the state's
Co-Op and charged DCA to work with GRDC, private and public partners and local
communities to administer it.

A pilot program involving 12 East Georgia counties was launched summer 2007.
Participation remains at 100 percent and communities have completed their
strategy plans.

Participation is voluntary and communities that decide to take part will undergo
an assessment, and then local follow-up discussions will take place to determine
focus areas. Participants will have access to a variety of benefits including
program grants (up to $5,000), access to reduced loan rates and two years of
customized technical assistance to achieve key initiatives.

Following the kick-off was a "meeting of interest" where Patrice Williams,
program coordinator, and Leigh Askew of Fanning Institute answered questions and
gave a presentation on how the initiative would work locally. Representatives
from the city, county, school systems and other local agencies were in
attendance.

"This program is about the economic vitality of rural Georgia," Williams said.

Askew, who worked with the pilot program, gave a presentation of statistical
data on Thomas County's population, wages and growth and how it compares with
its region and state.

"We are focusing on building growing, healthy, safe and educated communities,"
she said. "One size does not fit all; you have to be proactive instead of
reactive."

Then, Askew took goals from the county's comprehensive plan and meeting
participants discussed what type of goals these were and how to achieve them.

"It can't be just city and county governments," Roy Campbell, vice-chairman of
GRDC and Thomasville City Council member, said. "All citizens need to be
involved in some form or fashion."

Williams gave Thomas County Commissioner Elaine Mays the participation form and
stipulated Thomasville-Thomas County's involvement would need to be determined
by the Sept. 29 deadline.

"I think this was very informative and it gives us some ideas for pulling
together," Mays said after the meeting. "The city, county -- anybody that was
here today needs to be involved in what we're going to do and how we're going to
do it. I'll take this to the board and see what its interest is; I have no doubt
we will participate in some way. I feel it is something we need to take a look
at."

newspaper, go to http://www.timesenterprise.com/. Copyright (c) 2008,

                  The Leader-Telegram (Eau Claire, Wisconsin)

                              March 3, 2017 Friday

Eau Claire kicked out of business fund

BYLINE: Andrew Dowd, The Leader-Telegram, Eau Claire, Wis.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 394 words


March 03--Eau Claire businesses no longer have access to the Regional Business
Fund, which has provided more than $1.5 million in loans to companies in the
city in the past eight years.

The state Department of Administration notified fund staff last year that a new
federal program designed to aid rural areas would mean that Eau Claire could no
longer take part in the nonprofit fund that serves west-central Wisconsin
businesses.

That new program prohibits entitlement cities such as Eau Claire from any access
to federal Community Development Block Grant money awarded to nonentitlement
communities, including rural areas that are part of the Regional Business Fund,
according to a letter written by Tobi LeMahieu, fund manager.

The Department of Housing and Urban Development approved the Rural Economic and
Area Development Initiative in late fall, which harkened the end of Eau Claire's
ability to use the local fund.

As of Wednesday, city businesses could no longer apply for loans from the
Regional Business Fund.

"Please know that we will continue to monitor the situation and will be in touch
should any policies change that might allow the city to rejoin the RBF loan pool
in the future," LeMahieu wrote.

The Regional Business Fund's board of directors voted on Feb. 9 to return the
city's $350,000 payment it contributed to join the fund in 2009.

Mike Schatz, Eau Claire's economic development administrator, said the city may
use that money to create business façade loan and microloan programs similar to
what the regional fund has.

"We're trying to address it and come up with a way of meeting the financial
needs of the community," he said.

The City Council does have control over how the returned money is spent, Schatz
noted, and it could decide to allocate it toward other city programs.

The regional fund's board also decided that the Eau Claire Area Economic
Development Corp., which contributed $150,000 to the fund in 2010 to support the
city's inclusion in it, can seek a refund or decide to keep it in the fund.

Regional Business Fund programs provide gap financing to help starting and
growing businesses when they need loans in addition to what they can obtain
through private lenders.

Indiana: Lt. Governor Sue Ellspermann Awards a $40,000 Planning Grant to the
City of Mitchell

LENGTH: 192  words

DATELINE: Indianapolis


Office of Community & Rural Affairs, The State of Indiana has issued the
following news release:

Lt. Governor Sue Ellspermann has awarded a $40,000 planning grant to the city of
Mitchell for a comprehensive plan through the state's Office of Community and
Rural Affairs.

community."

Grant (CDBG) program, which has proven to be an effective tool for
community-based planning and research initiatives. Mitchell provided a local

an early stage venture capitalist and four of which as a manager of two startup
ventures. Since 2001, Michael has led CEI Community Ventures (CCV), one of only
six SBA New Markets Venture Capital (NMVC) companies in the US licensed to
deploy $10M of early stage capital and $3M of operational assistance grant funds

sister program to the New Markets Tax Credit initiative run by Treasury, the
NMVC program was a Clinton administration initiative designed to drive high
impact, early stage equity and grant capital into under-served and distressed

Indiana: Lt. Governor Skillman Awards Oakland City with a $30,000 Planning Grant

LENGTH: 254  words

DATELINE: STATE HOUSE


STATE HOUSE, June 19 -- The State Of Indiana has issued following press release:

Lt. Governor Becky Skillman has awarded the City of Oakland City with a $30,000
planning grant the city will use to fund a park and recreation master planning
study. These federal dollars are from the Community Development Block Grant
(CDBG) program. Indiana's Office of Community and Rural Affairs (OCRA)
administers the grants.

"These planning studies are often the first step for communities that want to
pursue new economic development opportunities," said Lt. Governor Skillman, who
oversees OCRA. "These studies are costly for rural communities, but the state
will continue to support communities that have a vision for improving the
quality of life for Hoosiers."

The grant will fund a five-year master park planning study which will be created
in compliance with the Department of Natural Resources' standards. The study
will assess the park system's physical facilities as well as current recreation,
arts, community events, sports and fitness offerings, and make recommendations
to better serve community needs in the coming years.

The CDBG grant program has proven to be an effective tool for community-based
planning and research initiatives. Visit www.in.gov/ocra for additional
information on this grant program.

Utah: Native Asset Building Initiative

LENGTH: 467  words

DATELINE: Salt Lake City


Office of Rural Assistance Center, The State of Utah has issued the following
news release:

Sponsor  Administration for Native Americans
Deadlines  Jul 15, 2013
Contact

Program Office Contact:
Christina Clark
Phone: 202.401.5399
Email: Christina.Clark@ACF.hhs.gov

Office of Grants Management Contact:
Tim Chappelle
Phone: 202.401.4855
Email: tim.chappelle@acf.hhs.gov
Purpose

Native Asset Building Initiative grants will provide funding to establish and
operate programs that provide an array of supports and services to enable low
income individuals and families to become economically self-sufficient.

Each project requires that eligible participants are given access to matched
savings accounts, called Individual Development Accounts (IDA), in which
participants save earned income for the purchase of a home, for business
capitalization, or to attend higher education or training. Participants are also
given access to other supportive services that enable them to become more
financially secure.
Eligibility

Applications will be accepted from:

Native 501(c)(3) nonprofits serving Native Americans
    Native nonprofit organizations designated by the Secretary of the Treasury
as Community Development Financial Institutions (CDFIs) that demonstrate a
collaborative relationship with a local community-based organization whose
activities are designed to address poverty and the needs of community members
for economic independence and stability
    Federally recognized tribal governments and Alaska Native Villages that are
joint applicants with a 501(c)(3) Native nonprofit organization
    Native nonprofit credit unions designated as low-income credit unions by the
National Credit Union Administration (NCUA) that can demonstrate a collaborative
relationship with a local community-based organizations whose activities are
designed to address poverty in the community and the needs of community members
for economic independence and stability

Geographic
coverage  Nationwide
Amount of
funding

Grantees awarded under this joint funding opportunity will implement one project
funded by two ACF program offices, OCS and ANA. As each program office will fund
a portion of the project, grantees will receive one award from OCS and one award
from ANA to fund the project. OCS and ANA will collaborate on funding decisions,
so all funded grantees will receive an award from each program office. No
grantee will receive only OCS funding or only ANA funding.

Grantees must provide at least 50 percent of the total approved cost of the AFI
budget. Grantees must provide at least 20 percent of the total approved cost of
the SEDS budget.

Total Funding Available: $2,800,000
Award Ceiling: $125,000,000
Award Floor: $50,000
Number of Awards: Approximately 6

For further information please visit: http://www.raconline.org/

                              April 3, 2015 Friday

Oklahoma: Rural economic development program seeking applications

LENGTH: 453  words

DATELINE: Oklahoma city


Division of Agricultural Sciences and Natural Resources, The state of Oklahoma
has issued the following news release:

Communities interested in boosting their regional economic development prospects
should apply now for the Stronger Economies Together program.

A national initiative designed to potentially have a big impact on the state,
SET helps rural communities partner together to enhance regional economic
development opportunities. The program is offered through the U.S. Department of
Agriculture Rural Development and Regional Rural Development Centers.

"SET helps communities think beyond their city and county borders to build
important relationships and identify key resources that can successfully drive
regional projects," said Dave Shideler, Oklahoma State University Cooperative
Extension community development specialist.

This is the third time Oklahoma has participated in the SET program. Currently,
18 counties in the state are actively involved in the initiative.

The 7-month program includes six coaching sessions covering an overview of the
region, team building exercises and a study of the region's economic climate and
potential resources.

Participating regions also will create a strategic plan that can be put into
action immediately, as well as have access to 40 hours of technical assistance
from the SET coaching team, including professionals from state and federal
agencies, OSU, Extension and other public and private organizations.

"Community leaders understand no project is successful without a plan. SET uses
the expertise of the USDA and Extension to help communities to gather the
necessary knowledge, skills and resources to build a solid plan and put it into
action," said Kathleen James, Oklahoma community and economic development
coordinator for USDA Rural Development. As an added benefit to participating in
SET, communities that complete the program tend to be in a good position to earn
grants and other types of support for needs they have identified.

"Part of the goal of the program is to create meaningful relationships across
communities, counties and organizations that have the potential to help regions
flourish economically," Shideler said. "Ultimately, that kind of growth is not
just good for the region, it's good for all of Oklahoma."Oklahoma State
University, U.S. Department of Agriculture, State and Local Governments
Cooperating: The Oklahoma Cooperative Extension Service offers its programs to
all eligible persons regardless of race, color, national origin, religion,
gender, age, disability, or status as a veteran, and is an equal opportunity
employer.

                             The Guardian (London)

                                  May 12, 1999

Action at risk;
A scheme that has already helped nearly 5,000 local initiatives is on hold
pending a review by the Countryside Agency. Kim Chalet reports

BYLINE: Kim Chalet

SECTION: The Guardian Society Page; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 862 words


Late last year a group of village residents gathered in a Somerset church to
toast the launch of a new wall hanging. The community textile, or Henstridge
Fresco as it became known, was devised and created by local people and was
partially financed by a grant from Rural Action, the scheme which promoted
grassroots environmental or community initiatives. There have been 4,800
successful schemes nationwide since it began in 1993, including pond clearing,
nature trails, traffic surveys, hedge laying, dry stone walling and wildflower
audits.

Six months on, no one knows whether the unveiling in Henstridge was the final
curtain for Rural Action.

In November last year, Rural Action - managed by Action for Communities in Rural
England (Acre) - told its network administrators to halt all works, including
grant giving and interest generating. Rural Action had been hoping to renew its
funding, ceasing in April 1999, from the Countryside Commission, English Nature
and the Rural Development Commission.

But its renewal coincided with the formation of the new Countryside Agency, and
the merger of two former sponsors. The small sum of pounds 210,000 has been
found to keep all the county networks intact, but the grant giving scheme has
been put on hold. Ominously, five of the scheme's organisers at its Cirencester
head office have been made redundant. In the coming months, the Countryside
Agency will have to address Rural Action's future.

The halt in grants posed problems for the scheme's county administrators. Many
had projects under discussion, others were halfway through to completion - Rural
Action has often encouraged environmental groups to work in phases.

Wendy Bullar, Derbyshire's network administrator, says that on her books she has
11 projects which have been approved but which cannot now be funded.

Nick Woolfenden, Rural Action administrator for Sussex, says: 'We work by small
groups of people taking a project to a local contact, an expert who will
champion their cause, give them advice and direction and help them apply to the
network for a grant. Typically, the grant needs are small - perhaps pounds 100
or so. The scheme's accessibility was its strength. Now there is a huge gap to
be filled.

'In the last year, we have sent out grant application forms to 100 groups. These
small groups of people spend time forming, organising, drawing up plans and
having meetings before filling in the grant form. Enthusiasm will be dampened,
with the ideas for these environmental improvements falling away.'
Administrators like Nick Woolfenden, and Sarah Taragon in Devon, are sending
their applicants lists of other sources of funds. Taragon sends out addresses of
30 other sources of possible funding, but says: 'Not all are appropriate and
most are national, so groups lose that local contact.' One of the many Rural
Action success stories has been the Carhampton Community Orchard, on the fringes
of Exmoor. The orchard, in the process of being re-stocked, managed and enjoyed
by the villagers, is ending the first year of a 10-year management plan, part of
a 25-year project to preserve it for generations to come.

The next phase of the Carhampton plan was to label all the new trees and
undertake an orchard education programme. But the group's pounds 1,200
application to Rural Action fell foul of the centrally imposed, and largely
unannounced, grant deadline. 'I'm not grumbling,' says Keith Jones, the
project's secretary. 'We've now got to start to look for other sources of
funding, but in small communities like ours - where the church is also appealing
for pounds 160,000 - it is difficult. That is why Rural Action has been so
invaluable.' Rural Action's business plan for its future development has been
deemed unacceptable. A meeting of the steering group of the funding partnership
concluded that the plan relied too heavily on exchequer funding and that a
broader range of financial support was needed. Acre has now made an appeal for
National Lotteries Board funding.

The old Countryside Commission, now part of the new Countryside Agency,
announced that a decision on the future of Rural Action would have to wait until
the new Countryside Agency Board is in place.

Helen Thomson, the agency's new head of community development, says that the
temporary halt to Rural Action's work was not unexpected. 'We had invited Acre
to look for alternative funding, from a variety of sources,' she says. 'There
are funds from the Countryside Agency and English Nature to maintain the
networks while we carry out a review to research and evaluate Rural Action's
work.' As the new Countryside Agency makes its first decisions, it is debatable
whether one of Rural Action's quieter strengths - the ability to listen to the
needs of rural communities - will be given prominence. Its supporters fear that
a new scheme may take a more top down approach. As one former employee of Rural
Action says: 'After seven years we knew how to encourage and support the schemes
people in rural communities had in mind. Now the suspicion is that public
participation will be encouraged along prescribed lines.'


LOAD-DATE: May 12, 1999

USA: Lt. Governor Skillman Awards a $30,000 Planning Grant to Town of Dale

LENGTH: 256  words

DATELINE: STATEHOUSE


STATEHOUSE, March 26 -- The State Of Indiana has issued following press release:

Lt. Governor Becky Skillman has awarded a $30,000 planning grant to the Town of
Dale to fund a water utility planning study. These federal dollars are from the
Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) program. Indiana's Office of Community
and Rural Affairs (OCRA) administers the grants.

"These planning studies are often the first step for communities that want to
pursue new economic development opportunities," said Lt. Governor Skillman, who
oversees OCRA. "These studies are costly for rural communities, but the state
will continue to support communities that have a vision for improving the
quality of life for Hoosiers."

The study will evaluate the town's current water system, including the supply,
storage tank and distribution system, and make recommendations for improvements.
The aging system, which was constructed in the late 1940's and early 1950's, is
in poor repair and contains asbestos. The study will provide preliminary
engineering as well as cost estimates for improvements to the water
infrastructure.

The CDBG grant program has proven to be an effective tool for community-based
planning and research initiatives. Visit www.in.gov/ocra for additional
information on this grant program.

STATEHOUSE, April 01 -- The State Of Indiana has issued following press release:

Lt. Governor Becky Skillman has awarded a $39,600 planning grant to the Town of
Boswell to fund a water and wastewater utility planning study. These federal
dollars are from the Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) program. Indiana's
Office of Community and Rural Affairs (OCRA) administers the grants.

"These planning studies are often the first step for communities that want to
pursue new economic development opportunities," said Lt. Governor Skillman, who
oversees OCRA. "These studies are costly for rural communities, but the state
will continue to support communities that have a vision for improving the
quality of life for Hoosiers."

The study will evaluate the town's current water utilities, including the
wastewater treatment plant and water distribution system. The system is
currently in violation of environmental regulations and is in poor repair. The
study will provide preliminary engineering as well as cost estimates for
improvements to the water infrastructure.

                           Aberdeen Press and Journal

                                 July 24, 2004

Milestone 100 projects for crofting development scheme

BYLINE: Ian Forsyth

SECTION: Business; Farm/Food; News; Pg. 21

LENGTH: 518 words


The Crofters Commission said yesterday that the Crofting Communities Development
Scheme (CCDS) had reached the milestone of supporting 100 community plans
throughout the crofting counties.  CCDS is part of the Highlands and Islands
Special Transitional Programme, and is jointly funded by the Government through
Scottish Executive Environment and Rural Affairs Department, and the European
Commission.

Earlier this year it was announced that the CCDS had been awarded an additional
allocation of funding of around £500,000 due to its strong performance in the
first three years.

Scheme manager Arthur MacDonald said: "Interest in the scheme has increased
steadily since it opened in 2001, particularly in the Western Isles where we
have two development assistants.

"In view of the success of the scheme in these areas and the extra funding
awarded this year, we are pleased to be able to support two additional
development assistants.

"One will operate in Skye, Lochalsh and Wester Ross, the other in Shetland.

"The high numbers of crofters in these areas will benefit from improved
promotion of the CCDS and help in formulating local eligible plans." The scheme
is designed to help crofting communities identify, prioritise and implement a
range of development plans to improve social fabric and economic structure.

Groups also bring into play sustainable economic and environmental principles to
create more vibrant and active communities.

The total investment in crofting achieved through the 100 approved plans is over
£9.4million.  This includes over £2.1million invested by the communities
themselves, and over £7.3million from 50 public sector grant sources.

The 100 approved plans comprise 330 separate projects covering the entire
spectrum of community developments ranging from traditional agricultural
operations such as fank improvements and the installation of stock grids, social
projects including community centres and play areas, to economic diversification
initiatives such as tourist facilities, cafes and commercial offices.

An example of a community initiative supported through the scheme is the
Broadford Environmental Development Group based in Skye.

Its community plan takes in six objectives and demonstrates a wide spread of
environmental, heritage and diversification projects.

Included in the plan are the appoint- ment of a village development officer, the
building of a millennium bridge and the creation of a community garden.

Chairman of the Crofters Commission David Green said: "It is extremely
encouraging to see that the CCDS has successfully supported 100 crofting
communities with their development plans.

"This is proof of the commitment and pride people feel towards their
communities.

"There is also real evidence that there is no shortage of the practical skills
required to not only have vision, but to be able to turn that vision into a
robust plan for the future that meets economic, environmental and
socially-sustainable criteria.

"Well done to Arthur MacDonald and his team for all their hard work."

Wisconsin: Governor Walker Highlights Success at Northern Wisconsin Economic
Development Summit

LENGTH: 378  words

DATELINE: New York



 Madison: Office of the Governor Scott Walker, The state of Wisconsin has issued
the following news release:



 Governor Scott Walker joined members of his cabinet today at the annual
Northern Economic Development Summit, held in Minocqua. In addition to
highlighting the economic success in northern Wisconsin, Governor Walker also
announced a $10 million investment in rural economic development through the
Rural Economic and Area Development Initiative, or READI.





 "Northern Wisconsin plays a crucial role in the economic success of our state
and is home to many of our key industries, including tourism, forestry, and
manufacturing," Governor Walker said. "The READI grants we're announcing today
work to ensure the continued success of these industries and others businesses
in rural areas of our state. This innovative approach encourages new business
growth and job creation, trains workers and provides access to housing, which
lays the foundation for sustainable, long-term growth in rural Wisconsin
communities."



 READI is a comprehensive category of Community Development Block Grant (CDBG)
funds administered by the Department of Administration's Division of Energy,
Housing, and Community Resources. The program will use $10 million of
unallocated CDBG funds to assist rural communities with economic development,
workforce housing, and workforce training. Funds are made available through an
application process to Units of General Local Governments (UGLGs).



 The comprehensive grants include up to $500,000 for proposals to create or
expand a business resulting in the creation of low- and moderate-income jobs;
workforce housing loans of up to $300,000 for proposals to attract new workers
to rural areas by rehabilitating or creating workforce housing near the economic
development project; and workforce training grants of up to $200,000 to train
new workers at the proposed economic development project.



 Governor Walker's cabinet is also participating in 61 events throughout
northern Wisconsin in Iron, Price, Taylor, Vilas, Oneida, Lincoln, Marathon,
Florence, Forest, Langlade, Shawano, Marinette, Oconto, and Menominee counties.

                          The Anniston Star (Alabama)

                           December 10, 2016 Saturday

Borden Springs firefighters need help expanding after acquiring emergency
vehicle

BYLINE: Laura Camper, The Anniston Star, Ala.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 490 words


Dec. 10--Borden Springs firefighters won two federal grants from the Rural
Community Development and Initiative Grant program this year to buy a utility
task vehicle and trailer to haul it.

But the department now needs a little more help from the county to safely and
conveniently store the UTV.

"It's in our fire department right now," said Richard McCain, assistant chief of
the Borden Springs Volunteer Fire Department. "But to get to it you've got to
move a lot of stuff out of the way."

McCain said the department was awarded $6,000 in June and another $7,000 in
October and had to come up with a $1,000 match to purchase the side by side.

The UTV will help firefighters search for and rescue lost or injured people on
the miles of the Pinhoti and Chief Ladiga trails that wind through the
department's coverage area as well as several thousand acres of land with no
road access, McCain said.

"What we've done in the past, many times, is I'd load my personal four-wheeler
up at home and haul it up there," he said.

But his four-wheeler doesn't have the space to haul a lot of equipment or an
injured person, McCain added. The new side-by-side has the space to carry an
injured person on a litter along with a medical technician to tend to the
patient on the trip, he said.

The firefighters want to add a shed onto the department that would allow them to
park a truck and just drive the UTV onto the attached trailer. But to do that,
they've also got to widen the driveway to the shed. They approached the county
engineer about adding some drainage pipe to allow the expansion.

County Engineer Lee Estes said he was unsure whether the county was allowed to
do the work since it was on private property. He contacted the Alabama Attorney
General's office for guidance.

In most cases, the county will do the installation, but the property owner has
to purchase the pipe, which in this case would cost about $300, Estes said. The
volunteer fire department would be able to purchase the pipe but would then have
to put off doing the construction on the shed, McCain said.

Estes said the project would be a quick one for the road department.

"We're talking an hour's worth of work," Estes said. "It'll take us longer to
drive out there than it will to lay it in the ditch."

Estes said the opinion he received stated the county could do the work and not
charge the department for the pipe, because "a volunteer fire department is
considered a quasi-government agency," Estes said. To proceed, though, he has to
have authorization from the Cleburne County Commission, Estes said.

Commission Chairman Ryan Robertson said the proposed pipe-laying will be on the
commission's meeting agenda for discussion Monday.

Staff writer Laura Camper: 256-235-3545 or, in Heflin, 256-463-2872. On Twitter
@LCamper_Star.

                            February 6, 2012 Monday

The Progress Fund celebrates record year of lending

BYLINE: The Daily Courier, Connellsville, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 437 words


Feb. 06--During its most successful year yet, The Progress Fund loaned more than
$5 million to 25 area small businesses, and is positioned to surpass this record
in 2012. The Progress Fund was recognized with significant awards in 2011
including:

-- $2 million awarded from the PA Department of Community and Economic
Development with funds provided by the U.S. Department of the Treasury's State
Small Business Credit Initiative to promote small business job creation in
Pennsylvania.

-- $2.75 million from Wachovia Wells Fargo NEXT Awards for Opportunity Finance,
to expand its Trail Town Program, strengthen local economies and stimulate job
growth in disadvantaged communities.

-- $1.052 million from the Small Business Lending Fund, to provide loan capital
to small businesses in rural areas of southwestern Pennsylvania.

-- $1.5 million from the Community Development Financial Institutions Fund for
financial institutions in Pennsylvania to provide capital to small businesses
and create jobs across the state.

-- A $100,000 grant and $500,000 loan from the USDA Rural Development's Rural
Microentrepreneur Assistance Program to provide technical assistance and
training to rural microentrepreneurs and small businesses and to help create or
save over 22 jobs.

-- A $62,963 capital grant from the Create Jobs for USA Fund, collaboration
between Starbucks and Opportunity Finance Network. The money will help The
Progress Fund create and sustain jobs in southwestern Pennsylvania as part of a
national campaign to support community businesses in underserved communities.

The Progress Fund was one of the first six organizations selected from across
the nation to be approved for participation in the Community Advantage Pilot
Loan Program which will increase SBA-backed loans to small businesses in
underserved communities.

The Progress Fund looks forward to using recently received funding to make more
small business loans in 2012 and having an even stronger impact on small
businesses and job creation in the region.

The Progress Fund is a vigorous nonprofit loan fund that creates jobs and
improves communities by providing entrepreneurial coaching and capital to small
businesses in the travel & tourism industry. The fund serves 40 counties in
Pennsylvania, Appalachian Ohio and West Virginia.

The fund was founded in 1997, and has made 378 loans totaling more than $41.48
million to 227 enterprises, creating or preserving more than 2,618 jobs.

                           The Mercury (South Africa)

                             July 09, 2015 Thursday
                                   E1 Edition

Work projects must address training;
CWP provides incomes and upgrades localities, but it should also involve
training and empowerment

BYLINE:   Mondli Zondo

SECTION: Pg. 9

LENGTH: 601 words


LAST week, I visited my family in Nyanyadu in rural Endumeni Municipality,
KwaZulu-Natal, and discovered my stepmother is involved in the Community Work
Programme (CWP).

Aimed at tackling poverty and unemployment, the programme provides an employment
safety net by giving participants regular work - typically two days a week -
providing a predictable income stream.

The work of the CWP involves doing anything from cleaning up public spaces to
planting seedlings, maintaining community gardens and parks, fencing schools,
desk refurbishments and the like.

The province has spent more than R200 million on CWPs and they are apparently
reaching more than 30 000 people.

But I am not convinced we have challenged ourselves enough to maximise impact.

Most participants have no formal education and use the stipend they receive to
supplement other grants they receive from government.

They would value opportunities to advance themselves so they can move from being
dependent on the state to being self-sufficient and contributing to the formal
economy.

With Women's Month approaching, we will no doubt witness the usual plethora of
summits and conferences highlighting challenges faced by women.

This is important, but I find greater value in talking about what opportunities
are available and how we can improve these.

I believe there is more to be done in unlocking the potential of CWPs in the
area of women and community development.

The goal of CWPs must change from being simply a provider of regular income to
being a source of skills development in order to bridge the skills deficit in
rural communities.

The government must create formal structures; an apprenticeship programme of
sorts to train participants, ultimately resulting in them being awarded a
formal, recognised qualification.

This can take the form of the recently announced initiative by the City of Cape
Town in partnership with UCT, in which the city plans to invest R39 million in
taxi operators' skills development.

The course will offer modules such as Business Management and Co-operative
Governance which will improve how operators conduct their businesses.

The same can be achieved for CWP workers who could use their newfound skills to
start businesses and eventually create employment by being awarded tenders.

These courses would also need to make provision for adults who are illiterate;
perhaps in tandem with Adult Basic Education and Training Programmes (ABET).

This would not only improve our adult literacy rates, but would have a ripple
effect in promoting a culture of learning in rural communities.

Research shows children who come from homes where parents are not educated are
unlikely to complete school themselves.

If it is to succeed, this is not a cause which should be taken up by government
alone.

The private sector needs to play a role in training and skills development. But
current market conditions mean few businesses will be able to do this.

So the government needs to provide incentives, whether in the form of tax breaks
or subsidies to businesses which invest in such initiatives.

By investing in the advancement of rural women, South Africa would improve the
quality of life of people living in rural areas.

In the Handbook of Research on Gender and Economic Life, Smith and Haddad found
increases in women's education in 63 countries accounted for the largest
contribution in reducing child malnutrition by up to 43%.

We need to move from defining women as victims of discrimination and see them as
agents of change.

l Zondo is a political researcher at the KZN provincial legislature and writes
in his personal capacity.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       Sarasota Herald Tribune (Florida)

                           January 22, 2009 Thursday

City goes back to the same well // Debt service on $5.8M loan

BYLINE: Nick Kotsopoulos

SECTION: LOCAL NEWS; Pg. B1

LENGTH: 764 words

DATELINE: WORCESTER


WORCESTER - For the second time in six months, the city has to dig into its
pockets to pay the debt service owed on the $5.8 million federal loan it
received for the Gardner Kilby Hammond Revitalization Project in the Main South
area.

Between August 2004 and February 2008, payments on that loan obligation were
made from federal earmarks secured for the city by U.S. Rep. James. P. McGovern,
D-Worcester, during the federal budget process.

In total, Mr. McGovern was able to obtain $1.1 million in federal money to pay
for the city's debt service on the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban
Development Section 108 Loan, as part of more than $8 million in overall federal
money that has been awarded for the Main South project.

But City Manager Michael V. O'Brien said the availability of more federal money
for that purpose has dried up for the time being.

"Due to the Bush administration's opposition to the authorization of federal
earmarks for local projects, as well as budget pressures due to the war effort,
a succession of natural disasters, and national economic pressures due to the
foreclosure and Wall Street crises, federal outlays for projects such as the
Gardner Kilby Hammond initiative were not approved in the past two federal
budget cycles," Mr. O'Brien said.

To make its debt service payment last August, the manager said, the city had to
use unexpended balances from the previous year's federal Community Development
Block Grant programs. Faced with having to make another payment Monday, the city
is using that same strategy.

The City Council Tuesday night approved the use of $132,939 in prior-year
unexpended balances from block grant programs so the city can make debt payment
on the loan.

But with another $232,061 debt payment due in August, Assistant City Manager
Julie A. Jacobson warned, that funding source the city tapped to make the last
two payments has also run dry.

"We will not have sufficient (Community Development Block Grant) unexpended
balances to make additional payments due in August and future years without
additional federal earmarks," Ms. Jacobson said. "If additional federal funding
is not received, we will recommend funding this debt service through our annual
(block grant) entitlement in the amount of $365,000 (annually)."

Ms. Jacobson said such a course of action would have a significant impact on
those agencies and services that receive block grant funds from the city.

She said if the city were to default on its payment obligation, the U.S.
Department of Housing and Urban Development would automatically take the money
out of the city's annual block grant allocation until the debt obligation is
resolved.

Mr. O'Brien said he has been assured by Mr. McGovern that the Gardner Kilby
Hammond project remains a high priority on his legislative agenda and the
manager said he is cautiously optimistic that future federal funding will be
secured for the project.

"We are grateful for the congressman's support of this initiative, and for his
leadership and commitment to continuing to seek federal earmarks to fund the
ongoing debt service needs of this pivotal project," Mr. O'Brien said.

The total loan issued for the project is $5.8 million. Ms. Jacobson said the
total amount of principal and interest on that note will be slightly more than
$10 million over its 20-year term. She said the current principal balance on the
loan is $4.7 million and debt service payments will run through August 2024. The
annual debt service payments will average about $365,000 a year during the life
of the loan, with balloon payments due in 2018 ($1.87 million) and 2024 ($1.27
million), she said.

The Section 108 loan was issued to the city for site acquisition, demolition and
preparation of a 7.5-acre parcel in Main South, so it could be redeveloped and
provide recreational opportunities for Clark University and neighborhood
residents through the Gardner Kilby Hammond Neighborhood Initiative - a $30
million public-private effort to revitalize a blighted 30-acre tract in that
area.

The recreational components of the redevelopment initiative include the new $7.5
million Boys & Girls Club, which opened in September 2006, as well as a $2.5
million track and field complex that will be constructed by Clark University and
made available to those who use the Boys & Girls Club.

"It is anticipated that the proposed track and field facility will be
constructed and opened by the end of calendar 2009," Ms. Jacobson said. "Clark
University will purchase 4.5 acres of the 7.5-acre parcel for this element of
the project."

NAME: WORCESTER CITY COUNCIL

Purpose

The Coca-Cola Foundation provides grants in the following areas:

Water Stewardship:
    Funding to support access to clean water and sanitation, watershed
protection in water-stressed regions, utilization of water for production and or
multiple use systems that do more than provide clean drinking water, education
and awareness programs that promote water conservation within communities and
industry.
    Healthy and Active Lifestyles:
    Funding to support access to exercise, physical activity and nutritional
education programs, programs that motivate behavior modification, and programs
that encourage lifestyle/behavioral changes.
    Community Recycling:
    Funding to increase liter abatement efforts, advance recovery and reuse,
increase community recycling awareness, and support research and innovation
    Education:
    Funding to support scholarships, school drop-out prevention, access to
education programs, and other education initiatives, per local business unit
priorities

Eligibility

The Coca-Cola Foundation does not make grants to:

Individuals (except through college scholarships); schools; religious

construction or renovation projects
    Organizations that do not have tax-exempt status under Section 501(c)(3) of
the Internal Revenue Code, or the equivalent
    Organizations formed outside the U. S. that do not have a charitable
equivalency status under the laws and provisions of their respective government

                             354 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                            Daily Post (North Wales)

                            May 21, 2003, Wednesday

GWYNEDD WELCOMES THE BEST OF THE PUBLIC AND PRIVATE WORLDS

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 4,5

LENGTH: 643 words


LARGE sums of money are obviously being drawn into the Objective 1 programme in
Gwynedd from both private and public sector sources.

Gwynedd Economic Partnership has to date secured approval for 35 Objective 1
projects worth in total more than pounds 34m and attracting more than pounds
12min European grants.

It says the best way to assess the success of the programme in the county is to
consider the economic impact that projects are having.

As might be expected, there has been a strong focus on small business.

Under the first phase of the Gwynedd Business Development Grant scheme, 79 new
SMEs and 163 existing SMEs received financial assistance and 293 jobs were
created.

A second pounds 1.4mphase to the business development grant scheme is being set
up to build on this success.

It will aim to increase the competitiveness of the SME sector in
Gwynedd,offering financial assistance to 63 SMEs in high value sectors of the
local economy,creating 200 new jobs and safeguarding a further 256.

Farming has always been a vital part of Gwynedd's economy and a pounds
2.6magri-innovationinitiative, which has secured an EU grant of pounds 1.24m,
will aim to create and embed a culture of innovation within SMEs in the
agricultural sector in Gwynedd as a means of ensuring the economic viability of
rural areas.

Another recently- approved project will see the appointment of a development
officer to work on inshore fisheries projects that will add value to primary sea
produce and help with branding and marketing.

Two other important projects that have been approved recently, that will
encourage the regeneration of peripheral and deprived communities in Gwynedd,are
the Gwynedd Key Fund and the Gwynedd Community Key Fund.

The main aim of the first is to support community- led initiatives which
contribute to social and economic developments. The pounds 870,000 Key Fund will
provide up to 100pc grants to schemes that will be developed and managed by the
communities themselves. This project aims to engage 46 community organisations,
support 30 community- led projects and support eight community owned assets.

The pounds 241,000 Gwynedd Community Key Fund,on the other hand, will assist
voluntary and community groups to develop new capacity building projects that
will promote the involvement of local people in the regeneration of their local
communities.

It is hoped that by the end of the project 67 community development initiatives
will have received support and 50 community initiatives will be still active
after two years.

The Objective 1 programme in Gwynedd continues apace.

During the last six months a further 13 projects have been approved by the Welsh
European Funding Office,drawing down almost pounds 5m of European aid and pounds
12mof total funding.

In addition to the projects that have already received WEFO approval, the reare
currently 13 projects to the value of pounds 36.1m with WEFO for consideration
and a further 16 projects to the value of pounds 29mhave been endorsed by the
Gwynedd Economic Partnership and are currently putting their bids together.

Projects submitted to WEFO include a marine centre of excellence in
Pwllheli,North West Wales management development centre in Bangor and the
Snowdonia land management project.

Partnership chairman Dewi Lewis said: "We are now entering the second half of
the programme. "I hope that the enthusiasm we have seen in the past will remain
and that we will continue to see strong and strategic projects being developed
in Gwynedd."

Regional projects under Objective 1 are also playing an important role and a
wide range of projects has been developed through intermediary organisations'
such as Wales Tourist Board, Finance Wales,Welsh Development Agency,local
authorities,colleges, universities andothers.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Gwynedd council, search for information on the new PEG website

Utah: Community Innovation Grants

LENGTH: 309  words

Purpose

Community Innovation Grants awards funding to nonprofits working to create
effective, equitable, and sustainable changes in communities. Although
limitations aren't put on the types of projects, at least 50% of Community
Innovation grants will be awarded to projects that address racial and economic
disparities.

Funds were awarded to the First Children's Finance Fund which address rural
child care issues
    Funds were awarded to the Northfield Healthy Community Initiative which is
designed to achieve community-level change for children and youth
    Funds were awarded to Renewing the Countryside II which works to strengthen
local food systems in rural areas
    Funds were awarded to the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe for culturally competent
health and wellness programs targeted for tribe members
    Funds were awarded to Men as Peacemakers which engages men with women in
preventing violence and promoting equity

Eligibility

501(c)(3) nonprofit organizations and government units are eligible.

Utah: Community Innovation Grants

LENGTH: 309  words

DATELINE: Salt Lake City


Office of Rural Assistance Center, The State of Utah has issued the following
news release:

    Funds were awarded to Men as Peacemakers which engages men with women in

                                US Official News

                           September 7, 2013 Saturday

Indiana: Lt. Governor Sue Ellspermann Awards a $40,000 Planning Grant to the
City of Huntingburg

LENGTH: 243  words

DATELINE: Indianapolis


Office of Governor, The State of Indiana has issued the following news release:

Lt. Governor Sue Ellspermann has awarded a $40,000 planning grant to the city of
Huntingburg to fund a downtown revitalization plan through the state's Office of
Community and Rural Affairs.

"Planning grants are an important first step as communities consider the best
way to attract new businesses," said Lt. Governor Ellspermann.  "The city of
Huntingburg continues its growth and revitalization, and we are pleased to
provide this important funding for planning in the downtown area.  The area that
the city has designated for the planning grant includes historic buildings such
as Old Town Hall, 4th Street's important retail district, favorite restaurants,
and more.  With the appropriate planning tools, the city will be able to plan
appropriately for future growth and attract even more businesses to beautiful
Huntingburg."

The planning grant for the city of Huntingburg will be used to evaluate the area
from Geiger Street to Van Buren Street as well as Third Street to Fifth Street.

The majority of the funding comes from the federal Community Development Block
Grant (CDBG) program, which has proven to be an effective tool for
community-based planning and research initiatives. Huntingburg has committed a
local match of $5,000.

The CDBG program is administered by the Indiana Office of Community and Rural
Affairs.

For further information please visit: http://www.in.gov/

                             May 19, 2010 Wednesday

Indiana: Lt. Governor Skillman Awards Princeton with a $30,000 Planning Grant

LENGTH: 260  words

DATELINE: STATEHOUSE


STATEHOUSE, May 19 -- The State Of Indiana has issued following press release:

Lt. Governor Becky Skillman has awarded the City of Princeton with a $30,000
planning grant the city will use to fund a park and recreation master planning
study. These federal dollars are from the Community Development Block Grant
(CDBG) program. Indiana's Office of Community and Rural Affairs (OCRA)
administers the grants.

"These planning studies are often the first step for communities that want to
pursue new economic development opportunities," said Lt. Governor Skillman, who
oversees OCRA. "These studies are costly for rural communities, but the state
will continue to support communities that have a vision for improving the
quality of life for Hoosiers."

The grant will fund a five-year master park planning study which will be created
in compliance with the Department of Natural Resources' standards. The study
will outline strategies the city's parks and recreation department will follow
to better serve community needs in the coming years. Replacing the city's
swimming pool, building a new multi-use trail system, and considering
alternatives for a potential community center are some items which will be
included in the plan.

The CDBG grant program has proven to be an effective tool for community-based
planning and research initiatives.

                       The Rushville Republican (Indiana)

                            January 10, 2017 Tuesday

Update on Stellar projects

BYLINE: Kate Thurston, The Rushville Republican, Ind.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 876 words


Jan. 10--Some might look around and not see many changes in Rushville after
becoming a Stellar Community, but if you look behind the scenes, there's a lot
of hustle and bustle preparing for big projects coming to the community.

Here is a recap of the Stellar process since summer.

As a result of being chosen for Stellar, the city will have access to state
funding for specific projects that were included in the application. Some of the
proposed projects include Overlook at Riverside Park, Morgan Street Corridor,
Flatrock Run Trailhead and Bike Hub, Campaign Quarters, Riverside Park Gateway
Plaza, Downtown Commercial Building Revitalization and Neighborhood
Revitalization. There are also several complimentary project ideas.

Rushville and Rush County leaders and residents certainly have spent time,
talent, energy and effort reimaging a more vibrant, appealing, prosperous,
stronger, stellar community. As previously shared, Rushville's Stellar
designation means the city is at the front of the line to apply for funding from
three state agencies: Indiana Department of Transportation (federal funds),
Indiana Office of Community and Rural Affairs and the Indiana Housing and
Community Development Authority.

It's important to understand what the Stellar program is and what it is not. It
is NOT A GRANT PROGRAM. There is NO pot of money to be drawn from and handed to
community leaders to spend. There are funding sources at the state and federal
level and by being chosen a Stellar Community Designee, Rushville is at the
front of the line to apply for those funds. Rushville's Stellar projects qualify
for these available funding sources.

Rushville is required to be locked in on the parameters set, meaning the seven
Stellar projects included in the city's Strategic Investment Plan submitted to
state officials are the only city initiatives eligible for state or federal
funding and the only projects the city's local investment dollars can help fund.

The total cost investment for the seven projects is $17,983,869 of which local
investment is $3.9 million over three to five years. Two community partners are
contributing funding with Rush County giving $240,000 over four years and the
Rush County Community Foundation providing $100,000 over the next four years.
The remaining funding is coming from a variety of state and federal agencies,
including monies available through the Indiana Office of Community and Rural
Affairs, the Indiana Department of Transportation (federal funds) and the
Indiana Housing and Community Development Authority.

Stellar is a three to five year process. Below you will find a "rough" timeline
of events.

--First 1-2 years -- Engineering/Design Phase for Projects

--Last 2-5 years -- Implementation and Construction of Projects

So behind closed doors, Mayor Mike Pavey and Director of Special Projects Brian
Sheehan, along with many others, are strategically planning the next steps for
the program and will start training this month.

"I feel like for the next two months you won't be seeing anything from the
outside perspective," Sheehan said. "We are in the planning stage right now; it
is kind of like learning all the rules, the process, etc. The only thing we have
now that is different is we are working through the initial process/planning
mode and are getting to the point of training."

This month the team will be going through training with the state and will
continue until April.

"Near the end of the month, we are going through a number of workshops and
meetings to prepare. Our next meeting is 'engaging the community in the
process.' There is a four-training session that will end in April," Sheehan
added.

The first meeting is Jan. 20.

"Stellar is a marathon, not a sprint," Pavey said. "Right now, we are working
harder and more than we will down the road and people just don't see it. The
community can expect the projects to occur between years two and four. We want
to stress that to the community that we are working toward that and are building
up to it. We are currently in the process of enhancing the community. We will
have a meeting with previous Stellar winners and learn from them. The state will
be coming to the meetings and teaching us more and more at each workshop."

"With the application and design process, there will be a lot happening. Most
projects won't be completed until 2018-2019," Sheehan said.

Down the road there will be regular opportunities for the community to stay
involved such as formal City Council hearing, project design open houses,
Facebook and website updates, periodic online surveys and press releases.

Currently, the program delivery schedule is as follows:

--The Overlook at Riverside -- 2019-2020

--Campaign Quarters -- 2019

--Downtown Commercial Building Revitalization -- 2019-2020

--Neighborhood Owner-Occupied Rehabilitation -- 2019-2020

--Flatrock Trail and Bike Hub -- 2021

--Morgan Street Corridor and Pedestrian Alley Improvements -- 2021

Questions about Stellar can be directed to Brian Sheehan at
bsheehan@cityofrushville.in.gov

Contact Kate Thurston at kate.thurston@rushvillerepublican.com

___ (c)2017 The Rushville Republican (Rushville, Ind.) Visit The Rushville
Republican (Rushville, Ind.) at rushvillerepublican.com Distributed by Tribune
Content Agency, LLC.

                       TELEGRAM & GAZETTE (Massachusetts)

                           January 22, 2009 Thursday
                                 FINAL EDITION

City goes back to the same well;
Debt service on $5.8M loan

BYLINE: Nick Kotsopoulos, TELEGRAM & GAZETTE STAFF

SECTION: LOCAL NEWS; Pg. B1

LENGTH: 757 words

DATELINE: WORCESTER


For the second time in six months, the city has to dig into its pockets to pay
the debt service owed on the $5.8 million federal loan it received for the
Gardner Kilby Hammond Revitalization Project in the Main South area.

Between August 2004 and February 2008, payments on that loan obligation were
made from federal earmarks secured for the city by U.S. Rep. James. P. McGovern,
D-Worcester, during the federal budget process.

In total, Mr. McGovern was able to obtain $1.1 million in federal money to pay
for the city's debt service on the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban
Development Section 108 Loan, as part of more than $8 million in overall federal
money that has been awarded for the Main South project.

But City Manager Michael V. O'Brien said the availability of more federal money
for that purpose has dried up for the time being.

"Due to the Bush administration's opposition to the authorization of federal
earmarks for local projects, as well as budget pressures due to the war effort,
a succession of natural disasters, and national economic pressures due to the
foreclosure and Wall Street crises, federal outlays for projects such as the
Gardner Kilby Hammond initiative were not approved in the past two federal
budget cycles," Mr. O'Brien said.

To make its debt service payment last August, the manager said, the city had to
use unexpended balances from the previous year's federal Community Development
Block Grant programs. Faced with having to make another payment Monday, the city
is using that same strategy.

The City Council Tuesday night approved the use of $132,939 in prior-year
unexpended balances from block grant programs so the city can make debt payment
on the loan.

But with another $232,061 debt payment due in August, Assistant City Manager
Julie A. Jacobson warned, that funding source the city tapped to make the last
two payments has also run dry.

"We will not have sufficient (Community Development Block Grant) unexpended
balances to make additional payments due in August and future years without
additional federal earmarks," Ms. Jacobson said. "If additional federal funding
is not received, we will recommend funding this debt service through our annual
(block grant) entitlement in the amount of $365,000 (annually)."

Ms. Jacobson said such a course of action would have a significant impact on
those agencies and services that receive block grant funds from the city.

She said if the city were to default on its payment obligation, the U.S.
Department of Housing and Urban Development would automatically take the money
out of the city's annual block grant allocation until the debt obligation is
resolved.

Mr. O'Brien said he has been assured by Mr. McGovern that the Gardner Kilby
Hammond project remains a high priority on his legislative agenda and the
manager said he is cautiously optimistic that future federal funding will be
secured for the project.

"We are grateful for the congressman's support of this initiative, and for his
leadership and commitment to continuing to seek federal earmarks to fund the
ongoing debt service needs of this pivotal project," Mr. O'Brien said.

The total loan issued for the project is $5.8 million. Ms. Jacobson said the
total amount of principal and interest on that note will be slightly more than
$10 million over its 20-year term. She said the current principal balance on the
loan is $4.7 million and debt service payments will run through August 2024. The
annual debt service payments will average about $365,000 a year during the life
of the loan, with balloon payments due in 2018 ($1.87 million) and 2024 ($1.27
million), she said.

The Section 108 loan was issued to the city for site acquisition, demolition and
preparation of a 7.5-acre parcel in Main South, so it could be redeveloped and
provide recreational opportunities for Clark University and neighborhood
residents through the Gardner Kilby Hammond Neighborhood Initiative - a $30
million public-private effort to revitalize a blighted 30-acre tract in that
area.

The recreational components of the redevelopment initiative include the new $7.5
million Boys & Girls Club, which opened in September 2006, as well as a $2.5
million track and field complex that will be constructed by Clark University and
made available to those who use the Boys & Girls Club.

"It is anticipated that the proposed track and field facility will be
constructed and opened by the end of calendar 2009," Ms. Jacobson said. "Clark
University will purchase 4.5 acres of the 7.5-acre parcel for this element of
the project."

                        Manawatu Standard (New Zealand)

                            February 6, 2017 Monday

In brief

SECTION: NEWS; NATIONAL; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 295 words


Car hits tree

A man was taken to Palmerston North Hospital after a car crashed into a tree.
Emergency services were called to Ruahine St, between Windsor St and Linmor
Place, in Palmerston North after a Subaru ran into a tree at 8am on Saturday.
Traffic was diverted around the scene while firefighters worked to free an
injured man trapped in the car. A St John Ambulance spokesman said the man was
then taken to hospital in a critical condition. Palmerston North Hospital
spokesman Dennis Geddis said the man's condition had stabilised later that
afternoon.

Flight cancelled

An Air New Zealand flight from Auckland to Palmerston North was cancelled on
Sunday due to crew illness. Air New Zealand spokeswoman Kelly Kilgour said
affected customers were put on to other flights, and no other services were
impacted.

UFB coming

Otaki, Foxton and Shannon are among the towns that will receive ultra-fast
broadband under phase two of the Government's rural broadband initiative
programme. Phase two will extend to an additional 151 towns and 43 suburban
fringe areas located around the larger centres covered by the first phase of the
programme, including Levin. It will start in 2017 and be completed between 2018
and 2024. UFB uses fibre-optic cables and can typically provide download speeds
of up to 100 megabits per second and, in some areas, up to 1000 Mbps.

Applications open

Horowhenua District Council is again inviting applications for funding from the
community grants schemes it administers. Applications to the Horowhenua
Community Development Grant, Community Consultation Grant, Creative Communities
Grant and the Shannon Community Development Grant, for round two of the
2016/2017 financial year, close on February 28. Visit the council website for
more information.

Utah: Coca-Cola Foundation

LENGTH: 422  words

DATELINE: Salt Lake City


Office of Rural Assistance Center, The State of Utah has issued the following
news release:

Sponsor  Coca-Cola Foundation
Deadlines  Applications accepted on an ongoing basis
Contact

1 Coca-Cola Plaza
Atlanta, Georgia 30301
Email: cocacolacommunityrequest@na.ko.com
Purpose

The Coca-Cola Foundation provides grants in the following areas:

Water Stewardship:
    Funding to support access to clean water and sanitation, watershed
protection in water-stressed regions, utilization of water for production and or
multiple use systems that do more than provide clean drinking water, education
and awareness programs that promote water conservation within communities and
industry.
    Healthy and Active Lifestyles:
    Funding to support access to exercise, physical activity and nutritional
education programs, programs that motivate behavior modification, and programs
that encourage lifestyle/behavioral changes.
    Community Recycling:
    Funding to increase liter abatement efforts, advance recovery and reuse,
increase community recycling awareness, and support research and innovation
    Education:
    Funding to support scholarships, school drop-out prevention, access to
education programs, and other education initiatives, per local business unit
priorities

Eligibility

The Coca-Cola Foundation does not make grants to:

Individuals (except through college scholarships); schools; religious
organizations or endeavors; political, legislative, lobbying or fraternal
organizations; travel, fundraising events or sponsorships, capital campaigns,
construction or renovation projects
    Organizations that do not have tax-exempt status under Section 501(c)(3) of
the Internal Revenue Code, or the equivalent
    Organizations formed outside the U. S. that do not have a charitable
equivalency status under the laws and provisions of their respective government
    Organizations that advocate support, practices, activities, inconsistent
with The Coca-Cola Company's non-discrimination policies, whether based on race,
color, religion, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, age or
disability

Geographic
coverage  Nationwide
Amount of
funding

Over the last ten years, the Foundation has contributed more than $305 million
in support of community programs and initiatives.

process

                             386 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                           Bangor Daily News (Maine)

                             June 20, 2006 Tuesday
                                 State Edition

Ashland, Van Buren receive grants to help fund local projects;
County gets money for labor database

BYLINE: BEURMOND BANVILLE OF THE NEWS STAFF

SECTION: Pg. B3

LENGTH: 427 words

DATELINE: CARIBOU


Ashland, Van Buren and Aroostook County have received grants from the United
States Department of Agriculture and the Department of Housing and Urban
Development to assist with housing programs and to update a survey of employees
and employers in Maine's northernmost county.

The Ashland Housing Corp. has been given a grant of $391,215 for its housing
needs, Van Buren is receiving $346,500 and Aroostook County will get $180,000,
according to Sens. Olympia Snowe and Susan Collins.

The money comes from nearly $4.5 million distributed throughout the state by the
two federal agencies.

The Economic Development Initiative money can only be used in projects where
Section 108 Loan Program money is used.

"This funding will help provide vital opportunities for rural Mainers to enhance
community services and health care facilities and boost economic growth in areas
that need it the most," the two senators wrote in a joint statement. "Many
Americans aspire to own their own home and funding provided by the Department of
Housing and Urban Development can often help make that dream a reality."

Daniel Lapointe, community development director at Van Buren, said the grant is
part of the package for infrastructure work at the town's regional business
park.

The grant is one of three sources of funding. Van Buren also received $499,800
from USDA Rural Development and $150,000 from the state's Municipal Investment
Trust Fund.

The entire project is just shy of $1 million. It will pay for sewer and water
line installation, construction of a road to the site, and the installation of
other needed utilities.

The regional business park, located near the town's Gateway School, will have
five lots for business and industrial use.

Lapointe said the town is now in the design phase and officials hope that
construction will begin in the fall. They are awaiting Maine Department of
Environmental Protection permits for the project.

In Ashland, the money will be used to rehabilitate a 32-year-old housing
project. The 24-unit project, known as Forest View Circle Apartments, according
to Shawn Pelletier of CS Management Inc., is owned by the Ashland Housing Corp.

Officials hope to start the rehabilitation project around Aug. 1.

The work includes roof and siding work, windows, electrical and plumbing
components, heating upgrades, the remodeling of kitchens and some earthwork.

The Aroostook County money will be used to update surveys of the county's labor
force. The data will be integrated into a database maintained by the Maine
Department of Labor and the U.S. Census Bureau.

LOAD-DATE: June 20, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             387 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                         Deming Headlight (New Mexico)

                           January 30, 2013 Wednesday

HUD approves $42 million in loan guarantee to New Mexicans

BYLINE: For the Headlight

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 351 words


ALBUQUERQUE - The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development announced
that it is approving a $42 million loan guarantee to the state of New Mexico.
This federal loan guarantee assistance is a first for the state, which will
establish a loan fund to support economic development projects in smaller, often
rural communities throughout New Mexico.

The State estimates that these projects will create 844 new jobs, primarily for
the benefit of low- and moderate-income persons.

This is not a HUD loan. HUD's Section 108 Loan Guarantee Assistance Program
enables local governments to borrow money at reduced interest rates to promote
economic development, stimulate job growth and improve public facilities.

Such public 'guarantee' is often needed to inspire private capital
contributions, to provide seed money or to simply boost confidence that private
firms and individuals may need to invest in distressed areas.

The security for the loan guarantee not only includes a pledge by the state of
its current and future Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) funds, but also
will include the pledge of assets related to the economic development projects
assisted with this loan guarantee financing.

"HUD's Loan Guarantee Program can be a powerful public investment tool to drive
economic development in underserved areas," said HUD Acting Regional
Administrator Mark Brezina. "The program will be a boost to community
revitalization efforts and provide jobs for residents who need them most."

New Mexico's Department of Finance and Administration, Local Government
Division, will administer this initiative to eligible communities across New
Mexico that meet program and financial underwriting criteria and have been
reviewed by the state Community Development Council.

HUD's mission is to create strong, sustainable, inclusive communities and
quality affordable homes for all. HUD is working to strengthen the housing
market to bolster the economy and protect consumers; meet the need for quality
affordable rental homes.

More information about HUD and its programs is available on the Internet at
www.hud.gov.
