MONTEREY

Mazda Raceway CEO nominated for award

Gill Campbell, CEO and general manager of Mazda Raceway Laguna Seca, has been
nominated for the Silicon Valley/San Jose Business Journal's Women of
Distinction Award and will be honored at a dinner tonight.

During the past five years, Campbell has spearheaded several capital improvement
projects and the return to the U.S. of MotoGP World Championship motorcycle
racing through the raceway's Red Bull U.S. Grand Prix.

For the raceway's 2007 schedule, call (800) 327-SECA, or see
www.laguna-seca.com.

SALINAS

Three nonprofits get $150,000 grant

Three local nonprofits that help increase ownership and wealth opportunities for
farmworkers and other low-income residents will receive a major grant from the
National Rural Funders Collaborative.

The Agricultural and Land-Based Training Association, El Pájaro Community
Development Corporation and the Salinas United Business Association will receive
$150,000 per year for two years to continue their organizations' work, which
includes small-business development and education, increased farm and
homeownership opportunities, and better access to capital.

The three nonprofits, collectively known as the Salinas and Pájaro Valleys Small
and Micro-Business Initiative, are one of five regional initiatives across the
country to receive funding from the collaborative. Rai$ing Change, an South
Monterey County initiative focused on creating wealth-building opportunities for
small business and farm development among local farmworkers and immigrants, also
received a grant.

MONTEREY

German winemaker to be guest on 'Tasty Planet'

German winemaker Rainer Lingenfelder will discuss "Post-Chardonnism" and the
business of making and selling wine in a growing global marketplace on
Saturday's "Tasty Planet" radio show, 1 to 4 p.m. on KRXA 540AM.

Host Scott Dick will talk to Chef Dory Ford of Bon Appetite Management Company
and the Monterey Bay Aquarium and Claudia Goebbels, a German television
journalist and chef instructor on food trends in Germany.

The show can be heard live, and podcasts are available at www.tastyplanet.org.

MOSS LANDING

Boot camp to cover nonprofit accounting

A one-day Nonprofit Accounting Boot Camp will be held 9:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. April
18 at Moss Landing Marine Laboratories, 8272 Moss Landing Road.

The boot camp is an effort to strengthen the financial accounting and reporting
processes of nonprofits statewide. Alan Strand, director of finance and quality
reporting for the California Association of Nonprofits, will lead the workshop.

Staff members and volunteers who are responsible for the accounting, financial
reporting and related tasks at Central Coast nonprofits are invited to attend.

Cost is $50 for California Association of Nonprofit members and $75 for others.
For information or to register, call (213) 347-2070, ext. 205, or see
www.CAnonprofits.org.

                              The Washington Post

                             June 23, 2001 Saturday
                                 Final Edition

In Va., an Uphill Battle for Water;
Volunteers Help Lay Pipes to Their Mountain Homes In Rare Venture With
Government

BYLINE: Craig Timberg, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: METRO; Pg. B01

LENGTH: 1303 words

DATELINE: PEAPATCH, Va.


Here in the coal country of southwest Virginia, wells dry up so often there's an
expression for it: "The mine sunk my well." Water disappears through cracks in
the earth as miners dig under mountain hamlets like this one, and homes that had
plentiful water for years get one last flush, then nothing.

Half of the region's 30,000 wells and springs have gone bad over the past
decade, according to some estimates, forcing an increasingly desperate search
for solutions. Roofs become cisterns, with gutters draining into giant barrels.
Hauling water becomes a weekly chore. And conservation -- watching every shower,
every load of laundry -- becomes a way of life.

It was against this setting of chronic, crippling water shortages that state
officials saw an opportunity for a new type of program that mixes traditional
government largess with the community spirit once used to raise barns and build
schoolhouses. Taxpayers pick up the cost of the pipes and equipment, but the
area's residents do the labor, showing how a self-interested brand of
volunteerism can bring services to communities that otherwise might not get
them.

Officials acknowledge that the program is only a small part of solving the
region's $ 283 million worth of water problems, but it is offering hope to those
in Peapatch and other remote rural communities that water may soon flow again.

"I'd like to have it so when the kids come home, they can shower all they want,"
said Gay Hale, 85, whose well went mostly dry a half-century ago and who still
raised four children at home through a combination of inventiveness and sheer
will.

She can hardly wait for the day, now about a month away, when Peapatch's own
waterline finally will give her enough water to keep her garden fresh through
the summer heat. "You come back . . . when we get water and see my flowers,"
Hale said.

Not far down White Mountain, a dozen men from the area -- including Hale's son
and grandson -- were laying four-inch water pipes for an extension that will
soon snake nine miles up to Peapatch, elevation 2,970 feet.

The older men were flagging traffic. And all but the two county employees
overseeing the work were donating their time, a sacrifice that makes the project
financially feasible in the most economically distraught region in the state.

Virginia has built 14 water projects, mostly in the coalfields region, using the
self-help program. With funding from the federal Community Development Block
Grant program, the Appalachian Regional Commission and some local sources, the
projects have extended water to 520 homes at a cost of $ 3.1 million, or just
under $ 6,000 a home. Hiring contractors to do the same job, program officials
say, would have cost nearly three times as much, if the work had been done at
all.

The push for the self-help programs comes from a nonprofit group in Upstate New
York called the Rensselaerville Institute, which promotes community development.
Only Texas has used the approach more often than Virginia, though nationwide
hundreds of projects have been built this way in at least 17 states, including
Maryland, said Jane Schautz, who recently retired from the institute. The model
also has been used for public health initiatives and road construction in rural
communities.

"It works because people see themselves as integral to the solution, and their
creativity is freed," Schautz said.

Advocates for the program had to overcome the skepticism of bureaucrats who had
trouble imagining residents working for free. "I thought it was the craziest,
kookiest thing I'd ever heard of," said James G. Wallace, an official with the
state's Department of Housing and Community Development, which oversees the
program.

That was before he met Thurmon Hackworth Jr., 49, a disabled coal miner whom
friends and neighbors call "Junior." He broke his back twice during a mining
career of more than 25 years. Now, he's what program officials call a "spark
plug," because he has organized and motivated the community to build the
Peapatch waterline, even though his contribution to the physical labor is
limited.

He moved up on White Mountain, on the road to Peapatch, four years ago, putting
a mobile home next to a house long owned by his mother-in-law and hooking up to
a well. A few months later, Hackworth awoke in the middle of the night, used the
toilet and it didn't refill. He spent the next day buying a 325-gallon tank and
filling it with water that flowed out of an abandoned mine at the base of the
mountain.

"If you run out of water, it doesn't matter how you feel. If you're sick or
tired, you still have to do it," Hackworth said.

Such tales are common in and around Peapatch, which has 50 homes, six
cemeteries, three churches and stunning mountain views of nearby West Virginia.
The pea patches for which the town is named are long gone, as is the Peapatch
Post Office. And the nearest shopping is an hour away down steep, twisty roads.

Folks here make an unspoken trade: clean mountain air -- and the freedom to live
in peace that only remoteness guarantees -- in exchange for making water
management a central part of every day.

That means fast showers. Or washing children two by two in a tub. Or keeping an
old wringer washer because it uses less water than a modern one. And forget
about washing the car or watering the grass. Such suburban comforts are hard to
justify when the county's water truck may not make a delivery for another week.

Coal mining gets most of the blame around here for the region's water troubles,
though drilling for natural gas and the region's three-year-old drought also are
culprits, local officials say. Drilling and mining break the aquifers that feed
the wells, draining away groundwater in a region that already has little in the
way of natural reserves.

A state law passed in 1992 requires that coal companies replace water sources
they damage, though such cases can be difficult to prove. Many problems started
before the law was passed, meaning there is no clear legal remedy, though a
portion of the tax on coal mining funds water projects.

"Industry does, as required by statute, replace water that it damages and
frequently goes beyond what's required by law," said W. Thomas Hudson, president
of the Virginia Coal Association, an industry trade group.

"It's a societal problem," he said, "and everybody ought to contribute to it."

Everyone does. State Del. Clarence E. "Bud" Phillips, a Democrat from nearby
Dickenson County, says tens of millions of state and federal tax dollars flow to
the region for water projects each year.

Phillips, a lawyer who sometimes sues coal companies in water cases, said only
more money can solve problems, though self-help programs do some good. The other
option is for residents to move, which many are reluctant to do because of the
deep roots of mountain families.

"Our people are very independent-minded," Phillips said. "They feel very
comfortable in these mountains and don't want to leave. . . . Why should we
leave if the problems weren't caused by us?"

Yet some do leave. At the base of White Mountain, in Jewell Valley, is a row of
identical houses, abandoned and overgrown with weeds. The old mining camp nearly
emptied out 15 years ago when a coal company shuttered the mine the camp was
built to serve. When the company turned off the water system, most residents
moved away.

Then last summer, the same waterline that is heading up to Peapatch ran through
Jewell Valley. Suddenly, there was no more hauling water, no more watching every
drop that came out of the faucet. Residents were so grateful that some
volunteered for the Peapatch project.

"I'm tickled to death with it. You can't do without water," said David
Hackworth, 47, a nephew of Junior, as they worked on the waterline. "We don't
save a drop."

                            Buffalo News (New York)

                             July 17, 2010 Saturday
                                 FINAL EDITION

Grants approved to renovate housing

BYLINE: By Jonathan D. Epstein - NEWS BUSINESS REPORTER

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. C6

LENGTH: 426 words


New York state's housing agencies have approved $1.1 million in grants to
Western New York organizations and municipalities to renovate affordable housing
and support growth and job creation by small businesses.

The money, allocated by two related agencies on Thursday to five entities in
Buffalo and outlying areas, is part of $18.4 million in grants and financings
that the state awarded to build or renovate affordable housing, help businesses
grow and support homeowners facing foreclosure.

Of that, the New York State Housing Finance Agency's Affordable Housing Corp.
approved $13 million in financings to build or renovate 598 affordable housing
units.

Also, the Housing Finance Agency's Housing Trust Fund Corp. approved another
$5.4 million through three different programs. That includes $2 million in state
Community Development Block Grants that will help create 148 jobs for low- and
moderate-income families, and another $3.2 million to enable organizations
around the state to provide free, professional foreclosure prevention and
counseling services.

Specifically, in Erie County, the AHC approved dual $200,000 grants to the Town
of Amherst and the Lt. Col. Matt Urban Human Services Center of Western New
York. Amherst will use the money for its Home Rehabilitation Matching Grant
Program to pay for renovations of 40 homes in the town, while the Urban Center
will finance renovations to 20 single-family homes in Buffalo.

The Housing Trust Fund Corp. also awarded a $200,000 grant through its Urban
Initiatives Program to rehab a two-story building and renovate two affordable
apartments in Buffalo.

In other area counties, the AHC gave out a $300,000 grant to the Rural Housing
Opportunities Corp. to buy and rehabilitate 10 single-family homes in Genesee,
Orleans and three other counties in the Rochester area.

The Housing Trust Fund Corp. awarded $105,000 in Community Development Block
Grant money for Wyoming County to help Steel & O'Brien Manufacturing expand and
create seven jobs. Another $500,000 will come from private financing.

That agency also gave $90,000 in block grant money to Wyoming County to help RS
Maher & Sons expand and add five jobs, using another $140,000 in private money.

Additionally, the AHC approved an $875,000 grant to Habitat for Humanity of New
York State to build 25 homes in 11 counties statewide, including Erie County.
And it approved a $600,000 grant to the Bishop Sheen Ecumenical Housing
Foundation for home improvements of 112 homes in 12 counties, including Allegany
County.

e-mail: jepstein@buffnews.com

                                US Official News

                           February 14, 2015 Saturday

Tennessee: Pilot Program Encourages Microenterprise

LENGTH: 886  words

DATELINE: Nashville


The state of Tennessee has issued the following news release:

The Tennessee Department of Economic and Community Development is launching
"LiftTN: Microenterprise," a pilot program to expand microenterprise development
across the state. The program--funded through the United States Department of
Housing and Urban Development (HUD)--is aimed at helping businesses that have
five or fewer employees expand. $400,000 in total grant money is being awarded
over a two-year contract to these five grantees:

o    West TN: altShops through Communities Unlimited ($100,000)
o    East TN: Mentor-Protégée Program through Knoxville Chamber of Commerce
($50,000)
o    Middle and Statewide: Incubator Without Walls Expansion Program through
Nashville
      Business Incubation Center ($200,000)
o    Community-based Program: Sonneschein Green Initiatives (SGI) Marketplace in
Hohenwald ($25,000)
o    Youth: TN Code Academy for Youth ($25,000)

"I am extremely pleased TNECD can participate in this pilot program," Economic
and Community Development Commissioner Randy Boyd said. "Encouraging and
supporting entrepreneurship is an important piece of a robust economic
development strategy, as entrepreneurs choose to stay here and invest in our
state, which ultimately helps create jobs and sustain long-term community
growth."

In order to determine the grant recipients, TNECD--through its office of federal
programs and the Business Enterprise Resource Office (BERO)--held four meetings
across the state in January and February 2014. The purpose of those meetings was
to gather information regarding unmet needs of microenterprises from agencies
and organizations that work with small, women-owned, minority-owned,
veteran-owned, rural and urban core businesses as well as youth entrepreneurs.

"Through the five selected programs, microenterprises will have access to
invaluable services and opportunities that will improve lives and communities,"
TNECD's BERO Director, Wisty Pender, said. "'LiftTN: Microenterprise' is unique
because of the diverse nature of the programs involved. All five engage in a
wide range of activities that will serve as a template for possible future
expansion of this pilot program."

"When HUD encouraged us to use more Community Development Block Grant (CDBG)
funding to support economic development, we decided to focus on microenterprise
businesses," TNECD's Director of Federal Programs, Brooxie Carlton said. "It's
exciting to use some of our CDBG funds in this new way because it allows us to
serve very small businesses across Tennessee. The goal is to continue the
program beyond this two-year pilot period, ultimately expanding it throughout
the state."

Communities Unlimited will use the grant funds to operate the altShops program
in the Bolivar and Somerville downtown areas. The altShops program is a business
incubator program for popup retail shops that recruits business owners and
assists them with startup costs, leasing of commercial property and other
technical assistance The altShops program will fund three microenterprises in
Bolivar and three microenterprises in Somerville.

The Knoxville Chamber will use the funds to operate the Propel, a
mentor-protégée program in cooperation with the respective chambers in Knox,
Roane, Blount, Jefferson and Anderson Counties. Propel will pair protégés
(microenterprises), which are relatively new to business with mentors who are
established business leaders. In addition to a mentor, each protégé will receive
coaching and technical assistance.

Growth Enterprises Nashville will use their grant to expand the capacity of the
Incubator Without Walls ("Virtual Incubator"), a program that provides virtual
business incubation. Participants in the Virtual Incubator will receive
one-on-one business counseling, as well as location-based training classes.

Center for Holistic Ecology currently conducts the Sonnenschein Green Initiative
(SGI) that promotes ecologically friendly business activity in the Hohenwald
community and surrounding areas. The grant money will allow SGI to establish and
operate the Hohenwald Marketplace, a place for local vendors to operate and sell
services and goods.

The TN Code Academy will use grant funds to expand the reach of its TN Code
Academy for Youth, a program that conducts one-day workshops, camps and classes
to further learning and increase interest in computer science and programming
for students between the ages of 12-18. The grant will allow TN Code Academy to
offer "Apps and Entrepreneurship", teaching youth not only how to make an app,
but how to monetize what they create.

About the Tennessee Department of Economic and Community Development
Tennessee was named 2014 and 2013 "State of the Year" for economic development
by Business Facilities magazine. The Tennessee Department of Economic and
Community Development's mission is to develop strategies which help make
Tennessee the No. 1 location in the Southeast for high quality jobs. The
department seeks to attract new corporate investment in Tennessee and works with
Tennessee companies to facilitate expansion and economic growth. Find us on the
web: tnecd.com. Follow us on Twitter: @tnecd.  Like us on Facebook:
facebook.com/tnecd.

In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

                          Business Day (South Africa)

                               February 08, 2007
                              Business Day Edition

Microsoft charity going begging

BYLINE: Lesley Stones

SECTION: HUMAN INTEREST; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 402  words


Microsoft charity going begging

NOT enough charities are coming forward with sensible business plans to win
donations from Microsoft SA, the company says.

Microsoft makes more contributions to social responsibility initiatives than any
other hi-tech company, donating $68m in cash and $331m in software to non-profit
organisations throughout the world last year.

Yet the charities in SA are not professional enough in their approach to win
more of that support, says Lungile Lose, Microsoft SA's community affairs
manager. Instead of being inundated with requests for cash and free software,
Microsoft SA often has to sit with the charities and show them how they could
benefit, he says.

Those that do seek funding often need help in drawing up a sound proposal.

More cash would be available for SA if local worthy causes were better at
presenting initiatives that pique the interest of its parent company, but they
lose out to charities in other countries that are far more professional in their
requests for cash.

"In this country, we have to work closely with non-governmental organisations to
encourage them to come up with proposals," Lose says.

This year, Microsoft SA has approved grants of about R1,5m, up 46% from last
year because some charities presented better business plans.

"The grants are issued on a competitive basis worldwide, so we compete with the
Middle East and Africa for grant allocations," says Lose. The firm was pleased
to get more funds allocated to SA. "We got a 46% increase because our programmes
this year have much more national impact."

Last month, Microsoft SA handed over the first R800000 and will donate software
to three organisations working to improve their communities. One was Skills
Development and Economic Independence of the Disabled, a body helping physically
disabled people earn a living by setting up income-generating centres in each
province by 2008.

Cash also went to the E-community Development Forum, a Western Cape project
helping to set up more centres to provide access to government information over
the internet in rural areas. The third donation went to a Telecentre "Train the
Trainer" project to develop the skills of telecentre operators.

Microsoft SA aims to work with local organisations to help at least 775000
people realise their potential through the use of technology over the next three
years, says Chose Choeu, its director of law and corporate affairs.

LOAD-DATE: February 8, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved


                             459 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                        Progressive Media - Company News

                           December 4, 2014 Thursday

BMS awards nine new grants to fight against hepatitis B and C in China and India

SECTION: OTHER CONTRACT SERVICES; Strategy And Business Planning

LENGTH: 346 words



HIGHLIGHT: Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMS) Foundation has awarded nine new grants for
the projects in China and India, in a bid to combat Hepatitis B and C infection
in both the countries.


The multi-year grants that worth about $3.5m will be used for the projects that
focus on hepatitis B virus (HBV) and hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection in
high-risk patient populations.

The grants are being provided through the foundation's Delivering Hope
initiative that supported about 40 projects in China and India since 2002.

Bristol-Myers Squibb Foundation president John Damonti said: "Delivering Hope
continues to increase its focus on HBV and HCV in China and India, the two
countries that have the highest incidence of viral hepatitis worldwide."

The grants received in China include Peking University Education Foundation to
develop virtual community for chronic hepatitis patients to provide a support
system.

Hepatitis B Foundation, along with the Chinese Center for Disease Control and
Prevention, will develop a programme to empower rural patients to become
actively involved in their disease management.

Wu Jieping Medical Foundation will conduct a study of the present status of HCV
treatment and the factors that influence it and will investigate HCV management
and education status among specific at-risk populations.

Inno Community Development Organisation will encourage self-screening and raise
awareness among migrant workers, and will establish ten community-based
Hepatitis C Intervention Centers for the migrant population in Guangdong
Province.

In India, the grants secured include All India Institute of Diabetes and
Research for a pilot programme in Mehsana and Sabarkantha, two rural districts
in the state of Gujrat that have experienced HBV outbreaks.

MAMTA will provide training in HBV and HCV risk assessment, disease prevention
and risk management for health care providers, including doctors, nurses, lab
technicians and others who come into direct contact with hepatitis patients.

United Way of Mumbai will carry out medical interventions and extensive
community education in around 18 slum areas in Mumbai, India, while SAMARTH will
conduct training activities to strengthen partners' ability to self-monitor and
evaluate their programme's progress.

                           February 19, 2015 Thursday

Tennessee: Pilot Program Encourages Microenterprise

LENGTH: 886  words

DATELINE: Nashville


The state of Tennessee has issued the following news release:

The Tennessee Department of Economic and Community Development is launching
"LiftTN: Microenterprise," a pilot program to expand microenterprise development
across the state. The program--funded through the United States Department of
Housing and Urban Development (HUD)--is aimed at helping businesses that have
five or fewer employees expand. $400,000 in total grant money is being awarded
over a two-year contract to these five grantees:

o    West TN: altShops through Communities Unlimited ($100,000)
o    East TN: Mentor-Protégée Program through Knoxville Chamber of Commerce
($50,000)
o    Middle and Statewide: Incubator Without Walls Expansion Program through
Nashville
      Business Incubation Center ($200,000)
o    Community-based Program: Sonneschein Green Initiatives (SGI) Marketplace in
Hohenwald ($25,000)
o    Youth: TN Code Academy for Youth ($25,000)

"I am extremely pleased TNECD can participate in this pilot program," Economic
and Community Development Commissioner Randy Boyd said. "Encouraging and
supporting entrepreneurship is an important piece of a robust economic
development strategy, as entrepreneurs choose to stay here and invest in our
state, which ultimately helps create jobs and sustain long-term community
growth."

In order to determine the grant recipients, TNECD--through its office of federal
programs and the Business Enterprise Resource Office (BERO)--held four meetings
across the state in January and February 2014. The purpose of those meetings was
to gather information regarding unmet needs of microenterprises from agencies
and organizations that work with small, women-owned, minority-owned,
veteran-owned, rural and urban core businesses as well as youth entrepreneurs.

"Through the five selected programs, microenterprises will have access to
invaluable services and opportunities that will improve lives and communities,"
TNECD's BERO Director, Wisty Pender, said. "'LiftTN: Microenterprise' is unique
because of the diverse nature of the programs involved. All five engage in a
wide range of activities that will serve as a template for possible future
expansion of this pilot program."

"When HUD encouraged us to use more Community Development Block Grant (CDBG)
funding to support economic development, we decided to focus on microenterprise
businesses," TNECD's Director of Federal Programs, Brooxie Carlton said. "It's
exciting to use some of our CDBG funds in this new way because it allows us to
serve very small businesses across Tennessee. The goal is to continue the
program beyond this two-year pilot period, ultimately expanding it throughout
the state."

Communities Unlimited will use the grant funds to operate the altShops program
in the Bolivar and Somerville downtown areas. The altShops program is a business
incubator program for popup retail shops that recruits business owners and
assists them with startup costs, leasing of commercial property and other
technical assistance The altShops program will fund three microenterprises in
Bolivar and three microenterprises in Somerville.

The Knoxville Chamber will use the funds to operate the Propel, a
mentor-protégée program in cooperation with the respective chambers in Knox,
Roane, Blount, Jefferson and Anderson Counties. Propel will pair protégés
(microenterprises), which are relatively new to business with mentors who are
established business leaders. In addition to a mentor, each protégé will receive
coaching and technical assistance.

Growth Enterprises Nashville will use their grant to expand the capacity of the
Incubator Without Walls ("Virtual Incubator"), a program that provides virtual
business incubation. Participants in the Virtual Incubator will receive
one-on-one business counseling, as well as location-based training classes.

Center for Holistic Ecology currently conducts the Sonnenschein Green Initiative
(SGI) that promotes ecologically friendly business activity in the Hohenwald
community and surrounding areas. The grant money will allow SGI to establish and
operate the Hohenwald Marketplace, a place for local vendors to operate and sell
services and goods.

The TN Code Academy will use grant funds to expand the reach of its TN Code
Academy for Youth, a program that conducts one-day workshops, camps and classes
to further learning and increase interest in computer science and programming
for students between the ages of 12-18. The grant will allow TN Code Academy to
offer "Apps and Entrepreneurship", teaching youth not only how to make an app,
but how to monetize what they create.

About the Tennessee Department of Economic and Community Development
Tennessee was named 2014 and 2013 "State of the Year" for economic development
by Business Facilities magazine. The Tennessee Department of Economic and
Community Development's mission is to develop strategies which help make
Tennessee the No. 1 location in the Southeast for high quality jobs. The
department seeks to attract new corporate investment in Tennessee and works with
Tennessee companies to facilitate expansion and economic growth. Find us on the
web: tnecd.com. Follow us on Twitter: @tnecd.  Like us on Facebook:
facebook.com/tnecd.

In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com
